title: Pro/Con: Climate Control Issues?
subTitle: Molly likes constant climate change; Laura sets it and forgets it. Whose control issues match yours?
promoTeaserSmall: Molly likes constant climate change; Laura sets it and forgets it. Whose control issues match yours?
promoTeaser: Molly likes constant climate change; Laura sets it and forgets it. Whose control issues match yours?
metaDescription: Molly likes constant climate change; Laura sets it and forgets it. Whose control issues match yours?

contributors.displayName: Laura Sky Brown and Molly Jean

pageElements.text:
Laura Says: Just Chill Out about Getting the Right Temperature

When it comes to weather extremes—in or out of the car—I believe in patience. After all, I come from Michigan, a place where weather extremes are intense. I believe that it is possible to get to a level of comfort if you just take the time to trust your clothing choices and the heating or cooling technology around you. That extends not only to home and office but most especially to the car. Repeat after me: You don't need to freak out about being warm (or cold) for the ninety seconds it takes for the car's heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) system to get you to the right temperature.
Repeat after me: You don't need to freak out about being warm (or cold) for the ninety seconds it takes for the car's HVAC system to get you to the right temperature.

At the moment, I am seeing temperature gauge readings in the 80s and 90s when I climb into a car and close the door. Six months from now, I expect to see 0 or -5 degrees on the same gauge. What is the constant? My reaction. I am OK about sitting in the heat of the car for a minute. I trust the car's modern HVAC system to achieve a mid-70s level of comfort quickly, and I am almost never wrong. So I don't do what a lot of people (like my colleague Molly Jean, for example) do and roll the windows down while also blasting the air conditioning on maximum. That is a waste of resources and energy, and besides, if it's that hot inside the car, it's also hot outside, so why encourage more hot air to enter the sanctum of the passenger compartment?

The same holds true when it's icy cold out. You do not need to start and run a car for ten minutes before driving unless the cold is really extreme. You certainly don't need to do it because you are too fragile to be chilly for a few minutes and need the car to be all toasty inside before you set foot in it. Molly may be a special snowflake, too delicate for this world, but I'm not. And I believe in confronting the weather we have, not freaking out about it.

Molly Says: I'll Do What Takes to Be Comfortable, Including Roll the Window Down

When it is eighty degrees outside, like right now, the interior of a car can hover in the 120-degree range. Keep in perspective that you can consume pork at 145 degrees. So it is literally like an oven. I would not consider climbing into my oven and thinking that blowing a bit of air inside would render me comfortable in a few minutes. Nope. I will roll down my window and welcome the breeze I create as I cruise down the road for five minutes, until my HVAC can lower the temperature to an acceptable level. Seriously, there are so many things in life I can’t control that the interior of a car does not have to be one of them.
I would not consider climbing into my oven, thinking that blowing a bit of air inside would render me comfortable in a few minutes. Nope. I will roll down my window.

As for winter, we Northerners should erect a shrine to American Motors, because that ill-fated company introduced the remote starter in 1983. I know it is not the best choice for the environment, but I will double up on my recycling to make up for it. If the car I am driving does not have remote start, I use the time it takes me to scrape the windows to warm up the car. Just like cooling a car, it takes a while to warm it up enough to make a car interior comfortable. I think most readers would agree that a driver who isn’t shivering or roasting is going to be a better driver.

Lastly, I am currently suffering from major temperature swings. Read: Hot flashes. Once the heat wave subsides, I am freezing. I equate it to being shoved in a pizza oven and then plunged into Lake Superior—every twenty minutes, all day long. So I think the very best place to be is in a car, where I can fluctuate the temperature quickly. In the winter, I roll down the window and stick my head out. I know it is difficult on my passengers, but if you were in a pizza oven, wouldn’t you open the door?

title: 2016 Toyota Tacoma
subTitle: Toyota's bestselling pickup, revitalized. Is this compact truck right for you? Here's what we think.
promoTeaserSmall: Toyota's bestselling pickup, revitalized. Is this compact truck right for you? Here's what we think.
promoTeaser: Toyota's bestselling pickup, revitalized. Is this compact truck right for you? Here's what we think.
metaDescription: Toyota's bestselling pickup, revitalized. Is this compact truck right for you? Here's what we think.

pageElements.text:
2016 Toyota Tacoma TRD Sport 4x4 Double Cab

Type: Five-passenger, all-wheel-drive compact pickup
Base price (4x2 SR5 Access Cab) $26,285
This truck: $34,630 (includes destination charge)
Trim levels: SR, SR5, TRD Sport, TRD Off Road, Limited
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 278 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 18 mpg city/23 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Entune Premium Audio with integrated navigation system (standard on TRD Sport)
Options I can’t live without: Crawl control, power moonroof
Notable standard features on this model: Sliding rear glass panel, composite inner cargo bed, lockable tailgate, push-button start, tilting and telescoping steering wheel, leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift lever, windshield GoPro camera mount, Bluetooth, iPod connectivity, Siri Eyes Free, rearview camera
Notable options on this model: Tri-fold locking tonneau cover, mud guards, V-6 towing package
You might also be considering:
2016 Chevrolet Colorado LT Crew Cab 4WD ($33,430)
2016 GMC Canyon SLE Crew Cab 4WD ($35,285)
2015 Nissan Frontier SV-V6 Crew Cab 4x4 ($28,515)

After a decade of decline, compact pickup trucks are making a comeback, and Toyota’s Tacoma is at the head of the small but growing pack. That's good news for people who want the versatility of a truck but aren't interested in something with a large footprint.

To anyone following industry fortunes, this isn’t a big surprise. The Tacoma has been the big dog in this pack for the better part of the past ten years. With competition diminishing during that decade of dominance—Chrysler, Ford, and General Motors all dropped out—Toyota has seen no need to make major changes to its bestseller.

But the return of General Motors to the arena, with its all new Chevrolet Colorado and GMC Canyon, and the promise of an all-new Honda Ridgeline coming for 2017, have galvanized activity at the Tacoma truck works, and here’s the result, all new for 2016.

There are five trim levels: the basic SR work truck (from $25,030), the SR5 (from $26,285), the TRD Sport shown here (from $30,585),  theTRD Off-Road (from $33,850), and the top-end Limited (from $35,645).

All-new is always an elastic term in the auto industry, and it’s been stretched a little in this application. The foundations of the new truck are dimensionally identical to the outgoing version, suspension layout is basically unchanged, and the disc/drum braking system persists (despite disc/disc systems in competing trucks). The engine choices are similar: a 2.7-liter four-cylinder that makes 159 horsepower or a 3.5-liter V-6, replacing the previous 4.0-liter. The V-6, though, is truly new and contemporary in technology, raising output substantially, from the 4.0-liter’s 236 horsepower to 278.

There are three transmission choices: a five-speed manual that's standard with the four-cylinder, a six-speed manual that's standard with the V-6, and a six-speed automatic. And high-strength steel and selective stiffening have helped make the truck's structure more robust.

Fuel economy improves slightly, with EPA ratings that range from 19 mpg city/23 mpg highway with the base 2.7-liter engine, rear-wheel drive, and automatic transmission, to 19/24 mpg for the rear-wheel drive V-6 automatic. EPA ratings diminish with manual transmissions and/or all-wheel drive.
The four-wheel drive  is part time with a limited-slip differential and a two-speed electronic transfer case. Push a dashboard button, and you’re in high or low range.

This doesn’t seem to make much of a case for the four-cylinder engine, although there is a significant difference in MSRP.  The four-wheel drive-option is a part-time system, with a limited-slip differential and a two-speed electronic transfer case—just push a dashboard button, and you’re in either high or low range.

As you’d expect, the styling has been revitalized, with a front end treatment that’s more strongly reminiscent of the full-size Tundra pickup. The fender flares are a bit wider, putting a little more brawn into the look, and there’s 9.4 inches of ground clearance, to enhance suspension travel, part of an increased emphasis on off-road capability.

Inside, the Tacoma features a modern set of soft-touch and material upgrades, as well as more bright trim and increased infotainment and connectivity features. Most models come with cloth upholstery, but leather is available in the top-of-the-line Limited model.

Other new interior options include wireless charging, push-button start, dual-zone auto climate control, updated touchscreen audio, a blind spot monitor, rear cross-traffic alert, and a power moonroof.

Something that truck owners will appreciate is how much effort the development team spent on measures to reduce interior noise levels, including an acoustic glass windshield, improved seals, and more sound-deadening materials in the floors and headliners. Based on a day of preview driving on and off pavement, these measures seem to have been effective.

The new Tacoma will be offered in two body styles, both with a back seat. Access Cab seats four, using rear-hinged half doors for back-seat access. The Double Cab body style (shown here) has room for five, with four full doors. Rear seating is cramped in the Access Cab version, but the seats fold up to increase cargo capacity.

Speaking of cargo, there are two cargo bed lengths. Access Cab versions come with the longer of two at 73.3 inches (a little over six feet), while Double Cab models can be ordered with the long bed or the short (60.5 inches, just over five feet). The inner beds are fashioned from synthetic material, and thus don’t require bedliners, the tailgates are lockable, and there’s a little spoiler on the upper lip that Toyota claims enhances vehicle stability—without specifying what speed.

The tailgate also features a damped opening that eases it to horizontal, rather than slamming down. And the rear bumper design, carried over from the current Tacoma, makes it easy to climb into the cargo bed.

On pavement, the Tacoma is smooth, quiet, and mannerly, not what you’d expect of a truck, particularly one equipped for serious off-road use. Steering isn’t exactly sports-car precise, but as you may have noticed this isn’t a sports car.

Speaking of that, thanks to the more robust V-6, the Tacoma is now rated to tow up to 6,800 pounds, when equipped with the towing package. That’s a 300-pound improvement over the 2015 truck, and respectable for this size class—although it’s interesting to note that Toyota research places towing 22nd on the list of attributes Tacoma owners prioritize.

While the increase in V-6 power enhances the Tacoma’s work ethic, we have to say that it’s not particularly impressive in terms of stoplight getaway or passing on two-lane highways.

The Tacoma’s most impressive dynamic feature, showcased at this preview, was its new Crawl Control, available with four-wheel drive. For extreme up- or downhills, rock gardens, or deep sand, the driver simply engages Crawl Control and steers. The truck does the rest, at speeds between 2 and 5 mph.

The Verdict:

The Tacoma has ruled in this class for a long time, and figures to be a dominant player even with the arrival of impressive new rivals from General Motors. While it may not emerge as the absolute best in the mid-size comparison tests that are sure to come, and it lacks a diesel engine option (just introduced by GM), it offers twenty-nine different configurations, lots of features, Toyota’s reputation for durability and reliability, and high resale values.

Toyota puts heavy emphasis on the Tacoma’s off-road capabilities, something you’ll see in marketing messages for the new truck. The rationale, according to Toyota, is that some 40 percent of all Tacomas are acquired by young buyers who like to take their trucks to places lacking pavement or even roads. If that's you, the Tacoma is something to take a serious look at.

However, while the off-road versions may be a little extreme or irrelevant for the other 60 percent, there are other trim levels that are more mainstream—the SR5, well equipped, versatile, and affordable, and if luxury is important, the Limited model serves it up in competitive quantities.

Is a mid-size pickup right for you? Four- and five-passenger pickups have become popular as all-around haulers—the industry identifies them as lifestyle vehicles. Their usefulness and relatively tidy size (in contrast to full-size trucks) makes them attractive to men and women alike—and a sure way to enhance your neighborhood standing is to have one of these parked in your driveway. Your neighbors will be only too happy to put it to work.
Toyota's video from the Tacoma introduction

title: 2015 BMW i3 - Jean's Driveway
subTitle: Who knew a BMW would look so good in green?
promoTeaserSmall: Who knew a BMW would look so good in green?
promoTeaser: Who knew a BMW would look so good in green?
metaDescription: Who knew a BMW would look so good in green?

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/dnK7XkhutXk" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Type: Four-passenger, rear-wheel-drive compact hatchback
Trim levels: i3, i3 with Range Extender
Base price: $43,350 for i3; $47,210 for i3 with Range Extender (prices include destination charge)
This car: $52,750
Engine: All-electric motor, 170 horsepower
Transmission: Single-stage automatic
Fuel economy: 117 MPGe; 39 mpg (combined city/highway) on gasoline power
Safety: Not rated
You might also be considering (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Chevrolet Spark EV ($25,995)
2016 Kia Soul EV ($32,775)
2016 Mitsubishi i-MiEV ($23,845)
2015 Nissan Leaf ($29,860)

Fun-O-Meter: 7.5

People buy electric cars for many reasons: environmentalism, futuristic fannishness, a particular kind of acquisitive desire that makes people want to be the first to get the newest technology. But why would people spend almost $50,000 (minus potential federal and local incentives) for a city-car-size electric BMW?

Just open the door and look inside; that’s your first answer. The i3 is a runway model of a car, with an interior that is as big a fashion statement as I’ve seen in a long time. Just a look at the materials list is exciting: a lightweight but strong carbon-fiber-reinforced plastic body—quite unusual for a non-sports car—enclosing interior panels made out of renewable Asian kenaf plants, and topped off by eucalyptus wood trim to complement the soft leather seating. And it’s not just the unusual materials, it’s the manner in which they are arrayed. The eucalyptus sheets are asymmetrically applied and bent in supple curves. The information screen appears to float in midair above the low cowl.
It’s beautiful. It’s inspirational. It’s groundbreaking. All of that, but we’ve seen the larger (and more expensive) i8, which is even more gorgeous.

The BMW i3 was introduced as a 2014 model, the first in the German automaker’s new i sub-brand of electric vehicles. Its passenger cabin is the world’s first mass-produced Carbon Fiber Reinforced Plastic (CFRP) automotive passenger cell. CFRP is as strong as steel, BMW says, yet 50 percent lighter, and 30 percent lighter than aluminum. When you save weight, you save fuel.
The interior materials—lovely as they are—were also chosen for sustainability and recycle status.

Range anxiety, of course, is a big issue with an electric car. BMW addresses that with a range extender at an additional cost of $3,850. The range extender is a generator powered by a little two-cylinder gas engine that comes from a BMW motor scooter. Its job is not to drive the wheels; it’s to kick in when the electricity dips below a certain charge, and then maintain that charge. You can drive a mere seventy-two miles on a charge without it, and double that to 150 miles with it. One caveat: You really don’t want to plan a long trip; the gas engine’s 1.9-gallon capacity will have you stopping for tiny little fill-ups every, oh, seventy-five miles or so. I would say put the range extender at the top of your optional equipment list.

Then you’ll want to accessorize with the BMW iCharging station for your garage, at another additional cost ($1,080) that doesn’t include installation. It has a twenty-five-foot cord. Using it will cut charging time down to a reasonable 3.5 hours from the unaided charge time of “forever” when using a standard 110-volt household outlet.

As long as you’re using it for short jaunts, that’s no problem. It’s perhaps unfair to quibble, since you’d expect a car this small to be more of a city car, but I’m here to say that it completely handles the freeway. It is able to blow by the surrounding traffic with ease, in the all-in way that electric vehicles give you everything they have the second you hit the go pedal. The difference between lesser electrics and the i3 is that you don’t feel like it’s going to explode because you’re going too fast at 70 mph. What did happen in my test car at a steady 70 mph was a small but disconcerting side-to-side front-end drift. Most irksome.

It was enough for me to set our Fun-O-Meter at 7.5. When could that ever happen in the Perfect 10 world of the BMW driving experience? Only, perhaps, in this case, because a gorgeous interior and heady acceleration do not make up for the drawbacks of permanently thrumming range anxiety and that very un-BMW-like on-center drift. In city driving, though, the fun jumps to a solid 9.5.

The i3 I drove was well equipped, although still not fully loaded, even at $47,210. It featured the Giga World package ($1,500), which adds keyless entry, a universal garage door opener, and a set of 19-inch alloy wheels. Its stunner of a Solar Orange/Frozen Grey two-tone paint job was an additional $500. The Tech + Driving Assist package ($2,500) gives you navigation, adaptive cruise control, BMW online and BMW apps, and advanced real-time traffic information. Not present on our i3 were a Harman Kardon sound system ($800) or a set of 20-inch alloy wheels ($1,300).

It’s questionable, the value of spending this kind of money for an EV when gas prices seem to be on a lowering trend. As a consumer vehicle, the i3 is the most expensive car in its class by a long shot. Certainly there is the Tesla Model S, at $75,000 before incentives, but other electric-powered competitors—the Nissan Leaf, the Chevrolet Volt, the Toyota Prius Plug-in, and EV versions of the Chevrolet Spark and the Kia Soul—are much more popularly priced in the mid-$20,000s-to-low-$30,000s range.

The BMW i3s you might see in the wild will be rare birds indeed. But they will most definitely stand out from the more common Volts and Leafs and Priuses and Sparks, which will go by unnoticed. Discerning owners of the i3 will appreciate that, you can be sure.

But now and then, every i3 driver should leave the confines of the urban hood and take to the highway just to experience that instantaneous, full-on blast of the i3’s mashed-foot-pedal, absolutely electric acceleration.
Get a little extra bang for those fifty thousand bucks.

title: 2015 Porsche Macan
subTitle: The Cayenne’s peppy little brother.
promoTeaserSmall: The Cayenne’s peppy little brother.
promoTeaser: The Cayenne’s peppy little brother.
metaKeywords: 2015 Porsche Macan; Porsche; SUV; sport-utility; crossover; German
metaDescription: The Cayenne’s peppy little brother. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive SUV/crossover
Price range: $50,895–$73,295 (includes destination)
Trim levels: Macan S, Turbo
Engines: 3.0-liter V-6, 340 horsepower; twin-turbocharged 3.6-liter V-6, 400 horsepower
Transmission: Seven-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 17 mpg city/23 mpg highway
Safety ratings: Not rated by either NHTSA or IIHS
Our favorite standard feature: All-wheel drive
Notable standard features on this model: Three-zone climate control, bi-xenons headlights, sport steering wheel
Notable options on this model: Adaptive damping, cargo management system, lane-keep assist
You might also be considering: Audi Q5, BMW X3, Mercedes-Benz GLK

After the sales success of the Cayenne SUV, adding a compact crossover to its model range was a no-brainer for Porsche. The Macan went on sale for the 2015 model year, and so far the only problem is that Porsche can’t build enough of them. In fact, the only Porsche that outsells the Macan is the Cayenne.

The fact that two SUVs sit atop the sales sheet doesn’t mean that Porsche has abandoned its sports car roots, though. Take the Macan on a curvy road, and it displays razor-sharp handling, with minimal body roll and exceptional turn-in. The cabin is comfortable and well put together, with quality materials and construction. All of the important controls are within easy reach, although the plethora of buttons on the center console can be confusing.

The base model is the Macan S, which has a 340-horsepower, 3.0-liter V-6 and comes standard with nineteen-inch wheels shod with all-season tires, an eleven-speaker audio system, a seven-inch TFT display, Bluetooth, three-zone automatic climate control, bi-xenon headlights, a multi-function sport steering wheel, piano black interior trim, split-folding rear seats, a power tailgate, and 17.7 cubic feet of storage capacity behind the rear seats (53.0 cubic feet with the rear seats folded).

The Turbo model gets a more powerful engine, adaptive damping, unique wheels, full leather upholstery, and an upgraded audio system. You can get some of the Turbo’s standard features as options on the Macan S, and there is also an extensive standalone options list for both models that includes high-tech performance items like torque vectoring, active suspension management, and ceramic composite brakes.

So far, the Macan has been a huge success for Porsche. In fact, most of the German automaker’s sales gains over the past year can be traced directly to this new model. Porsche recently stated that it would start ramping up production of the Macan. This is welcome news to prospective buyers, who have had to wait up to six months in some locations for their new vehicle. A wait, we might add, that they likely think was well worth it.

New for 2015

The Macan is an all-new model.

title: 2015 Porsche Panamera
subTitle: The Porsche of luxury sedans.
promoTeaserSmall: The Porsche of luxury sedans.
promoTeaser: The Porsche of luxury sedans.
metaKeywords: 2015 Porsche Panamera; Porsche; sedan; hybrid; German
metaDescription: The Porsche of luxury sedans. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Four-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive sedan
Price range: $79,095–$201,495 (includes destination)
Trim levels: Panamera, 4, S, 4S, 4S Executive, S E-Hybrid, GTS, Turbo, Turbo Executive, Turbo S, Turbo S Executive
Engines: 3.6-liter V-6, 310 horsepower; twin-turbocharged 3.0-liter V-6, 420 horsepower; 3.0-liter V-6/electric hybrid, 416 horsepower; 4.8-liter V-8, 440 horsepower; twin-turbocharged 4.8-liter V-8, 520/570 horsepower
Transmissions: Seven-speed automatic, eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: Panamera: 18 mpg city/28 mpg highway; 4: 18/27 mpg; S/4S: 17/27 mpg; 4S Executive: 17/26 mpg; GTS: 16/24 mpg; S E-Hybrid: 25 combined/50 mpg-e combined; Turbo/Turbo Executive/Turbo S/Turbo S Executive: 15/24 mpg
Safety ratings: Not rated by either NHTSA or IIHS
Our favorite standard feature: Front and rear parking sensors
Notable standard features on this model: Bi-xenon headlights, power liftgate, heated front seats, dual-zone automatic climate control, cruise control, automatic stop/start
Notable options on this model: Rearview camera, adaptive cruise control, lane change assist
You might also be considering: BMW 7 Series, Jaguar XJ, Mercedes-Benz S-Class, Tesla Model S

As with the Cayenne, purists scoffed at the idea of a Porsche sedan, but it didn’t take long to turn them into believers. With the handling of a sports car and the practicality of a sedan, the Panamera has cemented its spot in the Porsche model range.

The Panamera lineup is extensive, with no fewer than eleven trim levels. There are rear- and all-wheel-drive models, a plug-in hybrid, and normally aspirated and turbocharged engines. Oh, and there are three different long-wheelbase versions, too. Power ranges from 310 horsepower in the base version to a grin-inducing 570 horsepower in the Turbo S. A seven-speed PDK automatic is the transmission of choice in every Panamera save the S E-Hybrid, which uses the eight-speed Tiptronic S automatic.

The cabin of the Panamera is sumptuous and bears a strong resemblance to that of the 911, at least in the front seats. One thing the Panamera doesn’t have, which can be found in other luxury sedans, is a central controller for the multimedia system. Consequently, the center console is a button-rich environment that can be confusing at first glance. The rear seats are extraordinarily comfortable and supportive, and legroom, especially in the long-wheelbase Executive models, is plentiful. The thick rear pillars hamper rearward visibility somewhat, but options like a rearview camera and blind spot monitoring mitigate that problem.

As with every model in the Porsche lineup, there are lots of performance and appearance options. Peruse the list carefully, because it’s easy to get carried away and send the price skyrocketing.

New for 2015

The fastest, most powerful Panamera to date, the Turbo S, is new for 2015.

pageElements.text: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/oQioo4nc04I" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Taking inspiration from my favorite dog commercial this year (it’s from Subaru, no surprise), I’ve thought long and hard about how each of my dogs would spend a Dream Weekend. As if their lives weren’t already about as dreamy as we can make it for them!

Robert Garcia de Padua, 7

Bob is a Grand Champion Chesapeake Bay retriever, permanently retired from his show dog career, mostly because he became way too interested in the handler in front of him in the ring. Waayyyyy too interested, if you know what I mean. Bob is a simple dog with a great big heart. He’s a classic water dog, the colder the better, who loves to hunt birds. I think this would give him most joy:
● Take him to a very cold river or pond and let him swim as long as he wants. It will be for a solid hour. He swims in circles, pounding the water with his paws making bubbles. Then he swims around and around biting them. When they’re gone, he periscopes up, looks around, goes under and looks, then starts again.

● He would like Ray’s bone, Stella’s squeaky toys, and Stella’s green alien. She already bit off all of the legs, so there’s nothing left (including the squeaker) to ruin. He doesn’t care. He wants it. He stole her orange squeaky pig and tore it to shreds.
● Let him keep that pound of frozen sausage he “found,” defrosted, and ate.
● Go to Iowa with Tim to hunt pheasants and ducks. Just Tim. Not me. Not Stella. Especially not Ray.
● Lose his virginity. Please.
● Give him another shot in the show ring. Bitches in heat there.
● Let him climb up on the couch just once, and watch TV with Jean. Make Ray stay on the floor.

Stella Mae Jennings, 14

Stella is a garage-bred Chessie (pure but only purty to us), with a dicey disposition that has mellowed with age. She has earned her place as house dog. Her list is simple, so there is no reason in her stubborn mind why we can’t make this happen:
● Unlimited time with her squeakies and green alien. Until they are finally demolished. Usually by Bob. ● Her favorite dog bed, located under a sunbeam.

● Lying in bed under the fan.
● Hunting pheasants in South Dakota + me - Bob and - Ray.
● Only dog in the house. Only dog ever.
● No other dogs or humans within fifty feet of Jean.

● Never again have to get in the Suburban.
● Stay home with Jean. Make Jean stay home.

Cecil Ray Hartwick, 5

He's a mix of mostly black Labrador and Bull Mastiff and a smattering of unbelievable breeds (Bedlington Terrier, Schipperke, Catahoula Leopard Dog) affectionately dubbed Ray the Stray by his uncle Mark in Louisiana after he was found in a ditch in Mississippi. We arbitrarily gave him Bob’s birthday, since he arrived without one. This is a dog that knows what he wants at all times. He made his own list:

● All-toy access: Stella’s squeakies, Bob’s bones.
● Anything that is in Bob’s mouth, including hunks of bark from the woodpile.

● All-lap access: while Tim is reading in the lounger, while Jean is on the couch watching TV.
● No humans ever sitting in his favorite chairs.
● Never ever having to see the vet again. Ever.
● Hunting pheasants in Iowa + Tim - Bob.

● Lying in a ditch full of water or tub full of water.
● Chasing deer. Rabbits. Raccoons. Porcupines (grrrrrrr). Bears. Et cetera...
● Let him out to pee just ONE TIME without putting him on the tie-out. Suckers.

images.caption: Bob scopes out lobby of Mercedes-Benz from front seat of an S-Class.
On East Coast tour following auspicious showing at Westminster Kennel Club show, Bob stops by Rolls-Royce to check out Phantom legroom.
Ray wants Bob's stick. A rare stalemate.
Stella wants a ride in Toyota 4Runner SR5. Who wouldn't?
Ray's leather couch, pillow, and afghan. Another lazy day at the cabin.
Rare photo of all three dogs sitting still: Stella, Bob, and Ray.
Ray after reading the Sunday funnies.
Ray and Stella coming from the lake. Bob still making bubbles.
Bob and log. Ray has already stolen the bark.
Jean and Ray, together on the couch watching a Detroit Tigers ball game.

title: Certified Pre-Owned Cars: 7 Steps to Success
subTitle: Interested in a Certified Pre-Owned used car? So are lots of people. How to be a smart CPO shopper.
promoTitle: Certified Pre-Owned Cars: 7 Steps to Success
promoTeaserSmall: Interested in a Certified Pre-Owned used car? So are lots of people. How to be a smart CPO shopper.
promoTeaser: Interested in a Certified Pre-Owned used car? So are lots of people. How to be a smart CPO shopper.
metaTitle: Certified Pre-Owned Cars: 7 Steps to Success
metaDescription: Interested in a Certified Pre-Owned used car? So are lots of people. How to be a smart CPO shopper.

pageElements.text: If you've shopped for a car in the past several years, you've surely heard about Certified Pre-Owned cars. Starting as a way to market higher-end used cars, the Certified Pre-Owned designation has now become commonplace at car dealerships. A Certified Pre-Owned (CPO) car is generally a car with a clean history, few past users, of relatively recent vintage, and with less than about 80,000 miles on the odometer. It undergoes an extensive pre-sale inspection, and problems are fixed by the dealer before it's offered for sale.
What's not to like? Of course, all of this means that your average CPO car is sold at a premium over a non-CPO used car, but for the peace of mind you get, it can be well worth the cost.
If you are interested in a used-car purchase, here are five things to know about CPO.

1. All CPO programs aren't alike.

Manufacturers run Certified Pre-Owned programs, but so do some dealers as well as organizations such as Enterprise car rental, the National Independent Automobile Dealers Association (NIADA), and others. You need to understand where the Certified Pre-Owned designation is coming from. The big advantage of seeking out a CPO used car, rather than any old car on the lot, is that the CPO car comes with a warranty. You want it to be the manufacturer’s own warranty, not the local dealer’s. Why? If the CPO program is through the manufacturer, not just the local dealership, any warranty repairs you do need can be performed anywhere around the country. That's a strong argument in favor of the automaker's program.

2. Used cars aren't just for those who can’t afford new anymore.

CPOs are increasingly popular among premium brands. CPO sales of Volvos were up 47 percent in the first half of 2015. Brands such as Mercedes-Benz, Jaguar, and Cadillac all have firmly established CPO programs, and even Porsche sold 1,206 certified pre-owned cars in April, its highest rate yet and up 18.8 percent compared to the preceding year. Earlier this summer, electric-sports-car maker Tesla started online sales of Certified Pre-Owned Model S cars that are starting to come back from lease programs. If you want a high-end car but don't want to pay a high-end price, a Certified Pre-Owned car might be the ticket for you.

3. The popularity of leasing means you’ll have lots of CPO choices.

With so many people leasing cars, dealers find themselves with an increasing quantity of reasonably “young” vehicles with one owner that are good candidates for a CPO sale. You could get a great deal on a low-mileage used car by taking advantage of that. Consider that CPO sales are up 12 percent through the first half of 2015, while new-car sales are up 4.5 percent. It’s no longer an unusual way to buy a car, and that’s good for the consumer.

4. The detailed inspection report is only one of several perks to look for.

A benefit of CPO programs is that the car you're looking at will come with an extensive inspection report (more than 150 points are checked out under most CPO programs), and you’ll get a Carfax (or similar) report on the vehicle’s history. Read them!

You can often finance a CPO purchase at or close to the same low interest rates you'd get on a new-car purchase. Other perks: the power to take a car back within a specified time limit if you're not happy with it, and sometimes, a free loaner vehicle if your CPO purchase comes in for repairs at the dealership. You might also want the roadside assistance that is usually offered, if you don’t already have AAA or another road service plan. So much better than trusting someone you met on Craigslist.

5. The warranty details and potential hidden costs need your close attention.

A Certified Pre-Owned car often comes with two kinds of warranties: the powertrain limited warranty that the car had as new, which is continued for the new owner; and a warranty on problems that come up elsewhere on the car, which may or may not cost extra. The "certified" in the Certified Pre-Owned title can mean different things in different programs.

For example, a CPO from Ford comes with a twelve-month, 12,000-mile comprehensive warranty on a long list of components—the kind that older cars might tend to need replaced, such as the alternator, ball joints, air conditioning compressor, and power door locks. All good news! However, there’s a $100 warranty deductible for each visit to the shop. For Toyota, the deductible on similar warranty coverage is $50; for Mercedes-Benz, it’s $0.

Dealerships and other CPO providers may also offer an extended warranty that you have to buy separately, which could be a substantial extra cost. Make sure you understand the terms, including the deductible, for repairs under the warranty, and whether any of the warranties are transferable should you sell the CPO car down the road.

title: How Does a CVT Work?
subTitle: Everything you need to know to feel comfortable with a continuously variable transmission.

contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text: Did you know that about thirteen percent of new cars come equipped with a continuously variable transmission? To many people—possibly including you—that technology is an enigma. If you’ve heard anything about the CVT, it's likely that your feelings about it have been affected by the harsh opinions of hard-core car enthusiasts and late adopters, who may dislike or just distrust this type of automatic transmission.

Who likes CVTs? Auto companies, for a start. CVTs are currently available in vehicles from Audi, Honda, Hyundai, Mitsubishi, Subaru, Suzuki, and Toyota. General Motors and Chrysler are customers for the CVT made by one of Nissan’s suppliers.
What is a transmission that has no gears doing in so many cars, and how does it affect you?

Here's What a CVT Is

In simplest terms, a CVT, which is coupled to the engine, is a steel or aluminum case enclosing two grooved pulley wheels. Each pulley turns on its own shaft, and a rugged belt runs between them. One pulley receives the engine’s output and distributes it to the second pulley, which sends driving force to the wheels.

Inside the car, the driver selects Drive or Reverse, but otherwise there’s no need for shifting. In a way, having a car with a CVT isn’t so different from walking up the handicapped access ramp instead of climbing the stairs.

A CVT is compact, lightweight, and inexpensive. Without the teeth of large gears meshing with smaller ones, as in a traditional automatic or manual transmission, the car’s occupants feel no shift shock as it moves along.

And Here's How It Works

“Instead of the engine’s internal operating speed going up and down as you progress through fixed ratios, you vary the transmission ratios,” said Alex Fedorak, spokesman for Mitsubishi, which has CVTs in several vehicles.

Variability enters the picture when electronic calculations call for hydraulic pressure to be applied to the pulleys, making one wider and the other narrower. How wide or narrow depends on the driver’s input. At low speed, the pulley receiving the engine’s output widens and the other pulley narrows. When the car is barreling down the road, the opposite occurs.

The belt, which is somewhat V-shaped, climbs or drops between the pulleys’ widened or narrowed sheaves. This creates an effect similar to the different ratios between fixed gears. 
 
Thanks to the CVTs mediation, the engine’s internal operating speed stays more constant. As the result, though, the car tends to moo like an unmilked cow rather than roaring like a bull. Some have also noted an odd floating feeling, as if the engine and wheels aren’t precisely engaged.

And Here's Why It's a Good Thing

But the advantage of the CVT—why manufacturers are pushing them in the marketplace—is found in superb fuel economy.
For example, the 2016 Honda Fit LX with standard 6-speed manual transmission achieves 29 city/37 highway mpg. With the available CVT, fuel economy jumps to 33 city/41 highway mpg.
Also, Fedorak observes, “You can control emissions much more efficiently.”

But Here's What People Have Against It

Meanwhile, complaints about the unusual feeling of driving a CVT-equipped car are being addressed.

On Oahu three years ago, I sampled the Subaru XV Crosstrek, then a new model and one of the first to offer a “stepped” CVT. It allows the driver to use steering-wheel-mounted paddle shifters to manually select and hold simulated, electronically controlled fixed ratios. The feature proved useful when kicking down to a passing gear on the highway. In addition, the test course included a muddy off-road section where churning along in a low gear was desirable.

A stepped CVT can have other benefits as well. To keep the driver involved and take away the impression of indefiniteness, the Toyota Corolla S has a CVT that includes seven simulated ratios and a sport mode for more aggressive action among them. The Subaru WRX has a CVT with eight steps.

Fedorak moved to Mitsubishi in 2014, where he renewed his familiarity with CVTs and realized how much progress has been made in delivering performance like that of a conventional automatic transmission. “If you pay close attention to your tachometer, you’ll notice the difference,” he said. “It wasn’t real evident to me right away. That’s how good the programming of them has become.”
What about the longevity questions that have sometimes surrounded CVTs?
Fedorak says any of today’s CVTs “uses a belt that’s made out of steel links. It’s much, much, much more durable. The belts are nothing to worry about. They’re very sturdy, very massive.”

So, Should You Get One on Your Next Car?

So if the CVT performs well enough, why even think about it? Because there may be different requirements for service, like having the transmission fluid changed rather frequently. For instance, Nissan Cube owners engage in lively online debates over the question of service intervals, with some advocating fluid changes—which cost around $250—every 30,000 miles.

Otherwise, as the CVT delivers an improving driving experience and won’t leave you stranded along the road, there’s no reason to think about this transmission any more than the one in your washing machine. Oh, yes, it has a transmission, too.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/VgP3jVkYpVQ" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

2016 Buick Enclave AWD-Premium

Type: Seven- or eight-passenger, mid-size front-wheel-drive luxury sport-utility vehicle
Trim levels: Convenience, Leather, Premium, Tuscan Edition
Base price: $49,515 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $53,630
Engine: 3.6-liter V-6, 288 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 16 mpg city/22 mpg highway (AWD); 17/24 mpg (FWD)
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars
Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: not yet rated (2015 Enclave was scored as Good in four categories)
You might also be considering (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Acura MDX ($43,785)
2015 BMW X5 ($54,895)
2016 Hyundai Santa Fe ($31,295)
Fun-O-Meter: 6.5

I ran this photo on the Jean Knows Cars Facebook page recently, showing the view by night through a 2016 Buick Enclave’s windshield. The comments were surprising and many. Was it the strip of turquoise mood lighting that wraps all the way around the dash? Perhaps. It’s a slightly edgy look for what continues to be a pretty traditionalist vehicle, despite all advertising to the contrary. And rightly so, because lots of buyers want that.

Do you know how many people—women and men—love, love, love their Buick Enclave? It’s a strong emotion for a big, old school sport-utility vehicle first introduced in 2008 that hasn’t changed since 2013. At least, not that you’d notice looking at it sitting curbside. Not unless you can spot the new nineteen-inch wheels, a standard feature on this Enclave Limited.

If you’ve been loving your old Enclave for too long, and you can’t stop now...that’s okay. Your lovely, comfy seven-passenger SUV hasn’t changed that much; the 2016 model is a lot like the 2013, only better. Joke all you want about Buicks being for the middle-aged and older buyer, but this is a car company that appreciates and honors continuity, respects tradition, and has figured out how to integrate the latest technology into a surprisingly timeless, classic package.

The Enclave is sold in three trim levels and in front- or all-wheel-drive versions, all with a 3.6-liter V-6 and a six-speed automatic transmission. As befits an SUV that’s squarely in the cushy category, there are lots of luxury and semi-luxury features on board. Even the base Convenience package (base price, $39,990 including destination charge) has a rearview camera, SiriusXM satellite radio, 4G LTE Wi-Fi, remote start, and a power liftgate as standard. However, it’s the only model of Enclave available only as front-wheel drive, not all-wheel drive. The midlevel Leather package ($44,585) adds eight-way power adjustable front seats with—you guessed it—leather trim, plus a heated, wood-trimmed steering wheel, nineteen-inch aluminum wheels, and a few of the best active safety features: rear park assist, side blind zone alert, and rear cross-traffic alert.

The top-end Limited package ($48,440), the model that we tested, adds forward collision alert, lane departure warning, heated and cooled front seats, a premium Bose sound system, and a set of 19-inch chrome-clad aluminum wheels (20-inch wheels are optional). Buick is also tarting up the SUV a little with the new-for-2016 Tuscan Edition, which has a bronze theme; the 20-inch chrome-clad wheels have bronze accents, and the traditional Buick “waterfall” grille is bronze.
Its voice recognition speaks like a human and can recognize my occasionally grating Michigan accent, a very special blend of nasal, flat-vowel, duck-quacking disharmony.

Now, speaking about that “latest technology” thing. Navigation systems are becoming as common as air conditioning, and they can be just as fiddly to get right. There’s nothing remotely fiddly about the Enclave’s excellent Intellilink system. I don’t use the word “perfect” too often, but in this 2016 Enclave, the nav system is perfect. It has voice recognition that speaks like a human and can recognize my occasionally grating Michigan accent, a very special blend of nasal, flat-vowel, duck-quacking disharmony. But it knows me. Speak the address in one sentence; the Enclave’s nav system will deal with it.

It also has in-car 4G LTE Wi-Fi, which is new for 2016 in the Enclave as it expands across the General Motors lineup. This is a controversial add-on in the Jean Knows Cars offices. Some of us love the idea of being able to stream movies and surf the Internet on a road trip—only while riding as a passenger, of course. Others feel that the monthly data charge you’ll incur after the first three months of ownership is not necessary as long as you’ve got a smartphone with a data plan. I tend to think that in-car wireless is something we’ll be taking for granted within a few years. Of course, in the Enclave, it is teamed with GM’s OnStar services, which is all the better.

Having said all that, the tiny carryover infotainment screen is a disappointment in an age when customers seem to want something as big as an iPad. This one is 6.5 inches, even on the optional top-end infotainment package with navigation ($1,395) and rear-seat entertainment ($2,035), which has dual DVD-player screens in the second row that are even bigger, at seven inches. Why do the eight-year-olds in the second row get better screens than their parents in the front? I ask. Spoken like a true childless DINK (double income, no kids).

As for the kids in the back, one key to the Enclave’s popularity is that you can get it in seven-passenger or eight-passenger versions, and the second row of seats have a handle (Buick calls it SmartSlide) that lets you fold and slide the seats, which makes it easier for people to get into the third row. That’s the kind of versatility that explains why so many people who might have bought a minivan in the past are going for the Buick Enclave instead.

There’s no doubt that you have many, many choices when it comes to an SUV this size: almost two dozen of them, in fact. If you’re trying to figure out why a Buick should make it to your short list, think about this. For two years in a row, Buick has been number one in the J.D. Power Customer Service Index among twenty mass-market brands. The Enclave doesn’t have the cachet of a Mercedes-Benz GL-Class or the cult following that models from Honda (Pilot) and Hyundai (Santa Fe) can call on, but it offers an exquisitely cossetting magic-carpet ride. So, if tradition and truly fabulous comfort appeal to you, this is one SUV you should not overlook.

title: 6 Things to Never Ever Do in a Car
subTitle: You don't do any of these things. Right?
promoTitle: 6 Things to Never Ever Do in a Car
promoTeaserSmall: You don't do any of these things. Right?
promoTeaser: You don't do any of these things. Right?
keywords: 6 Things to Never Ever Do in a Car
metaTitle: 6 Things to Never Ever Do in a Car - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: You don't do any of these things in the car, do you?

pageElements.text: Sick of being warned about distracted driving? Not to worry—although we agree that you should put down the cheeseburger and the cell phone and watch the road whenever you’re driving. This is not one of those stories. This time, we’re warning you about the everyday habits you and your passengers have probably picked up, probably without considering how dangerous they are.

Let’s face it: an automobile is a giant, heavyweight projectile, and you’re sitting inside it, going 70 mph. Take a few minutes and consider these six rules that you should immediately adopt for yourself and your passengers.

1. No legs up on the dashboard.

Airbags and seatbelts are designed to save you, but you compromise that with something as mundane as improper and reclined seating positions. It’s tempting, especially on a long drive, for the front-seat passenger to kick off his or her shoes and stretch the legs across the dash. It’s also dangerous. The airbag that’s under the dashboard is designed to deploy extremely quickly —in 1/20 of a second, at speeds up to 200 mph, according to the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. When it does, it’s designed to protect a passenger sitting in the upright position with a seatbelt on. If that bag deploys in an accident and encounters your legs, it is likely to push them back into your body, hard. If you’ve seen the cautionary tale of Canadian college student Bethany Benson (http://www.caa.ca/feet-on-the-dash/), whose life and health were seriously transformed when that happened to her, you will keep your feet on the floor where they belong.

2. No seatbelt tucked under the arm or behind the back.

Short women and teenagers are frequently guilty of this. Parents are guilty of letting the teenagers get away with it. The National Institutes of Health published a study linking this practice to deaths from “lacerations of the liver, spleen, intestines, mesentery, diaphragm, and aorta, and spine injury” in accidents. The seatbelt is designed to lock in place in an accident, and you don’t want that sudden “grab” to hit you in the internal organs. There’s even a medical condition called “seatbelt syndrome” to describe the damage that can happen if your seatbelt is not strapped across your body in the correct position.

So keep the seatbelt diagonally across the center of your chest, away from your neck, with the lap belt low on the hips and below the stomach. If the fit’s not right, adjust the seat instead. 
http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3612840

3. Don’t sit too close to the airbag.

If you’re driving, sit at least 10 inches away from the steering wheel, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) recommends. How to get there? If you have a tilting and telescoping steering wheel, move it back and tilt it down. Slide your seat back, recline the seatback. While we’re at it, take a few minutes to think about how you are positioned in the driver’s seat. AAA recommends you position yourself so that your line of sight is three inches above the steering wheel for best visibility. http://seniordriving.aaa.com/improve-your-driving-skills/prepare-drive/your-bodys-fit-vehicle

image.altText: 04 Not Buckled Credit Flickr Lars Plougmann

pageElements.text:
4. No riding in the back seat unbelted—and no allowing others to do that.

CBS “60 Minutes” correspondent Bob Simon was killed this way in February, riding in the back of a Lincoln Town Car taxi in Manhattan. It may be somewhat safer to ride in the back seat, but you still need to be strapped in so the airbags, which increasingly provide full coverage to back-seat passengers, can do their job. It’s tempting to let your back-seat riders wander around in back, or even unstrap and lie down across the back seat. Don’t let them. Ever. credit: flickr/Lars Plougmann

5. No loose objects rolling around on the floor or seats.

The trunk or rear storage compartment of your vehicle is there to carry things. Take the extra 30 seconds to put the packages you haven’t mailed yet, the umbrellas and used coffee cups into the back. They don’t look too scary now, but in a crash….check out this German video for a mental picture you won't forget anytime soon.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Q1jj4NAzfHQ" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

6. No smoking a cigarette or pipe while you drive.

Well, don’t do that in the first place, but if the airbag deploys while you’re lighting up, you’ll be wearing it. It’s also a form of distracted driving, since the fiddling with lighters, ashes, and disposal all take attention of the road. And aside from the damage you could do to yourself if you drop the lit smoke in an accident, secondhand smoke is a proven risk to everybody who rides in the car with you. Don’t do it.

New for 2016: 1 mpg more fuel efficient, Automatic Emergency Braking

In the ever-growing crossover game, Hyundai’s Tucson remains a reliable option. With 102.2 cubic feet of passenger volume and 31 cubic feet of cargo space, it offers generous space in a surprisingly neat and compact package. There are two engines and transmissions available: six-speed or seven-speed automatic hooked up to either a 2.0-liter four-cylinder or a 1.6-liter four-cylinder engine. You might not take a second look at the standard features, but options like all-wheel drive and a tech package move this model up a few notches on the crossover totem pole. The Popular Equipment package on the SE offers a power driver's seat with lumbar support, LED daytime running lights, roof side rails, and automatic power windows. The Ultimate package amps it up a bit with pedestrian detection, rear parking sensors, and a panoramic sunroof. The 2016 Tucson embodies many of the qualities customers have come to expect from Hyundai: affordability, quality, practicality.

You might also be considering: Chevrolet Equinox, Dodge Journey, Kia Sorento

The Hyundai Santa Fe brings to the table everything you want from a crossover: versatility, space, and style. The new hands-free power liftgate (on the Limited model) will be a deal clincher for those who tend to cart stuff in back (besides kids and other passengers, of course). The three-row configuration can accommodate five, six, or seven passengers, depending on the rear seating you choose. Front- and all-wheel-drive are both available, and under the hood is a surprisingly powerful engine. The 3.3-liter V-6 produces 290 horsepower, a boon for those who tow. The standard features are fairly impressive, including a driver’s blind spot mirror, heated exterior mirrors, and LED headlight accents. The Limited model adds leather seating surfaces, a rearview camera, LED brake lights, and—a real reason to look at a new vehicles these days—the active safety features of blind spot detection with rear cross-traffic alert and lane change assist.
New for 2016: Hands-free power liftgate added on Limited models; GLS trim renamed SE; Java Espresso replaces Frosted Mocha for exterior paint color.

You might also be considering: Kia K900, Lexus LS, Mercedes-Benz S-Class

You might just do a double take when you lay eyes on the new Hyundai Equus. You will ask:  What is that sleek, opulent car in front of me? Is it a Mercedes? A BMW? Don't feel bad if you're surprised, at first, that it's a Hyundai, but know that you won't underestimate this automaker again. The Equus is Hyundai’s luxury sedan, and it boasts many of the features you would expect from a high-end sedan – like power seats, wood accents, sunroof – without the close-to-six-figure price tag. It is powered by a 5.0-liter V-8 that produces 429 horsepower, and the engine hooks up to an eight-speed automatic transmission. Although the standard features make up a long enough list to satisfy the queen of England, there is an optional Ultimate package, too. It includes cooled rear seats, forward-view cornering camera, and head-up display. If you’re looking for luxury, performance, and quality and can do without the flashy names or prices, the Equus offers indulgence for the practical driver.
New for 2016: Hands-free Smart Trunk

A populist choice since its 2011 debut, in 2016 the Hyundai Elantra continues to bring the value and style customers have come to expect from this model. With a surprisingly elegant frame and smooth lines, the Elantra appeals to entry-level buyers but also to value-oriented buyers across the socioeconomic spectrum. Standard features like cruise control, a trip computer, and Hill Start Assist Control further add value and quality, while options like a sunroof and heated exterior mirrors make it even more comfortable. There are two engine choices, a 1.8-liter four-cylinder or a 2.0-liter four-cylinder, teamed with a six-speed manual (an increasingly difficult choice to find these days) or a six-speed automatic transmission. The Value Edition offers $1,000 in savings without doing away with fan-favorite features including leather steering wheel and shift knob, heated front seats, and a power tilting and sliding sunroof. The Sport model offers a sport-tuned suspension, aluminum pedals, heated front seats, a black chrome grille, and a special set of seventeen-inch alloy wheels. People come for the Elantra’s practicality and stay for the style and comfort.
New for 2016: Value Edition (offers $1,000 in savings).

title: Pupsaver Car Seat for Dogs
subTitle: Is this soft seat the answer to the problem of how to drive safely with dogs? We put it to the test.
promoTeaserSmall: Is this soft seat the answer to the problem of how to drive safely with dogs? We put it to the test.
promoTeaser: Is this soft seat the answer to the problem of how to drive safely with dogs? We put it to the test.
metaTitle: Pupsaver Car Seat for Dogs - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Is this soft seat the answer to the problem of how to drive safely with dogs? We put it to the test.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text:
Pupsaver
$139.95



My fourteen-pound Jack Russell terrier, Bizee, raised her paw to be the tester of this rear-facing car seat for small dogs from Pupsaver. She has traveled many miles inside of her less-than-luxurious dog cage. So to be able to ride like her human companions was seen as a win-win by both of us. Yes, I am just guessing how she felt about this experiment.
The company refers to it as a safety seat for small dogs, created to restrain your dog in case of accidents or sudden stops.

When I spotted the Pupsaver on an Internet search, billed as safe, comfy, and easy to install, I was excited to try it out to see if it fit our needs. The Pupsaver is installed in the front passenger seat, which you first move all the way back. It's attached using the car's seatbelt, and there's a short tether inside the Pupsaver seat that attaches to the dog's collar or harness. The company refers to it as a safety seat for small dogs, created to restrain your dog in case of accidents or sudden stops. The website describes it as a giant catcher’s mitt, which is a perfect description. In case of an accident, the mitt catches the dog, and the car’s seatbelt system holds the seat in place. It sounded ingenious to me. I put my kid in a car seat; it makes sense for the dog, too.

I am shocked and appalled when I see dogs with full run of a vehicle on a highway or even around town. Small dog owners seem especially guilty, with petite pups hopping from row to row and even traveling on the driver’s lap. I understand the urge to give your pup freedom to roam or snuggle next to you while running your errands or heading out on the highway for a long trip. But there is no wiggle room on this issue if you love your dog. Your pup must be restrained for even the shortest trip.

Our dogs have always traveled in their crates, or houses as we call them. But I am on a quest to be able to see Bizee as we travel. I tried a booster. She could see out the window, and I could see her, but I worried about its crashworthiness—especially in the front seat. The harnesses I have tried didn’t fit her properly, and she was uncomfortable. Her house is boxy and takes up a lot of space, and honestly I feel like I am putting her in solitary confinement.

Is This Thing Safe?

I learned that the Pupsaver had actually been crash tested for a twenty-five-pound dog at 30 mph (by a lab that also serves the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, according to Pupsaver). That convinced me to give the Pupsaver a test drive.


)

The Road Test

We got off to a rocky start with the Pupsaver. When we first tried to install the seat, it taco’d right over Bizee as you see in this photo. All the pictures showed the front standing up tall, but in practice the Pupsaver was clamshelling over her. I knew this wasn’t right, so we reread the directions, which suggested you hang up the Pupsaver for two weeks and it would right itself. That did not help the situation, so we emailed for further instructions. Their suggestion was to flip it inside out for forty-eight hours and try again. Voilà, it worked.

Since the seat is designed to hold dogs that weigh less than thirty pounds, only those canines who shop in the petite department can ride. It can be used in both the front and rear seats. I found it especially nice to be able to look over and see Bizee all snuggly in the front passenger's seat. But sometimes I must bring my husband along, and he prefers the front, so we tested the rear placement as well. Because of the shape of the Pupsaver, when Bizee is in the rear, I can't see her. I guess you could buy one of those mirrors that parents use to see their babies in rear-facing car seats. When my teenage daughter was sitting next to her in the middle row, it was nice for her to be able to interact with Bizee as we drove down the road.

For anyone who travels with their dog every day, it would be ideal to just leave the Pupsaver in place. I personally often have passengers in the front seat, so I found it a bit cumbersome to keep moving the Pupsaver around. It is easier to stash than a boxy crate. However, we also bring her crate so if we leave her in the car for any amount of time. Why? you ask. Because we are helicopter dog parents, and we worry that she could somehow hang herself. So, for us it adds one more item to our packing list.
There is no wiggle room on this issue if you love your dog. Your pup must be restrained for even the shortest trip.

The Verdict

If dogs could talk, I believe Bizee would give the Pupsaver high marks for softness and the ability to see her people. She would take away points for not being able to see out the window or snuggle. But I must use my head and not my heart when it comes to pet safety in the car, and that means she must be restrained at all times. The Pupsaver is a good weapon in the safety arsenal. It's great for long trips. We even brought it in to the cottage we rented, and she used it as a puppy couch. At $139.95, it is a bit pricey, but it will keep your pooch safe.

And, honestly, would you let your baby crawl around in the car? No, you'd ensure your baby was strapped into the car seat when you're sailing down the highway. The same is true for pets. Restrain your pup in the car. End of discussion.

More about Dogs in the Car!

Buying a Car for Your Dog

7 Best New-Car Features for the Dog Owner

Keeping Your Dog Safe in the Car

The Hyundai Veloster already delivered hard and edgy style, but the 2016 Rally Edition takes it to the next level. A more performance-focused suspension, lightweight wheels, and carbon-fiber-look aero accents give the Rally Edition a sporty feel. All of the planned 1,200 units of this model will come in Matte Blue paint.  There are three choices of transmission: six-speed manual or six-speed and seven-speed dual-clutch automatic. Standard features include heated outside mirrors, a rearview camera, and cruise control. Options include a seven-inch navigation system, push-button start, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, and a panoramic sunroof. If you want a popularly priced vehicle that veers a bit off the beaten path, put this on your list.
