title: 7 Apps to Improve Life in the Car
subTitle: Whether you’re an Android or iOS kind of person, if you own a vehicle, you need at least one of these.
promoTitle: 7 Apps to Improve Life in the Car
promoTeaserSmall: Whether you’re an Android or iOS kind of person, if you own a vehicle, you need at least one of these.
promoTeaser: Whether you’re an Android or iOS kind of person, if you own a vehicle, you need at least one of these.
keywords: 7 Apps to Improve Life in the Car
metaTitle: 7 Apps to Improve Life in the Car - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Whether you’re an Android or iOS kind of person, if you own a vehicle, you need at least one of these.

pageElements.text:
1. Milewiz

$4.99 per month
This is a FitBit for your car; using this, you can effortlessly let your phone track how many miles you’ve driven.

Pro: If you are a business person and need to keep track of the miles you’ve driven, this app is your new best friend. When driving your personal car for professional business, you can receive up to 57.5 cents per mile in tax deductions. And don’t worry about filing away a paper log or tearing apart your house looking for said paper log in the event of a tax audit. Milewiz’s records are totally electronic, so even five years down the road, you will have access to an accurate report of your mileage.

For those receiving reimbursements or driving a company car, Milewiz will simplify the process of tracking your expenses. The app logs the miles you’ve driven and provides a template for you to input other costs like tolls, parking, and gas. Finally, it throws together all the trip information under a heading of your choice with tags that include where you went and whom you saw. Can you say comprehensive?

Con: The question you need to ask yourself: Is it worth it? Milewiz costs $4.99 per month or $49.99 per year. Even though the first twenty drives each month are free, $50 can be a steep price for someone who only occasionally needs to track miles. If your business commutes are relatively short and regular in length, you can probably log your miles the old-fashioned way.

Available for: iOS 7.1 or later
iOS

2. Autosist

Free
This is an all-in-one app for keeping records on your vehicle(s).

Pro: Type A people, rejoice! This app allows you to electronically file away all of your automotive receipts, documents, and logistical information. Last week’s gas receipts, your registration, and your tires’ sizes are all at the tip of your fingers. Glove boxes have the tendency to become black holes for important paperwork, but Autosist will help you find exactly what you need at a moment’s notice.

If you have a hard time remembering when your car last had an oil change or when you last visited the dealership, fear not. Any evidence of these services such as receipts and other paperwork can be filed away and found later. Best of all, Autosist is free.

Con: The issue with Autosist is the same problem all digital filing services have. If the app goes down or becomes obsolete, what happens to your information? How will you get to it? You simply do not have the same type of access to electronic documents as you do to hard copies. So if you download this app, maybe keep the old shoe box of paperwork as a backup.
Available for: iOS 6.0 or later; Android 3.0 and up

iOS
Android

3. DashCommand

$9.99
For the true tech geek (or those who aspire to be), this app lets you create a custom menu of information about your car in real time, everything from diagnostics to average fuel economy.

Pro: If you take care of your own car maintenance or if you just want to know a bit more about what’s going on under the hood of your car, say hello to DashCommand. This app gives you more detailed information about your engine, like range, average fuel economy, and torque. The data appear on an intuitive easy-to-read interface, and anyone from a professional racing driver to a recently licensed sixteen-year-old will be able to understand the infographics. It costs $9.99, which is not bad for such a helpful tool.
Con: You should buy a mount for your phone if you plan on using this app while driving. Even so, it could become a source of distracted driving.
Available for: iOS 5.1.1 or later; Android 2.1 and up; Windows 95 through Windows 8

iOS
Android
Windows

4. Waze

Free
This is a crowdsourcing app that lets you find out from other drivers about traffic and problems along your route.

Pro: The map app on the iPhone uses a red line to indicate traffic on your route, but you have no idea whether that means a mile of slow-moving cars, a closed exit, or an eight-car pileup. The Waze app gives you traffic and road information in real time that is provided by other users like yourself. This will help you decide if you should take the freeway or hop off onto the side streets. Additionally, this app can give you valuable information such as telling you if cops are ahead and indicating where you can find cheap gas. Waze is free.

Con: Receiving real-time updates from fellow drivers can be more than a bit distracting when you are on the road. Also, what is to stop you from going 90 mph when you know the nearest cop is fifteen miles away? Keep in mind that the “crowd” doesn’t know everything at all times.
Available for: iOS 6.0 or later; Android varies by device; Windows 10

iOS
Android
Windows

5. Carrr Matey

Free
This pirate-themed car app makes finding where you parked your car smooth sailing.

Pro: If the mere thought of searching for your car causes a groan to rise in your throat, get ready to turn that frown upside down. Carrr Matey is a no-cost lighthearted app that pulls you out of the rough waters of confusion and drudgery. You are the captain; your car is the ship; and a compass leads you back to your parking spot. This app also lets you set a parking timer, use a map, share location with friends, and keep a travel log. Aside from the unbelievable practicality, Carrr Matey provides some much-needed fun.
Con: If you want your app to get to the parking spot without kidding around, you won’t see the fun in this.
Available for: iOS 5.0 or later; Android 1.5 and up

iOS
Android

6. CamOnRoad

Free
This app does what people in Russia do: record what happens around the car while driving. This is a dash cam that works through your smartphone, which sits in a dash-mounted phone holder.

Pro: You’ve probably heard that the use of dash cams in Russia is prevalent due to the preponderance of hit-and-run accidents. It’s useful to have video of what really happened to document accidents for insurance claims. That could be useful in the United States, too, but Americans will largely use them for navigation and fun. CamOnRoad is a free dash cam application that transforms your smartphone into a DVR with GPS navigation features. In other words, no need to mount a video camera in the car. It makes following navigation instructions much easier and allows you to travel more safely. Plus, it is just plain cool.

Con: Using your phone constantly for an extended period of time will obviously drain its battery, so you will have to buy a mount that charges your phone for you, or your car will have to have charging capabilities. The temptation to get distracted while fiddling with the dash cam or looking at the screen will be great.
Available for: iOS 7.0 or later; Android varies by device

iOS
Android

7. iOnRoad

$4.99
This app will turn your smartphone camera into another set of watchful eyes on the road.

Pro: iOnRoad uses your phone’s camera to detect vehicles in front of you and other surrounding danger, and it warns you when you get too close or veer off the road. If you have ever longed for a personal driving assistant, now you can have one for $4.99. The app also scans speed signs, locates your car once you’ve parked, and records your drives. From avoiding a collision to saving yourself from a speeding ticket, iOnRoad will help you in more ways than one.

Con: Again, you need to buy a separate mount for your smartphone if you want to use this app. iOnRoad is only $4.99, though, so shelling out some extra money for the mount might be worth it. Also, you should never fully rely on your car or phone’s technology to keep you safe. You still need to pay attention to the surrounding environment.
Available for:  iOS 8.0 or later; Android 2.2 and up

iOS
Android

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

Transmission: Nine-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 19 mpg city/26 mpg highway (AWD); 20/27 mpg (FWD)
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick Plus

Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2015 Chevrolet Traverse ($31,870)
2016 Ford Explorer ($31,646)
2015 Nissan Pathfinder ($30,395)
2015 Toyota Highlander ($31,045)

Fun-O-Meter: 6.5

Another SUV? Yes, another SUV! But this big three-row SUV is from Honda, and for a lot of buyers, that makes all the difference. The Pilot has been on the market since 2003, selling in the comfortable six figures every year, satisfying the kinds of customers who love the Accord and CR-V but need to carry seven (or even eight) people and similar quantities of stuff.
Now, for 2016, the Pilot has been completely redesigned—both outside and in—and is more than prepared to do battle against its numerous strong competitors, chief among them the Ford Explorer.

The Pilot is available in five trim levels, from the affordable LX (which starts at $30,875) to the luxuriously over-the-top Elite ($47,300; all prices include destination charge). In between are the EX ($33,310), the EX-L ($36,785), and the Touring ($41,900). Both front- and all-wheel-drive models are available, although the Touring is only available with all-wheel drive.

All Pilot models have a new 3.5-liter V-6 engine that offers 30 more horsepower, at 280 hp, over the 2015 model. A six-speed automatic transmission (up from five speeds last year) is standard on the LX, EX, and EX-L, while the Touring (the model I drove) and Elite get a nine-speed automatic transmission with paddle shifters. Dreamy.
A full suite of advanced safety technologies, which Honda calls Honda Sensing, gives you the camera and radar sensors that drivers will soon wonder how they lived without.
The Pilot has a windshield-mounted camera and wave radar on the grille to help spot potential collisions—with vehicles or even pedestrians—before they happen.

As on all Hondas, a multi-angle rearview camera is standard on all models. The Honda Sensing system is optional on the EX and EX-L, and standard on Touring and Elite models. On the tech list are collision mitigation braking, road departure mitigation, forward collision and lane departure warning systems, plus lane keeping assist and adaptive cruise control. The Pilot has a windshield-mounted camera and wave radar on the grille to help spot potential collisions—with vehicles or even pedestrians—before they happen. This helps explain why the Pilot was given a prestigious Top Safety Pick Plus designation from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.

What, you ask, is “road departure mitigation,” and why do you want it? This feature alerts and helps to assist the driver if the system determines a possibility of your vehicle unintentionally crossing over lane markings at speeds between 45 and 90 mph. A message will appear in the display panel, followed by steering wheel vibrations. If you’re not clued in by that point, braking may be applied automatically if the lane lines are solid and continuous.

This may not be your cup of tea, so how about the choice of four driving modes—Normal, Snow, Mud, or Sand—for the all-wheel-drive Pilot? All-wheel drive does not turn the Pilot into a Jeep, but does give you a leg up in slippery conditions via a drive mode selector button just below the transmission gear selectors. (Even the front-wheel-drive Pilot has the Snow setting.) A little extra amusement is the animated snow, mud, and sand swirling around the wheels of the Pilot icon on the dash. This is Intelligent Traction Management, Honda style.

The Elite model justifies the $4,800 more it costs over last year’s top model, the Touring, by adding several things that are firsts on a Honda: twenty-inch wheels, ventilated front seats, heated second-row seats, a heated steering wheel—my favorite luxury item in the winter—and a panoramic glass sunroof. It also has second-row captain’s chairs, cutting maximum passenger capacity to seven from eight.

Honda’s infotainment system, HondaLink, is as always straightforward, intuitive, and clean-looking. On the Pilot LX, HondaLink has a teeny five-inch LCD screen, but all other models get an eight-inch touchscreen, so much better in every way.
Navigation is optional on the EX-L and standard on the Touring and Elite.

As I said before, the interior is completely updated, but beyond its styling, what really makes this model say “2016” is its controls. The rear entertainment system (standard on Touring and Elite, optional on EX-L) is Blu-Ray. The Pilot has push-button start. Coolest of all is the transmission gear selector, a sort of video game in which you operate a different-looking and different-feeling square for each gear.

Fun was clearly not the basic demand of the Pilot’s engineering team, or the steering  and braking would have a crisper response. But the quality of the ride was impeccable, and the overall feeling of quality and specialness within make the Pilot a real threat in this category.

Honda has a lot of die-hard fans, and one reason is this company’s ability to meet the real needs of real people in its own inimitably cheerful, accessible way. Further proof of that came when I opened the power liftgate on the Pilot Touring to discover an enormous 82-quart cooler fits back there with both back rows occupied with happy campers. Party time!

2016 Honda Pilot: view from the back.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive hybrid hatchback
Estimated price: Starting around $25,000
On-sale date: Early 2016
Trim levels: Prius, Prius Eco
Estimated fuel economy: 56 mpg city/53 mpg highway
Safety features: Toyota Safety Sense package (pre-collision alert with pedestrian detection, lane departure alert with steering assist, full-speed dynamic radar cruise control, automatic high beams)
Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Chevrolet Volt ($33,995)
2016 Ford C-Max Hybrid ($25,045)
2016 Honda Civic Hybrid ($25,555)
Fun-O-Meter: We will see...

LAS VEGAS—If you want something to be seen as important, you have to make it look important. In these crazy, crazy days of cheap gas and sport-utility vehicle lust, hybrid sales have been in freefall. Toyota needed to pull out the stops to make the unveiling of the fourth-generation Prius important.

How about Vegas! How about the roof of concert venue The Linq! How about Australian alt-rockers Atlas Genius to rev up the crowd!! Let's lower it from the sky by cables and light up the night with a wild light show and laser Toyota logos on every building surrounding The Linq!
And how about we make the new Prius look really, really different?

Toyota proudly states that it has sold eight million hybrid vehicles (3.5 million of them Priuses) since it all started, back in the mid-1990s. Just by driving them, Toyota owners have 5.8 billion gallons of gasoline and avoided emitting 58 million tons of CO2 emissions.
Nothing sexier than CO2 numbers, I always say. And as for “sexy,” there’s no doubt the Prius isn’t and never has been.

Toyota is aiming to change all that with the new look and feel of the Prius, but clearly it doesn’t want or need to alienate the loyal Prius owners who have made this model a mainstay on the roads of college towns and trendy urban neighborhoods. So you’d expect it to come out not looking all that different from the somewhat awkward shape it has had since the first one came out in 1997.

Hahaha. Just kidding. It looks outrageously different—especially in the rear, which is polarizing to the nth degree. My impromptu Las Vegas rooftop poll divided opinion along gender lines: women kinda liked it, men kinda hated it. But they were journalists, bloggers, and car dealers, so never mind that. The real test will be how the radical additions to its basic wedge shape will hold up in the light of day, out on the road where it belongs.

Overall, the new Prius ticks off several of the traditional points of a pleasing design proportion—it’s longer, lower, and wider. Toyota describes its stylized side profile as “evoking an athletic shape” and “inspired by a runner in the starting blocks.” This is very close to Mazda’s description of Kodo design. Hmmm. The front has a whole lotta lights going on, a big stack on each front corner. If you stand back and take in the entire front, the overall look isn’t all that radical, but definitely fresher and more noticeable.
If you stand back and take in the entire front, the overall look isn’t all that radical, but definitely fresher and more noticeable.

The rear has even more going on, taking Cadillac’s vertical light direction further by wrapping the corners of a vestigial rear spoiler in light that arcs down so low, it almost meets the road. It begs to be photographed up close.

The last Prius I drove was Earth Day 2015. I didn’t like that it looked every one of its drab seven years. I described the gray interior as unrelenting mouse fur. The seats were uncomfortable in the extreme, and the instrument panel was centered over the center console instead of in front of the driver.

The new Prius handles most of the complaints neatly. The new interior is modern, although the shiny white plastic center console gave me pause. The seats felt great, but there it was—the center-mounted instrument panel. There’s no reason to believe any driver should get comfortable looking away from the road to read the instruments.

Which brings us to the great advances made in safety features these days, one of the best reasons to buy a new car. The 2016 Prius will have its fair share, with Toyota’s new Safety Sense active safety features on board: a pre-collision system with pedestrian detection, lane departure alert with steering assist, full-speed dynamic radar cruise control, and automatic high beams. You’ll be seeing Safety Sense across most of the Toyota lineup by the end of next year.

The proof of success will be out on the road, where the last Prius was pretty quick and delivered exceptional fuel economy, but was ungainly and uncomfortable. Fuel economy improvement is in the bag, thanks to lighter hybrid system components, better batteries, and an internal combustion engine claiming ground-breaking thermal efficiency.

Numbers aren’t being announced quite yet, although Toyota says it expects class-leading fuel economy with a 10 percent improvement over the 2015 Prius, which gets 51 mpg in the city and 48 mpg on the highway. So that would be about 55 mpg combined, better than anything that isn’t sold with a plug. Right behind this model, there will be an even more efficient Eco model.
A stiffer body and a new, more sophisticated double-wishbone rear suspension leads one to believe that the driving experience will also improve.
The Fun-O-Meter rating remains on hold until we get behind the wheel.

images.caption: 2016 Toyota Prius at its Las Vegas debut.

title: 2016 Lexus RX
subTitle: Some updates, but the most noticeable addition? The standout styling.
promoTeaserSmall: Some updates, but the most noticeable addition? The standout styling.
promoTeaser: Some updates, but the most noticeable addition? The standout styling.
metaDescription: Some updates, but the most noticeable addition? The standout styling.

pageElements.text:
2016 Lexus RX350 F Sport

Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive luxury crossover
Models: RX350, RX350 F Sport, RX450h (hybrid), RX450h F Sport
On-sale date: December 2015
Base price (estimated): $42,500
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 295 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic with paddle shifters
Fuel economy 20 mpg city/28 mpg highway (front-wheel drive); 19/26 mpg (all-wheel drive)
My favorite standard feature: Ten-way power front seats
Option I can’t live without: Touch-free rear liftgate
Notable standard features on base model: LED headlamps; illuminated door handles, heated side mirrors with turn signal repeaters; power rear hatch; leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift lever; ten-way power front seats; reclinable rear seats; four twelve-volt outlets; two USB ports; dual zone auto climate control; foot lights; power tilting and telescoping steering column; Bluetooth; nine-speaker audio system
You might also be considering: Audi Q5, BMW X3, Land Rover Discovery, Lincoln MKX, Mercedes-Benz GLC-Class

Lexus pretty much invented the crossover class—sport-utility vehicle styling on a front-wheel-drive passenger-car platform—back in 1998, when the first RX came out. This crossover has set the pace for Toyota’s luxury division through each successive generation, accounting for a substantial proportion of Lexus sales. In 2014, this came to 34.5 percent of the brand’s sales—pretty impressive in a nine-vehicle Lexus lineup.
The RX series has never been a favorite of car-enthusiast reviewers, who have found it a little ho-hum. But it has scored well with the critics who matter most: those who vote with their checkbooks.
The traits that have propelled the RX to sales of 100,000-plus every year since launch are typical Lexus: first-rate assembly, posh interiors, smooth ride, respectable power, and quiet operation.

Those are pretty good creds, and pretty much what we’ve come to expect, given the Lexus pursuit of perfection. But if you think about it, you’ll see that something’s missing from that list of virtues. As good as it has been, the RX has never turned heads out there in the traffic stream.
So here’s generation four, and we think the Lexus stylists have resolved the anonymity issue. There’s far more character.

So here’s generation four, and we think the Lexus stylists have resolved the anonymity issue. There’s far more character in the vehicle sides, with lots of sculpting, a swoopy roofline, hunky haunches, and topping it off a great big Lexus spindle grille adorning the front, distinctly bigger than the previous generation. Whatever one may think about this Lexus cosmetic trademark—opinion seems to be either love or hate, with no middle ground—combined with the sculpted sheetmetal it helps to give the new RX much more curbside presence.

There’s more to this renewal than styling, of course. The RX has grown substantially—expanded 4.7 inches to 192.5 inches in length, on a wheelbase stretched 1.9 inches to 109.8 inches. As you’d expect, this translates as more interior volume for passengers and cargo. In the rear seat, which the design team has also enhanced by lowering the floor slightly, the seating positions are even more comfortable.

Other updates include selective stiffening of the unit body; as in all crossover SUVs, the frame and body shell are integrated. Although Lexus didn't give specifics, we encountered no chassis quivers in a day of driving the various RX models—RX350, RX450 Hybrid, and the F Sport versions of both. Lexus also invested in reducing interior noise levels, which is interesting, since the RX was already one of the more serene vehicles in this class. In any case, more than ever the RX is exemplary in terms of NVH (noise, vibration, and harshness).

A nifty addition to the new body shell is a power liftgate with an optional remote feature. Touch the Lexus logo at the rear, and the hatch pops open.

Like the current RX, the interior of the fourth generation is handsomely furnished, with several different trim combinations and a respectable list of standard features. There's a pair of audio options, a twelve-speaker Pioneer system and an even more sublime fifteen-speaker setup from Mark Levinson. Prominent among the options is a 12.3-inch color display that resides atop the center dashboard. (The regular infotainment screen is eight inches.)

The standard RX engine continues to be a 3.5-liter V-6, but Lexus characterizes it as all new. That’s certainly true of the cylinder heads, which now accommodate direct fuel injection, yielding greater efficiency and more power. EPA ratings gain 1 mpg in the city for front- and all-wheel-drive versions, 20 mpg in the city and 28 mpg on the highway for the front-wheel-drive model and 19/26 mpg for the AWD model. (Incidentally, Lexus is now saying AWD means "all-weather drive.")

Horsepower climbs from 270 to 295 horsepower, which matches the combined output of the current RX450h, a gasoline-electric hybrid. The powertrain of the 450h, for its part, doesn’t change much, augmenting power of the 3.5-liter gasoline engine with an electric motor boost to the front axle in front-drive versions, and another at the rear in AWD versions. EPA ratings are 31/30 mpg for the front-wheel-drive hybrid, 30/28 with AWD.

As with the current RX, the standard V-6 is paired with a smooth eight-speed automatic transmission that features paddle shifters in F Sport models. The 450h transmits power via a continuously variable transmission (CVT), which continues to be a little tedious when the driver suddenly calls for maximum thrust as the transmission works to catch up with the engine.
The F Sport version has a firmer setup with adaptive shock absorbers and multiple operating modes, giving the steering a little more sense of precision.

The Lexus chassis engineers have made alterations to the suspension setup, softening the spring rates but stiffening other components to reduce body roll in cornering without compromising ride quality. The ride is still luxurious in most trim levels, particularly the standard RX with eighteen-inch wheels (higher trim levels have twenty-inch wheels). The F Sport version has a firmer setup with adaptive shock absorbers and multiple operating modes, giving the steering a little more sense of precision. However, as with the current generation, steering is not a strong suit.

Lexus counts sixteen rivals in the RX's crossover class. Among them, you can find engines with much more punch, and several competitors that are quicker, although the RX's upgraded V-6 provides respectable acceleration; Lexus forecasts 0 to 60 mph in about seven seconds, and a little faster than that for the hybrid.

The new RX won’t reach showrooms until early December, so Lexus wasn’t ready to release 2016 prices. But pricing for the current lineup isn’t exactly at the bottom of this competitive set, ranging from about $42,000 to a little over $51,000, excluding option packages. Our fearless prediction: look for 2016 window stickers with higher numbers at the bottom line.

The 2016 Lexus RX amplifies the virtues that have made it a winner since day one: top quality, lovely interiors, quiet operation, smooth ride, and all-day comfort. Making the F Sport available in both gasoline and hybrid versions of the RX should broaden its appeal. One thing is sure: the upgraded RX can be expected to stay at the top of the Lexus sales charts.

title: 2016 Acura RLX
subTitle: On technology alone, don't overlook this luxury sedan.
promoTeaserSmall: On technology alone, don't overlook this luxury sedan.
promoTeaser: On technology alone, don't overlook this luxury sedan.
metaDescription: On technology alone, don't overlook this luxury sedan.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel drive luxury sedan
Price range: $55,370 - $66,870
Trim levels: RLX, RLX Sport Hybrid SH-AWD
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 310 horsepower; hybrid three-motor system with lithium-ion battery, combined 377 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic or seven-speed dual-clutch (Sport Hybrid)
Fuel economy: RLX: 20 mpg city/31 mpg highway; RLX Sport Hybrid: 28/32
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA): 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick Plus
Our favorite standard feature: Navigation
Notable standard features on this model: Jewel Eye LED headlights, heated side mirrors, rain-sensing windshield wipers, tri-zone automatic climate control, Milano leather-trimmed interior, power front seats, forward collision warning, adaptive cruise control
Notable options on this model: Krell audio system, heated front seats, front and rear parking sensors, heated steering wheel
You might also be considering: Audi A6, BMW 5 Series, Cadillac CTS, Mercedes-Benz E-Class

The RLX stepped up its tech game for 2016, and luckily many of the bells and whistles now come standard. Acura has the slightly frustrating practice of distinguishing between models based on packages, so for the RLX there are the Navigation, Technology, and Advance packages. For 2016, the company has dropped two packages, and Navigation is now the base model. Now that we have that cleared up, let’s talk standard features. Navigation, rain-sensing wipers, power seats, and forward collision warning are included on all package levels, which is rather incredible. The options also include some cool features, such as front and rear parking sensors and a heated steering wheel. The RLX’s 3.5-liter V-6 produces 310 horsepower, and if you opt for the Sport Hybrid, a three-motor system with lithium-ion battery will deliver 377 horsepower. Despite all the power under the hood, this vehicle received five stars from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration and was named a Top Safety Pick Plus, the highest accolade from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. There is no manual transmission available, but a seven-speed dual-clutch is found on the Sport Hybrid model. The RLX delivers luxury and performance without a BMW or Mercedes logo on the grille. You can decide whether that’s a good or bad thing.
New for 2016: AcuraWatch expands scope and content of safety and driver assistive technologies

Designer Walkaround: 2016 Acura NSX at the Detroit Auto Show (with video)

pageElements.text:
Type: 5-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive SUV/crossover
Price range: $36,190 - $44,340
Trim levels: RDX, RDX AWD
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 279 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic with paddle shifters
Fuel economy: 20 mpg city/29 mpg highway (front-wheel drive); 19/28 mpg (all-wheel drive)
Safety rating: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS): Good in four areas, Superior in front crash prevention; Marginal for child-seat anchor ease of use
Our favorite standard feature: Multi-view rear camera
Notable standard features on this model: Jewel Eye LED headlights, sport seats with leatherette-trimmed interior, driver’s ten-way power seat, front passenger four-way power seat, push-button ignition
Notable options on this model: Adaptive cruise control, navigation system, blind spot information system, ventilated front seats
You might also be considering: Audi Q5, BMW X3, Lincoln MKC, Volvo XC60

The 2016 Acura RDX brings to the table everything you would expect from an upscale crossover: comfortable size, practical entertainment and safety features, and run-of-the-mill driving experience. Acura is Honda’s luxury brand, so naturally the RDX comes with a bit more glamour. The corporate Honda multi-view rear camera, sport seats, push-button ignition, and power front seats all come standard. In the optional category are adaptive cruise control, navigation, and blind spot information, in addition to all-wheel drive. The 3.5-liter V-6 is new for 2016 and produces 279 horsepower. A six-speed automatic with paddle shifters is the only transmission available, which is not surprising for this class. In a car that often serves as a family vehicle, safety holds special weight. It may not bear the logo of an old-money car company, but at just over $36,000, you won’t have to bear the old-money price tag.
New for 2016: 3.5-liter V-6 engine, Jewel Eye LED headlamps

subTitle: Make your crew swoon.
promoTeaserSmall: Make your crew swoon.
promoTeaser: Make your crew swoon.
metaDescription: Make your crew swoon.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five- or seven-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive SUV/crossover
Price range: $43,785 - $58,000
Trim levels:
MDX, MDX SH-AWD, Tech, Entertainmennt, Advance, and AcuraWatch Plus packages
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 290 horsepower
Transmissions: Nine-speed automatic
Fuel economy: MDX: 19 mpg city/27 mpg highway; MDX with Advance package: 20/27 mpg; MDX SH-AWD: 18/26 mpg; MDX SH-AWD with Advance package: 19/26 mpg
Safety rating: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA): 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick Plus
Our favorite standard feature: Siri Eyes Free
Notable standard features on this model: Jewel Eye LED headlights, speed-sensitive wipers, sport seats with leather-trimmed interior, tri-zone automatic climate control, rear view camera
Notable options on this model: lane keeping assist system, adaptive cruise control, navigation, rear entertainment system, all-wheel drive
You might also be considering: BMW X5, Infiniti QX60, Lincoln MKT, Volvo XC90

Say goodbye to the minivan and hello to the 2016 Acura MDX, an upscale crossover that seats up to seven. Sitting behind the wheel will put a smile on your face for any number of reasons. Perhaps it’s the fact that you are operating a vehicle with a nine-speed automatic transmission hooked up to a 3.5-liter V-6 that produces 290 horsepower. Or maybe you’re enjoying the standard Siri Eyes Free technology; or the leather-trimmed interior; or the automatic climate control; or the rearview camera. Really, the list could go on. For an extra chunk of change you can also get your hands on optional features that will make your trip safer and easier, like lane keeping assist system, adaptive cruise control, navigation, or all-wheel drive. Speaking of safe, the MDX earned five stars from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration and was a 2015 Top Safety Pick Plus, top accolade from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. This SUV/crossover may not steal your heart with its exterior, but every other aspect will make you and your crew swoon.
New for 2016: Nine-speed automatic transmission

Engines: 2.4-liter four-cylinder, 201 horsepower

The 2016 Acura ILX brings value and affordability to the sport-sedan class. Competing against popular choices including the Audi A3 and the Mercedes-Benz CLA-Class, the ILX offers a comparable level of luxury and sophistication at a reasonable price. Also, feel free to gawk at that fuel efficiency: 25 mpg city, 36 mpg highway. This sedan has a 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine producing 201 horsepower mated to an eight-speed dual-clutch transmission. The standard features on this vehicle drive home the overall theme of value. Heated front seats with driver’s eight-way power adjustment, push-button ignition, a five-inch color information display, and a rearview camera are standard. Some of the latest safety features are optional: a collision mitigation system, adaptive cruise control, and navigation. Bottom line, the ILX will deliver tasteful and comfortable bang for your sensible buck.

New for 2016: 2.4-liter engine, AcuraWatch safety and driver-assistive features

2016 Acura ILX: Introduced at Los Angeles Auto Show

title: 7 Must-Dos for Your Car This Fall
subTitle: Before the snow flies, check these maintenance tasks off your list.
promoTitle: 7 Must-Dos for Your Car This Fall
promoTeaserSmall: Before the snow flies, check these maintenance tasks off your list.
promoTeaser: Before the snow flies, check these maintenance tasks off your list.
keywords: 7 Must-Dos for Your Car This Fall
metaTitle: 7 Must-Dos for Your Car This Fall - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Before the snow flies, check these maintenance tasks off your list.

pageElements.text: It may still be hot and muggy where you are, but make no mistake: cold weather is coming. With it come icy highways, road salt, dry air, and general unpleasantness.

Of course cold weather can be beautiful and enjoyable, too, but only when you are well prepared for it. Just as you’ll enjoy a cross-country ski adventure the most if you’re correctly dressed for the weather, you’ll appreciate the cold months of driving the most if your car is ready for it.
Right now, before cooling temperatures make it more of a challenge, have a look at these seven areas to take care of, and make sure you’re ready for winter.

1. Protect your car’s exterior. Early autumn is the perfect time to work on your car’s body: the weather is not too hot, not too cold. A careful cleaning, followed by a coating of wax or sealant (synthetic wax product), will help protect the paint job against the ravages of winter and help keep salt and road gunk from doing too much damage to your paint job. A protective coating is very helpful even if you only do it once a year, in case you’re not the kind of person who normally obsesses over car finishes.

2. Do a thorough interior cleaning. The dry air of winter will be no friend to your leather upholstery. Lexol and Meguiar’s are two of the best known makers of leather conditioning products for the car. These are best applied at temperatures above 60 degrees Fahrenheit, so September is perfect. Aside from keeping the leather from cracking, you’ll be happier when you’re sealed into your vehicle this winter if you start with a clean, crumb- and debris-free car interior; all the easier to keep on top of the salt and grime that will get tracked in as the weather intensifies. Need better floor mats? This is a good time to put in some heavy-duty winter mats.

3. Check the battery. In any vehicle that’s more than five years old, the battery could need changing. You don’t want to find that out when your car suddenly won’t start in the dark in February. Besides, a battery is one of the cheapest updates you can make on a car. Get it checked at your next oil change, or sooner.

4. Check the brakes. What is more important, really? Brakes will be called upon to do extra duty on slick roads. John Nielsen of AAA points out, “Brake components that are badly worn, or a brake system in need of hydraulic fluid, may not provide the level of control needed for safe winter driving." Don’t wait to hear that metallic sound that tells you your pads need replacing; have your mechanic look over your brake pads and rotors this fall.

image.altText: Fall Clean Snow Tire Goodyear Ultra Grip Ice WRT

pageElements.text: 5. Take a serious look at your tires. Snow tires are an excellent investment in the North. All-season tires are okay, although not as desirable as mud-and-snow tires in cold climates. Whatever tires your vehicle is wearing, it's time to replace them when the tread depth gets down below 4/32”. Also, check your tire pressure regularly as the weather changes, because your tires will lose a pound of air pressure for every ten degrees the weather drops. Once a week is not too often. If you have a spare tire, check its pressure, too.

6. Get your coolant system flushed out. This is an every-other-year kind of thing, but that doesn’t mean it’s unimportant. Fluids are the life blood of your vehicle, and a freshly flushed compartment with fresh antifreeze can help your car keep working well in extreme temperatures.

7. Change the wiper blades. Every fall and every spring is a good schedule to replace the wipers. If you’re anticipating a harsh winter where you live, get special winter wiper blades that can stand up to more abuse from snow and ice. Look forward to swapping them out in the spring for another fresh pair just in time for April showers. This is a small expenditure that reaps great quality-of-life benefits.

title: 2016 Scion iA: Jean's Driveway
subTitle: Is the all-new subcompact attractive enough to grab Millennials' attention? I asked one.
promoTeaserSmall: Is the all-new subcompact attractive enough to grab Millennials' attention? I asked one.
promoTeaser: Is the all-new subcompact attractive enough to grab Millennials' attention? I asked one.
metaDescription: Is the all-new subcompact attractive enough to grab Millennials' attention? I asked one.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/BxjkYK-ZkOA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive subcompact sedan
Base price: $16,495 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $18,184
Engine: 1.5-liter four-cylinder, 106 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual
Fuel economy: 31 mpg city/41 mpg highway
Safety: Not yet rated by National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) or Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS)
My favorite standard feature: Rearview camera
Notable options on this model: Navigation system ($419), door-sill protectors ($170)
You might also be considering: 2016 Chevrolet Sonic LS Manual ($15,170); 2016 Ford Fiesta S ($14,965); 2016 Honda Fit LX ($16,610); 2016 Hyundai Accent SE ($15,570); 2016 Kia Rio LX ($14,990)

Key Points:

• The iA is an all-new model and Scion's first sedan. It doesn't replace any existing vehicle in the lineup for this youth-oriented Toyota brand.

• And since I said "youth oriented," I brought my own Millennial, intern Annie Boniface, to do this short, sweet video review of the iA.
• Along with the new iM hatchback, it's an attempt to rev up Scion's product line, which has been in a bit of a drought with no new products since the FR-S in 2012.
• It's based on the Mazda 2 sedan, which is not currently sold in the United States, and it looks like a small Mazda inside and out.
• The model we tested had a six-speed manual transmission; a six-speed automatic transmission adds $1,100 to the price.

• The iA is a fuel-economy leader in this already frugal class. EPA fuel economy is 33 mpg city/42 mpg highway for the model with six-speed automatic transmission. Compare that with the Hyundai Accent's 26/37 mpg (1.6-liter four-cylinder engine, six-speed automatic transmission); the Chevrolet Sonic at 24/35 mpg (1.8-liter four-cylinder, six-speed automatic); and the Kia Rio at 27/37 mpg (1.6-liter four-cylinder, six-speed automatic).

• Safety equipment helps the iA stand out from the pack, especially the standard low-speed pre-collision safety system that uses a laser sensor to help the driver avoid collisions. Other standard items include six airbags, a brake-override system, and a rearview camera. This kind of technology is not seen in the subcompact car class, let alone as a standard feature.
• The company claims to offer a "no hassle" buying experience at Scion dealerships.
• The warranty also sets it apart from its rivals: scheduled maintenance is covered for two years or 25,000 miles.

• Manufacturers of “youth oriented” cars are missing their targets as Baby Boomers have co-opted many of the vehicles intended for entry-level buyers.
Will that happen here? The average age of a Scion driver is around thirty-seven, according to industry reports.

More to Read:

Should You Buy It? 2016 Scion iA

title: 2016 Honda HR-V
subTitle: Smaller than the CR-V, but you'll be seeing just as many of them on the road soon.
promoTeaserSmall: Smaller than the CR-V, but you'll be seeing just as many of them on the road soon.
promoTeaser: Smaller than the CR-V, but you'll be seeing just as many of them on the road soon.
metaDescription: Smaller than the CR-V, but you'll be seeing just as many of them on the road soon.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive compact crossover
Price range: $19,995–$25,470 (prices include destination charge)
Trim levels: LX, EX, EX-L Navi
Engine: 1.8-liter four-cylinder, 141 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual (FWD LX or EX), continuously variable automatic (AWD models, EX and EX-L Navi)
Fuel economy: 25 mpg city/34 mpg highway (FWD, six-speed manual transmission); 28/35 mpg (FWD, CVT); 27/32 mpg (AWD, CVT)
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA): 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS):
Not yet rated
Our favorite standard feature: Multi-angle rearview camera (with guide lines on EX and EX-L Navi)
Notable standard features on this model: LED brake lights, intermittent rear wiper, tilting and telescoping steering wheel
Notable options on this model: Honda Lane Watch active safety package, power tilting moonroof, daytime running lamps, rear privacy glass, push-button start, heated front seats, seven-inch infotainment screen with HondaLink and Pandora compatibility (EX and EX-L Navi); roof rails, leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift knob, leather-trimmed seats, navigation system, SiriusXM HD radio (EX-L Navi only)
You might also be considering: Buick Encore, Kia Soul, Jeep Renegade, Mazda CX-3, Nissan Juke

If you are interested in a subcompact—the Honda Fit, perhaps, an excellent example of the genre—but you want all-wheel drive, a higher seating position, more ground clearance, and more utility, how about the all-new 2016 Honda HR-V? That was the thinking at Honda, a company that has earned the respect and sometimes fanatic loyalty of a large number of U.S. buyers. The HR-V has some of the great features you may already know from the Fit: the second-row Magic Seat that folds into the floor and makes the interior almost incomprehensibly roomy—58.8 cubic feet of cargo space, with the rear seats down—the long list of standard equipment, and the multi-angle rearview camera, along with LaneWatch active safety tech on the upper-level EX and EX-L Navi models.

This is still a small SUV and won't be a choice for someone who is eyeing a Chevrolet Suburban or a Range Rover, but it's got the all-wheel drive, practicality, and citified appeal that Honda fans will appreciate and small-crossover buyers will find very, very attractive.

New for 2016: The HR-V is an all-new model.


More to Read:

Should You Buy It? 2016 Honda HR-V

title: 2017 Bentley Bentayga
subTitle: An SUV to end all SUVs makes a splashy debut at the Frankfurt Auto Show.
promoTeaserSmall: An SUV to end all SUVs makes a splashy debut at the Frankfurt Auto Show.
promoTeaser: An SUV to end all SUVs makes a splashy debut at the Frankfurt Auto Show.
metaDescription: An SUV to end all SUVs makes a splashy debut at the Frankfurt Auto Show.

pageElements.text:
Type: Ultra-indulgent five-to-six-passenger sport-utility vehicle
Release date: Early 2016
Estimated price: Starting just under $200,000
Competes against: Range Rover
What’s most interesting: All-new 6.0-liter twin-turbocharged W-12 engine making 600 horsepower and 663 pound-feet of torque

The Bentley Bentayga is a high-luxury sport-utility vehicle that can go anywhere, if you’re brave enough to take a vehicle this expensive everywhere. The all-new suspension has four on-road settings handle just about everything, operated through a single rotary dial. But wait, there’s more: an additional four off-road modes handle Snow & Grass, Dirt & Gravel, Mud & Trail, and Sand Dunes.

Inside, you’ll find everything you’d expect from a Bentley SUV: diamond-quilted leather seats “inspired by finely tailored hunting jackets.” Heated and ventilated seats with six massage program settings and up to twenty-two ways to adjust them. Wood-veneer trim all the way to the rear console and the optional picnic tables. Technology is the latest, including electronic infrared night vision.

Even more personalization comes from custom division Mulliner, which can fit a bespoke three-piece picnic hamper set that doubles as a set of outdoor seats, with a refrigerator compartment inside. Or choose a Breitling Mulliner Tourbillon, in rose or white gold with mother-of-pearl or ebony face and diamond indexes. Get this: the car has a dedicated drive to wind the watch for you.
Coming soon are a clean diesel and a plug-in hybrid version, plus a seven-seater Bentayga. Something for everyone (who has money)!

images.caption: 2017 Bentley Bentayga event seat and hampers.

title: 2017 Jaguar F-Pace
subTitle: The Jaguar of crossovers has an attractive face and an even more attractive price.
promoTeaserSmall: The Jaguar of crossovers has an attractive face and an even more attractive price.
promoTeaser: The Jaguar of crossovers has an attractive face and an even more attractive price.
metaDescription: The Jaguar of crossovers has an attractive face and an even more attractive price.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, all-wheel-drive luxury crossover
Release date: Spring 2016
Estimated price: $43,385–$57,695; $70,695 (First Edition) (prices include destination charge)
Trim levels: Premium, Prestige, R-Sport, S
Engine choices: Supercharged 3.0-liter V-6, 340 or 380 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic
Competes against: Audi Q5, BMW X5, Lexus RX, Porsche Macan, Volvo XC90
What’s most interesting: Lightweight aluminum construction; wearable, waterproof Activity Key to let you lock keys into the vehicle while you snowboard, surf, or hike
The Jaguar F-Pace made a debut at the Frankfurt Auto Show on Monday that was worthy of the Guinness world records people, and indeed the loop-the-loop stunt qualified for the record book.

It was only a matter of time until Jaguar decided: Can't beat 'em? Join 'em. So here is a luxury crossover from the British luxury brand. If you like the F-Type sedan but want something more SUV-like, here's your Jaguar. Billed as "an all-weather Jaguar sports car, life-proofed for five people and their belongings," the F-Pace should catch the eye of anyone shopping for a crossover in the $40,000 range.

The first F-Pace you're likely to see will be the $70,000-plus First Edition special, in Rhodium Silver with unique cosmetic touches including red brake calipers, a full set of LED headlights, glossy black fender vents, a sliding panoramic roof, and a set of twenty-two-inch fifteen-spoke wheels. Inside, there's special hound's-tooth embossed Windsor leather upholstery and other luxury touches. Jaguar will also bring out a four-cylinder diesel version in late 2016.

Will it feel like a Jaguar to drive? The automaker says yes, in part because of its Intelligent Driveline Dynamics system, which gives the F-Pace the rear-wheel-drive Jaguar driving experience, then automatically transferring to all-wheel drive in a matter of milliseconds when you need more traction.

As you'd expect, Jaguar loaded up the F-Pace with a plethora of active safety technology involving a forward facing stereo camera for lane departure warning and automatic emergency braking systems. There's also a laser head-up display, adaptive cruise control with long-range radar ("queue assist," as Jaguar puts it), traffic sign recognition, an intelligent speed limiter that can automatically adjust to speed limits as you pass through them, a blind spot monitor that can also detect other vehicles approaching fast from behind, and park assist.

Interesting but frivolous technology includes the Activity Key ($400), a sort of FitBit-style waterproof wristband that lets you leave the keys securely locked in the F-Pace while you go off snowboarding, surfing, or hiking.

Jaguar has recently unveiled a comprehensive new five-year/60,000-mile warranty program called EliteCare that's on all Jaguars sold in the United States, and the new F-Pace is no exception, packaging five years or 60,000 miles of complimentary scheduled maintenance and 24/7 roadside assistance. This, the availability of this crossover, and a resolve to lower prices across the board, should go a long way toward getting people back in Jaguar showrooms.

title: Jeeps at the Frankfurt Auto Show
subTitle: Eye candy: Jeep's trio of Mopar-ized show versions of its Cherokee, Renegade, and Wrangler SUVs.
promoTitle: Jeeps at the Frankfurt Auto Show
promoTeaserSmall: Eye candy: Jeep's trio of Mopar-ized show versions of its Cherokee, Renegade, and Wrangler SUVs.
promoTeaser: Eye candy: Jeep's trio of Mopar-ized show versions of its Cherokee, Renegade, and Wrangler SUVs.
keywords: Jeeps at the Frankfurt Auto Show
metaTitle: Jeeps at the Frankfurt Auto Show - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Eye candy: Jeep's trio of Mopar-ized show versions of its Cherokee, Renegade, and Wrangler SUVs.

pageElements.text: How much do Europeans like Jeeps? This year, a whole lot: Jeep set an all-time summer sales record with small but significant numbers (in the mid-four figures) that added up to a 163 percent increase for the year through August. A lot of that sales bump came from the all-new Renegade, so Jeep's Mopar division wisely showed off a modified version of the Renegade at the Frankfurt Auto Show this week. There was also a Cherokee and a Wrangler specially modified for the occasion.
Not intended for sale, these are Jeep's way of showing off some of what Mopar can do. They're fun to look at, though.

Jeep Renegade Trailhawk
The rugged yet cute 2015 Renegade made its debut at the 2014 New York Auto Show. Here at Frankfurt, the Mopar-ized Renegade Trailhawk is decked out in special Anvil paint with special edition stickers on the sides. It gets special seventeen-inch wheels, a pair of rear tow hooks, black mirror caps, and skid plates underneath. Mopar touches include special pedals and floor mats. More photos in the gallery at the end.

Jeep Wrangler Rubicon Sunriser
Check out that sunrise-colored matte orange paint job, the four-inch suspension lift kit, and the double tow hooks on the front bumper. There's an engine skid plate and bead-lock wheels that guard against "unintended tire removal" during rock, sand, or mud maneuvers. (Always a good thing.) The trend toward LED lighting gets a nod with daytime running lights and rear lights, as well as between the A-pillar and the windshield. Inside you see the same matte orange teamed with black leather. See additional photos in the gallery below.

Jeep Cherokee KrawLer
The Cherokee goes by Jeep code name KL, thus the capital letters in this show Jeep's name. Get it? The KrawLer is modified to look and work like an extreme off-roader, based on the top Trailhawk model with the addition of a heavy-duty suspension, off-road tires, skid plates, rock rails, and wide fenders. It has Jeep's Active Drive Lock four-wheel-drive system with low range and a rear differential lock, and it features the FCA corporate nine-speed automatic transmission. Cosmetically, that paint job is matte green designed to look military, and the interior has a Quartz Grey theme.

title: 2015 Hyundai Azera
subTitle: Character actor.
promoTeaserSmall: Character actor.
promoTeaser: Character actor.
metaDescription: Character actor. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive sedan
Price range: $34,895–$39,095 (includes destination)
Trim levels: Azera, Limited
Engine: 3.3-liter V-6, 293 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: Azera: 20 mpg city/29 mpg highway; Limited: 19/28 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Good; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Hands-free trunk opener
Notable standard features on this model: Leather upholstery, suite of electronically controlled active safety features, 12-way power driver’s seat, heated and ventilated front seats and heated rear seats, dual-zone climate control system, cooled glove box, Bluetooth connectivity, iPod/USB ports
Notable options on this model: 19-inch wheels, LED foglamps, HID headlamps, panoramic sunroof, carbon interior accents, power rear sunshade, manual rear-window shades
You might also be considering: Buick LaCrosse, Ford Taurus, Nissan Maxima, Toyota Avalon

Not many people know the Hyundai Azera. If this front-wheel-drive sedan were an actor, it would have a long and successful career doing character roles, like Wilfrid Hyde-White, who played Colonel Hugh Pickering in My Fair Lady. The Azera has nicely sculpted bodywork and a presentable face, a contemporary powertrain that can sing, and a newly upgraded infotainment system that masters all its lines. Weighing significantly less than many its competitors, it can also do the old soft shoe. For 2015, the Azera gets a minor face lift and fanny tuck with a new grille and bumpers. The standard eighteen-inch wheels have been redesigned. And the sedan adds a standard hands-free trunk opener for convenience and blind-spot detection with rear cross-traffic alert and lane-change assist for safety. Climbing inside over newly illuminated door sill plates and settling into the heated and ventilated leather front seats, we find the redesigned center stack includes an eight-inch touchscreen that can split between navigation and audio functions. The 14-speaker sound system brings out all the tenderness of "On the Street Where You Live." Included in the Azera Limited are a panoramic sunroof, power rear sunshade, manual rear side window sunshades, and ambient lighting. When you’re casting for a premium sedan, the Azera might not come to mind first, but you may find it perfect for the part.

New for 2015

Restyled front and rear; new 8-inch LCD screen and infotainment features; standard blind-spot detection, rear cross-traffic alert, and lane-change assist.

title: 2015 Hyundai Equus
subTitle: Serenity in motion.
promoTeaserSmall: Serenity in motion.
promoTeaser: Serenity in motion.
metaDescription: Serenity in motion. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, rear-wheel-drive sedan
Price range: $62,450–$69,700 (includes destination)
Trim levels: Signature, Ultimate
Engine: 5.0-liter V-8, 429 horsepower
Transmission: 8-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 15 mpg city/23 mpg highway
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Good; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Heated and ventilated front seats
Notable standard features on this model: 19-inch alloy wheels, navigation, 9.2-inch touchscreen, 7-inch TFT instrument display, 3-zone automatic climate system, smart cruise control, lane-departure warning with blind spot detection, 17-speaker sound system
Notable options on this model: Dual 9.2-inch rear entertainment monitors, power door closers, rear-seat lumbar support, 12.3-inch TFT instrument display, around-view camera system, ventilated rear seats
You might also be considering: Kia K900, Lexus LS, Mercedes-Benz S-Class,

Substantial, roomy, and powerful, the Hyundai Equus is an alternative luxury sedan that might not dazzle your kinfolk and neighbors quite like a Mercedes-Benz but will draw smiles and nods from your accountant and investment adviser. The Equus looks restrained yet elegant, and it has flair but not flash. Brown, gray, silver, black, and white are the exterior color choices. Nineteen-inch wheels enhance the big sedan’s presence. Smooth power delivery is expected in this class, and the Equus has an eight-speed automatic transmission waving its baton to sooth the savage breast of a 429-horsepower, 5.0-liter V-8.

The Equus Signature has as many standard features as a prairie dog town has holes. Active safety is overseen by lane departure warning with blind spot detection, smart cruise control, and parking assistance, among others. Far more sumptuous than a prairie dog’s burrow, the interior includes heated and cooled leather front seats with the driver’s throne power-adjusting 12 ways from Sunday. To get really nutty, the Equus Ultimate has a 12.3-inch TFT instrument display and a head-up display, adds cooled rear seats (they’re already heated), powers up the rear head restraints, outboard lumbar supports, and side-window sun shades, and finally slaps in dual 9.2-inch entertainment system monitors. So your kinfolk and neighbors will vie with one another to ride in back.

New for 2015

There are no changes for the 2015 model year.

title: 2015 Hyundai Accent
subTitle: All modern conveniences.
promoTeaserSmall: All modern conveniences.
promoTeaser: All modern conveniences.
metaKeywords: 2015 Hyundai Accent; Hyundai; sedan; hatchback; Korean
metaDescription: All modern conveniences. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive sedan or hatchback
Price range: $15,555–$18,305 (includes destination)
Trim levels: GLS, GS 5-Door, Sport 5-Door
Engine: 1.6-liter four-cylinder, 137 horsepower
Transmissions: 6-speed manual, 6 speed automatic
Fuel economy: Manual: 27 mpg city/38 mpg highway; automatic: 26/37 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Small overlap front: Poor; Moderate overlap front: Good; Side: Average; Roof strength: Good; Head restraints and seats: Good; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Satellite radio
Notable standard features on this model: Six-way driver’s seat, air conditioning, tilt steering wheel, power windows, 6-speaker audio system, iPod and USB ports
Notable options on this model: Bluetooth connectivity, voice control, sunroof, automatic headlamps
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Sonic, Ford Fiesta, Honda Fit

Roomy for a subcompact, the Hyundai Accent is well designed inside and out and presents a level of mechanical sophistication we’re not used to seeing for less than $20,000. Under the hood, the direct-injection 1.6-liter four-cylinder generates 137 horsepower, which is outstanding for a small powerplant. The balance between performance and efficiency is hardly compromised, though, and the sculpted, streamlined body helps to achieve up to 38 highway mpg. You choose between a six-speed manual or six-speed automatic transmission; the latter comes with a selectable Eco mode that governs performance in favor of fuel economy. In addition to the sedan, the Accent is offered as a hatchback. The GS 5-Door has the same trim as the GLS sedan, but the Sport 5-Door, which replaces last year’s SE model, adds standard features such as a leather-wrapped multifunction steering wheel (and re-tuned steering), premium cloth upholstery, and auto-up driver’s side window. Outside, the Sport shows some attitude with sixteen-inch alloy wheels, LED headlamp accents, fog lamps, and a rear spoiler. Standard on every model, a suite of safety features includes active front head restraints and sophisticated stability and braking systems.

New for 2015

New grille, headlamps, and taillamps; outside temperature display; revised LCD audio display; new colors, wheels, and seat fabrics.

title: 2015 Mercedes-Benz GLK-Class
subTitle: The sun sets on this luxury crossover.
promoTeaserSmall: The sun sets on this luxury crossover.
promoTeaser: The sun sets on this luxury crossover.
metaKeywords: 2015 Mercedes-Benz GLK-class; Mercedes-Benz; Mercedes; crossover; sport-utility; SUV; wagon; diesel; German
metaDescription: The sun sets on this luxury crossover. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive SUV/crossover
Price range: $38,825–$40,325
Trim levels: GLK250 BlueTec, GLK350
Engines: Twin-turbocharged diesel 2.1-liter 4-cylinder, 200 horsepower; 3.5-liter V-6, 302 horsepower
Fuel economy: GLK250 BlueTec: 24 mpg city/33 mpg highway; GLK350: 19/25 mpg; GLK350 4MATIC: 18/24 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Good; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: 8-way power adjustable front seats
Notable standard features on this model: Bluetooth, tilt and telescoping steering column, steering-wheel mounted shift-paddles, all-wheel drive (BlueTec model), 19-inch wheels
Notable options on this model: 115-volt outlet in cargo area, power liftgate, active blind-spot, lane keeping, and parking assist
You might also be considering: Acura RDX, BMW X3, Infiniti EX

It’s the end of the line for the 2015 Mercedes-Benz GLK-Class. Next year the compact SUV will be reborn as the GLC-Class, so if you’re partial to the squared-off, wagon-esque design of the GLK, hurry to the dealership before they’re all spoken for. Engine variants for this model include a 3.5-liter V-6 with 302 horsepower and a twin-turbo 2.1-liter four-cylinder diesel with 200 horsepower and 369 pound-feet of torque. Both engines are paired with a seven-speed automatic transmission, and while you can get the GLK350 with rear- or all-wheel drive, the diesel version is only available with the latter. At 18 mpg in the city and 24 mpg on the highway, fuel economy is decent but not exceptional in the GLK350 4MATIC, although dropping AWD will improve the numbers by 1 mpg in both the city and highway ratings. To get a significant bump, you’ll have to opt for the diesel, if you can still find it.

Legroom is a bit snug for rear passengers with only 35.1 inches to spread out and, despite its boxy hindquarters, the GLK-Class's cargo capacity is only 16.5 cubic feet with the rear seats up; that number jumps to 54.7 with the second row folded flat. Like most Mercedes-Benz vehicles, the GLK's interior is elegant, but most of the bells and whistles that many drivers have come to expect in new vehicles are optional features, such as navigation, a rearview camera, and a power liftgate. That usually isn’t much of a drawback for luxury buyers willing to shell out the extra thousands for the German crossover’s premium packages, but as with most end-of-cycle cars, they’ll probably have to take what they can get from what’s left on the lot.

New for 2015

No major changes.

You might also be considering: Land Rover Range Rover, Toyota Land Cruiser

The G-Class stands out in the crowded SUV field due to its iconic design that harks back to a time when “explorer” was an acceptable job title. The 2015 G is well equipped with either a 382-horsepower, 5.5-liter V-8 engine in the GL550 or the twin-turbo version that bumps up the output to 536 horsepower in the G63. Both are paired with a seven-speed automatic transmission. With standard all-wheel drive, three sequentially lockable differentials, and eight inches of wheel travel, the G-Class boasts some serious off-road capabilities. One may be forgiven for saying the G-Class is over-engineered, since it’s more likely to be traversing the Whole Foods parking lot rather than the plains of the Serengeti. On that end, drivers will be pleased that it’s standard equipped with adaptive cruise control, blind-spot assist, a rearview camera, and parking assist sensors to help you squeeze into those tricky compact parking spaces.

New for 2015

There are no major changes to the G-Class for 2015.

subTitle: Commercial vehicle with versatility and appeal.
promoTeaserSmall: Commercial vehicle with versatility and appeal.
promoTeaser: Commercial vehicle with versatility and appeal.

pageElements.text:

Price range: $36,990–$47,175 (includes destination)
Trim levels: 2500 Cargo, 2500 Passenger, 2500 Crew, 3500 Cargo, 3500 Passenger, 3500 Chassis Cab
Engines: Turbo-diesel 2.1-liter four-cylinder, 161 horsepower; turbo-diesel 3.0-liter V-6, 188 horsepower
Transmission: Seven-speed automatic
Fuel economy: N/A
Safety ratings: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Crosswind assist
Notable standard features on this model: Load-adaptive stability control, collision prevention, 5.8-inch color LCD display, Bluetooth
Notable options on this model: Regular or long wheelbase, standard or high roof, parking assist, lane-keeping assist, blind-spot assist, rearview camera
You might also be considering: Ford Transit, GMC Savana, Nissan NV, Ram ProMaster

The market for a sixteen-seat commercial van is largely, well, commercial, but the choices have never been more appealing if you’re looking for a people mover. The 2015 Mercedes-Benz Sprinter is available as either a passenger (three row), crew (two row with cargo), or cargo van configuration, and offered with a 144- or 170-inch wheelbase. Buyers can choose from two turbo-diesel engines: the standard 161-horsepower, 2.1-liter 4-cylinder or a 188-horsepower, 3.0-liter V-6. Both are linked to a seven-speed automatic transmission. Although not technically an off-roader, it does have an available 4x4 drivetrain on both cargo and passenger versions equipped with the V-6, which makes it more capable in inclement weather. And because of its tall and top-heavy vehicle—especially if you choose the high roof option—buyers will appreciate the standard crosswind assist for additional stability. Optional safety features abound, including blind-spot assist, lane-keeping assist, and high beam assist. While a 5.8-inch color display and Bluetooth connectivity are standard, a rearview camera is optional. The interior has been nicely upgraded, but most of the outfitting in a Sprinter is bespoke and performed by what Mercedes calls a Preferred Upfitter, which means the sky—and your wallet—is the limit when it comes to customizing this van.

New for 2015

Crosswind Assist has been added as a standard feature and all-wheel drive can now be optioned with the V-6 engine.
