The 2015 Mercedes-Benz SLK brings a bit of refinement and comfort to the sporty compact roadster segment. The compact two-seater shares a lot of features with its pricier and more aggressive SL sibling. Similarities include the Swiss-army knife panoramic glass roof hardtop that transforms seamlessly into convertible in less than 20 seconds, and it’s also available with the glass-panoramic-roof darkening Magic Sky Control. Airscarf, which blows warm air onto your neck, is optional rather than standard. The real tradeoff between the two models is in the performance and proportions. Engine options for the SLK include a 1.8-liter turbo 4-cylinder that produces 201 horsepower, a 3.5-liter V-6 with a 302-horsepower output, and the range-topping 415-horsepower 5.5-liter V-8. A six-speed manual is offered but only on the base SLK250; the other models get a seven-speed automatic. The SLK has smaller exterior dimensions, which explains the significantly tighter cabin and trunk, but nobody buys a roadster for its cargo capacity or legroom.

New for 2015

There are no major changes to the SLK for 2015.

title: 5 Cool Things about the 2016 Honda Civic
subTitle: 2016 model is sleeker and more tech laden.
promoTitle: 5 Cool Things about the 2016 Honda Civic
promoTeaserSmall: Wrap your heads around the fact that this is a Civic!
promoTeaser: Wrap your heads around the fact that this is a Civic!
keywords: 5 Cool Things about the Honda Civic
metaTitle: 5 Cool Things about the 2016 Honda Civic - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 2016 model is sleeker and more tech laden. Wrap your heads around the fact that this is a Civic!

pageElements.text: The Honda Civic looked so small, so...economical, when it first reached the United States some forty years ago. Back then, its very size was revolutionary, and it quickly set about creating a fan base that has grown exponentially over the years.

How things have changed. The all-new tenth-generation Civic sedan was introduced in Los Angeles on Sept. 16. It's longer, lower, and sportier in appearance than anything a Civic buyer of the 1970s could have imagined. Thirty-five million people worldwide have bought a Civic; we have a feeling that number is going to take a jump once the all-new model comes out this fall.
If you had any doubt that Honda has just given the Civic's substantial customer base something to drool over, one look will convince you.
Or maybe five looks? Here are five cool things we noticed about the 2016 Civic.

1. There's a turbo. It's an all-new 1.5-liter four-cylinder teamed with a continuously variable transmission, tipped to exceed 40 mpg on the highway. You'll find it on the EX-T, EX-L, and Touring models. This is the first turbocharged engine on a U.S. Honda and will offer more power than any U.S. Civic has ever had that's not an Si model.
The standard engine on the new Civic is a 2.0-liter four-cylinder, which you can pair with a six-speed manual or a continuously variable automatic transmission.

2. It's a smartphone user's dream. Apple CarPlay and Android Auto are both enabled, letting you use your favorite apps—from Google Maps to your Apple music collection—from the Civic's 7.0-inch touchscreen.

3. It is amazingly spacious. Honda is really, really good at optimizing interior space, and the new Civic is no exception. The automaker has added 3.7 more cubic feet, including 2.7 more cubic feet in the trunk, and added two inches of rear-seat legroom over the 2015 model. The driver's seat rides lower in this wider, longer body, and even the center console is more capable with up to 7.2 liters' worth of enclosed storage capability up front.

4. It has the latest in advanced safety technology. Honda has rolled out its Honda Sensing suite of tech on its 2016 CR-V, Pilot, and Accord, and the Civic will have it available. Adaptive Cruise Control with Low-Speed Follow (a blessing in stop-and-go traffic, giving your right leg a rest while it safely creeps along for you) will make its first appearance on a Honda. There's also collision mitigation braking (automatically applying brake pressure when it senses that you're not hitting the brakes hard enough to avoid colliding with the car ahead of you) and road departure mitigation, an engineering marvel that uses the steering and brakes to help keep you from inadvertently driving off a marked roadway. It's triggered between 45 and 90 mph when you're drifting too close to the right lane marking line without your right turn signal on.

5. A Civic Type-R is coming. Yes, performance fans, the first ever Civic Type-R for U.S. buyers, promises American Honda communications chief Sage Marie. The rest of the lineup will include a coupe, a sportier Si model, and a five-door hatchback, all rolling out this fall after the sedan (and not yet shown to the public).
Pricing has not yet been announced.

title: 2016 Ford Explorer Platinum
subTitle: Should you spring for the top-end model of the all-new SUV? Here's what we think.
promoTeaserSmall: Should you spring for the top-end model of the all-new SUV? Here's what we think.
promoTeaser: Should you spring for the top-end model of the all-new SUV? Here's what we think.
metaDescription: Should you spring for the top-end model of the all-new SUV? Here's what we think.

pageElements.text:
Type: Seven-passenger, all-wheel-drive sport-utility vehicle
Base price (base Explorer with front-wheel drive): $31,995 (all prices include destination charge)
Base price (Explorer Platinum): $53,915
Price as tested: $54,760
Engine: Turbocharged 3.5-liter V-6, 365 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 16 mpg city/22 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA): 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS): Good in three areas, Marginal on small overlap front crash test
My favorite standard feature: 10.1-inch infotainment touchscreen
Notable standard features on this model: 20-inch aluminum alloy wheels; power moonroof; 10.1-inch display screen; navigation; premium Sony audio; brushed aluminum and ash wood interior trim; perforated, heated and ventilated leather upholstery; adaptive cruise control; heated wood and leather steering wheel with power tilt and telescope; rearview camera; blind spot detection
Notable options on this model: Second-row captain's chairs with center console ($845)
You might also be considering: Acura MDX, Audi Q7, Buick Enclave, Infiniti QX60, Land Rover LR4, Lexus GX, Volvo XC90, Lincoln MKT
What’s this? A $54,760 Explorer? Really?

Well, why not? America has been demonstrating an increasing appetite for luxury in its vehicle selections, and Ford’s marketing mavens see an opportunity to cash in. Never mind that a luxury version of the Explorer steps on its corporate cousin, the Lincoln MKT, from the division that Ford is working so hard to revitalize.
So what distinguishes the Explorer Platinum from the Explorer Sport, the previous top-of-the-line version, base price (including destination charge) $44,445?

There are some details unique to the Platinum edition—a 10.1-inch center dash digital display; leather upholstery, including heated and ventilated seats up front and some fancy stitching; a 500-watt Sony audio system with twelve speakers; a heated wood-and-leather rim steering wheel; brushed aluminum interior trim; and a brushed aluminum Ford badge affixed to the center of the steering wheel hub.
That’s Nirvana leather, by the way.

But, mostly, stepping up to Platinum will net you just about everything available in the Explorer option catalog: all-wheel drive, dual power moonroof, navigation, you name it. The only extra-cost option on the model I drove is second-row captain’s chairs with a center console, $845.

To demonstrate the Platinum package, Ford put together an unusual rally, beginning in Vancouver, British Columbia, and finishing up in Albuquerque. It wound through nine cities, covering 1,278 miles and involving 187 journalists in the driving.

Our segment started at Big Sky, near Bozeman, Montana, and concluded near Jackson, Wyoming. The idea was to develop your own driving adventure—within the constraints of the starting point and destination, of course. Our adventure was a visit to Yellowstone National Park, where we watched the Old Faithful geyser spout boiling water into the sky, saw a bison ambling down the middle of the road—no one was inclined to contest his right of way—and enjoyed the beautiful scenery.

A minor footnote was a Forest Service roadblock that required a minor detour to get to our destination hotel. This was caused by a visitation of black bears, who’d come down from the nearby Grand Teton mountains to munch on a bumper crop of wild berries. Unfortunately, we didn’t really get a look at the bears.

Through all of this, the Explorer Platinum comported itself competently and unobtrusively. The chassis engineers note specific suspension tuning for this edition, which we’d guess is a little softer than that of the Sport and a little firmer than the other Explorers. Be that as it may, ride quality was smooth, although smooth also applies to the highways we traveled as well as the operation of the six-speed automatic transmission.
Even with its biggest of Explorer engines—a 3.5-liter EcoBoost V-6—acceleration can’t be called much better than adequate.

Even with its biggest of Explorer engines—a 3.5-liter EcoBoost V-6—acceleration can’t be called much better than adequate. We dipped into the V-6’s power reservoirs frequently once clear of the national park, passing vacationers who were in no hurry, and making these passes required a fair amount of advance planning.

However, to be fair, this is a vehicle that weighs pretty close to 5,000 pounds, and our route entailed altitude—between 5,000 and 7,000 feet. Altitude is the enemy of horsepower, and we’re sure this fanciest of Explorers will perform more vigorously closer to sea level. It also dilutes fuel economy, but we didn’t check mpg for our trek. The EPA rates this setup for 16 mpg city, 22 highway, lowest in the Explorer lineup.

One other Explorer Platinum trait that merits mention: a lack of cabin noise. Ford cites noise reduction as a key development target for this edition, and we have to say mission accomplished. Quiet operation is a key component of vehicle comfort, and the Explorer Platinum is among the best in its class on this key metric.

The Verdict:

There's no doubt that the Explorer Platinum goes about its business with quiet competence, made better by the fact that it is loaded with luxury features. So, should you consider paying the substantial price premium for the top-of-the-line Explorer? You'll be paying a $10,000 premium over the Explorer Sport—which carries it into competition against some of the many prestige three-row luxury utes in this price class—but for those who want both luxury and a Ford Explorer, it's a good choice to have.

The only thing longer than the fuel range in the Hyundai Sonata is the list of trim levels. The SE, Sport, and Limited will most often come with the 2.4-liter four-cylinder, and the Eco gets the 1.6-liter four-cylinder. In the Sport 2.0T and Limited 2.0T, the turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder delivers a wild ride. Finally, the Hybrids bring even more efficiency to the party with a 2.4-liter four-cylinder that is paired with lithium-ion battery and electric motor. The one thing all of these models have in common? Impeccable value. The price starts at just over $20,000, and for that money you have access to standard features like remote keyless entry, cruise control, and driver’s blind spot mirror. For a bit more cash you can enjoy a heated steering wheel, hands-free Smart Trunk opener, and other less necessary options. Tree huggers on a budget will smile at the Hybrid models’ price tags. Affordability does not trump safety here, though, and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration gave the Sonata five stars.
New for 2016: Driver’s knee airbag

You might also be considering: Audi A3, BMW Z4, Mercedes-Benz E-Class

It has been some time since Buick has offered a convertible in the U.S. market; it has been since the Reatta, last produced in 1991. This one, which goes on sale in spring 2016, is all new for American buyers but is sold in Europe as the Opel Cascada. This model was greeted with approval at its debut at the 2015 North American International Auto Show in Detroit. Built on the same platform as Buick's Verano compact sedan, the Cascada is billed as large enough to fit four adults, with 13.4 cubic feet of storage space with the top up. As for the top, it's a folding electrohydraulic soft top that retracts in seventeen seconds at speeds up to 31 mph. Luxury features are many, including General Motors' increasingly ubiquitous 4G LTE wireless hot spot on board, a 7.0-inch touchscreen with GM's excellent IntelliLink infotainment system, 20-inch wheels, and heated front seats and steering wheel, all standard. Active safety features include lane departure warning, park assist, rain-sensing wipers, and a rearview camera. Buick may be scratching an itch for a reasonably priced, reasonably luxurious convertible with this new model.
New for 2016: The Cascada is all new for 2016.

If you’re looking for muscle in a not-so-obvious way, you might want to put Buick Verano on your list. The Verano has two engines available, a 2.4-liter four-cylinder that produces 180 horsepower and a 2.0-liter four-cylinder that produces 250 horsepower. This power is kept neatly beneath Buick’s classic design and elegance, though. Luxury remains a selling point as standard features include dual-zone automatic climate control, eight-way power driver’s seat, and push-button start. Options take this luxury a bit further, providing a heated, leather-wrapped steering wheel, heated and leather-appointed seating, and  a rearview camera. For 2016, Buick has updated its Driver Confidence package and moved from six-way power driver’s seat to eight-way. The infotainment also received a make-over with a touchscreen now available and IntelliLink stepping up its game. Like the other 2016 Buick models, new exterior colors have been added.

The Buick Regal’s name says it all. This car was made for those that have royal tastes but realistic budgets. Starting at just over $27,000, your wallet will not threaten to bite your hand off after this purchase. However, do not let the price tag trick you into thinking you’re missing out on luxury. Coming standard on the Regal are OnStar,cruise control, leather-appointed seating, dual-zone automatic climate control, rearview camera, color touchscreen, and many other features. If you want to step up the class and safety even further, you can purchase packages that include features like lane change alert and adaptive cruise control. For 2016 Buick updated its infotainment system, IntelliLink, which will offer new display screens and more intuitive controls. Also new this year for the Regal are the exterior colors Ebony Twilight Metallic, White Frost Metallic, Crimson Red Tintocat, and Dark Forest Green Metallic. With this car’s classic styling and value and Buick’s recent updates, you and your accountant will be smiling.

Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA): 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS): Good in four areas br> Our favorite standard feature: Rearview camera

You might also be considering: Acura MDX, Infiniti JX, Volvo XC90

The Enclave ranks high in the highly sought after crossover/ sport-utility vehicle category. With Buick’s classic luxury and value and a classic design, this car will satisfy the wants and needs of a wide range of customers. The Enclave can seat either seven or eight depending on your desired configuration, so space is not a concern. The 3.6-lter V-6 delivers a nice hit of power, and a six-speed automatic is the only available transmission. The standard features on this vehicle are geared toward the family. A storage system under the rear floor, power windows, remote starter, and rearview camera all work to make mom or dad’s life just a little bit easier. The options class the Enclave up even further. With a heated wood-trimmed steering wheel and dual moonroof, you will be the envy of even the snootiest country club moms.
New for 2016: OnStar with 4G LTE, Exterior colors: Summit White, Ebony Twilight Metallic, White Frost Tricoat, Standard 19-inch aluminum wheels and optional 19-inch chrome-clad aluminum wheels

The 2016 LaCrosse embodies all that is Buick: luxury at a value price. Starting at just over $31,000, this full-size sedan has all the bells and whistles. Coming standard are a leather-wrapped steering wheel, dual-zone automatic climate control, full-color information center, and remote start. So for those chilly days, you can get the heat flowing before you ever sit foot in your car. The options on this model are geared towards safety. Side blind zone alert, lane change alert, and other camera sensing features come in a package that will allow you to breathe a little easier behind the wheel. There are two engines: a 2.4-liter four-cylinder with eAssist and a 3.6-liter V-6. The one feature that is not explicitly listed but completely changes the game for this vehicle is space. And a lot of it. The LaCrosse provides ample room for family, camping gear, or whatever your heart desires.

subTitle: And my husband thought our 2015 Golf SportWagen TDI’s 50 mpg  was due to his brilliant driving...
promoTeaserSmall: And my husband thought our 2015 Golf SportWagen TDI’s 50 mpg was due to his brilliant driving...
promoTeaser: And my husband thought our 2015 Golf SportWagen TDI’s 50 mpg was due to his brilliant driving...
metaDescription: And my husband thought our 2015 Golf SportWagen TDI’s 50 mpg  was due to his brilliant driving...

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: I have a front-row seat in the unfolding Volkswagen diesel drama.

I not only own a 2015 VW Golf SportWagen TDI, I sold a 2013 VW Jetta SportWagen TDI to a good friend on the East Coast. So, I now realize, we are both out here whooping it up in our mega-mileage VW wagons while spewing pollutants all over our respective woods, fields, and wetlands.

To recap from last Friday’s official EPA news release, the Fed alleges that “four-cylinder VW or Audi diesel cars from model years 2009-2015 include software that circumvents EPA emissions standards for certain air pollutants.” At first blush, it just sounds pathetic. Dig deeper, and it becomes much more cynical and calculating.

The Notice of Violation claims that “a sophisticated software algorithm...detects when the car is undergoing official emissions testing, and turns full emissions controls on only during the test.” The rest of the time, the emissions controls are virtually useless emitting “nitrogen oxides at up to 40 times the standard.”

The emissions defeat device software was discovered when researchers from West Virginia University and the International Council on Clean Transportation raised questions about high emissions levels during independent analysis. EPA and CARB began their own investigation, and in September after they “demanded an explanation for the identified emissions problems," Volkswagen admitted that the cars contained defeat devices.
Appalling, pathetic, cynical, and calculating. And they’ve been caught, the too-clever-by-half cheaters. How embarrassing is this?

Before I get too carried away by the automotive scandal of the month (and too bad for any auto company that had good news breaking this week), I’m going to sit back and see just how much the Wolfsburghers have learned from watching General Motors stumble through its own morass of secrecy, complicity, and cover-up, a nightmare that is far from over, despite a reported tally to date of $2.3 billion in fines, repairs, and lawsuits. Far, far from over.

For VW, every hour seems to bring new revelations, accusations, and questions—not just 500,000 U.S. cars, but as many as 11 million around the world. Not just the 2.0-liter diesel engines, but possibly other VW diesels as well. Who knew what and when? Martin Winterkorn, chairman of the board of management and CEO of VW AG (and oh by the way, also head of VW R&D since 2007) has resigned. Will he be replaced by the U.S. head of Porsche, Matthias Muller? How much will this cost Volkswagen? And, will this be the death knell for the diesel in the U.S.?
I have skin in this game. I’ll be back as news develops with a recap.
Love, Jean

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive mid-size sedan
Trim levels:2.5 (base, S, SR, SV, SL); 3.5 (SR, SL)
Base price: $23,325 (price includes destination charge)
Engine: 2.5-liter four-cylinder, 185 horsepower; 3.5-liter V-6, 270 horsepower
Transmission: Xtronic continuously variable automatic with paddle shifters
Fuel economy: 2.5: 27 mpg city/39 mpg highway; 3.5: 22/32 mpg
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not yet rated; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not yet rated; 2015 model was Top Safety Pick
Competition: Ford Fusion, Honda Accord, Mazda 6, Toyota Camry

“The segment of Altima is the second largest segment in the United States. We today occupy the second position in this segment behind Camry. We passed Accord, thanks to the product attributes and also to the energy of our dealers. Let’s not forget...this is the most sold car for us in the U.S. it’s very important in order to reach our goal of 10 percent market share in the U.S. market.” —Carlos Ghosn

Carlos Ghosn is a bit of a rock star in the automotive world, after reaching out from Renault in 1999 and snatching Nissan back from the brink of death. He became famous for his lack of sleep as he jetted between France, Japan, and the U.S. and for his diminutive stature, outsize ego, and lack of patience for anyone who couldn’t keep up.
This week, he rocked on through the morning news shows in New York City, showing off the new 2016 Nissan Altima, the bread and butter for Renault’s table.

Nissan is calling the Alima a “minor refresh”—actually a public relations spokesman told me it was a major minor refresh—to bring Nissan’s number-one seller here into line, design-wise, with the 2015 Murano and the 2016 Maxima. The revised Altima now bears the sensuous curves of Nissan’s “Energetic Flow” design language and bold Vee grille design. There’s a name for that, too—V-Motion, in Nissan-speak.

The biggest changes include the addition of new safety technologies to its portfolio of existing features, and an upgrade to the Altima’s Xtronic CVT’s performance and feel with the third-generation D-step Shift logic. We’ve tested this CVT on both the Murano and the Maxima and it’s really impressive. Instead of the usual nothingness you feel with most CVT’s the D-step feels like there are real gears in there—especially noticeable from a standing start and when you’re passing slowpokes.

New for 2016 is the SR model, a sportier version available with either four- or six-cylinder engine. It has a sport suspension tuning, a rear spoiler, sporty black-and-blue interior color scheme, a leather-wrapped steering wheel and gear lever, special eighteen-inch aluminum alloy wheels, and smoked headlights. LED lights will be optional on the 2.5 and standard on the 3.5, both coming later in the model year.

Buyers will be interested by the fuel economy of the 2.5-liter model, by far the most popular choice. Getting 39 mpg on the highway puts it at the top of the very competitive mid-size sedan segment. Did I say the Altima was overlooked? Perhaps not so much anymore, with sales up 60 percent since 2009.

The new Altima goes on sale in November.

title: Learning to Shift
subTitle: Confessions of a girl and a manual transmission, in which I take intern Annie, age 19, for a lesson.
promoTeaserSmall: Confessions of a girl and a manual transmission, in which I take intern Annie, age 19, for a lesson.
promoTeaser: Confessions of a girl and a manual transmission, in which I take intern Annie, age 19, for a lesson.
metaDescription: Confessions of a girl and a manual transmission, in which I take intern Annie, age 19, for a lesson.

pageElements.text:
Annie Boniface:

I lift my left foot off the pedal all too carefully, waiting for the correct moment, and slowly engage my right foot, pressing down with control until...griiiind, gurgle, stop. The car lurches to a halt. Press the ignition button, put both feet to the floor. I remove my left foot from the pedal a bit too quickly this time, and before I can even consider doing anything with my right foot, I hear griiiind, gurgle, stop. The car lurches to a halt.

Add Jean asking in the background, “Now what happened there?” or explaining how gears work, or telling me to pretend there’s an egg between my foot and the pedals as I carefully apply pressure, and you have my experience in learning to drive stick.

When it comes to simple tasks, I am a surprisingly slow learner. My dad, a car guy to the bone, cringed in horror when I was learning to drive automatic and couldn’t quite figure out which pedal operated the brake. At the ice cream store where I worked every summer, it took me two weeks before I could make a small cone without coils of vanilla soft serve falling to the floor. Don’t even get me started on basic math.
My inability thus far to maneuver those three pedals and remember when to put the clutch in is not a reflection of your teaching. Truly, it’s not you; it’s me.

What this all amounts to is a note of encouragement to my teacher in the stick shift endeavor. Jean, you are a fabulous instructor with absolute patience, a necessary sense of humor, and clear instructions. My inability thus far to maneuver those three pedals and remember when to put the clutch in is not a reflection of your teaching. Truly, it’s not you; it’s me.

Jean decided to hold this driving lesson in a cemetery, perhaps to totally freak me out. It’s still unclear. Anyway, the roads running through the graveyard were narrow, and only one was paved. One wrong move, and I would take out Grandma Sally’s headstone and Jean’s car's right tire. The  roads created the least of my problems, though, because I would have to successfully move the car forward without stalling to actually hit something.
As Jean put it, there is nothing masculine or feminine about using a drill, changing a tire, or driving manual. And besides, girls who drive stick are cooler.

Despite the resulting carsickness and frustration, learning to drive stick remains an important goal for me. As Jean put it, there is nothing masculine or feminine about using a drill, changing a tire, or driving manual. And besides, girls who drive stick are cooler.

Jean Jennings:

HAHAHAHAHAHA! I wondered what was going on in that head, Annie, as you were lurching along in the family Volkswagen. (Don’t tell my husband.) First off, I chose the cemetery because everyone in there is already dead, although in hindsight, those headstones can be pretty pricey. I admit that I didn’t expect the gravestones to be quite so close on both sides of the narrow lanes. Sorry for that.
All you need to do is slowly let the clutch out (good God, not that slowly) until the car actually starts moving. Then you feed in the gas. Simple. Easy.

So here’s the thing. As I showed you, you don’t even have to touch the gas in first to get the car going. All you need to do is slowly let the clutch out (good God, not that slowly) until the car actually starts moving. Then you feed in the gas. Simple. Easy.

How did you put it? “Griiiind, gurgle, stop." I couldn’t for the life of me figure out how you kept stalling it, but this isn’t a permanent situation. In fact, having gone at it for two long hours in that graveyard, you probably already have the correct procedure embedded in your busy brain’s putamen, ready to present itself the next time you find yourself behind the wheel of a car with three pedals and a stick. Like riding a bike, sis.

Or maybe it’s in your amygdala, which stores all of your most terrifying moments and shuts off the blood to your brain when encountering one of them. HAHAHAHA. Just kidding. Get ready for Round Two. I swear we will go to a big , open parking lot. You’re right, it’s totally worth it because girls who drive sticks are cooler. We can move on to the power tools after that
Love, Jean

You might also be considering: Audi A4, Mercedes-Benz C-Class, Cadillac ATS

If there is one BMW you should be familiar with, the iconic, classic, longtime favorite of enthusiasts 3 Series is it. Available in sedan, wagon, or hatchback form and offering five different engines—including a diesel—and in rear- or all-wheel-drive (xDrive) form, the 3 Series can be molded to your wants and needs. There’s also good news for all of the stick-shifting fanatics out there; you can have a six-speed manual or eight-speed automatic transmission. The 3 Series is highlighting its sportiness even further in 2016 as the Sport Line now comes standard on the Gran Turismo, 328i, 328d, and 340i (xDrive included). Speaking of standard, rain-sensing wipers, automatic headlights, and BMW Assist eCall all come standard. Unfortunately, you’ll have to pay for features like rearview camera, active blind spot alert, and navigation. Owning a 3 Series is an adventure in driving excitement and offers an ability to be in tune with your vehicle that its adepts claim is shared with few other cars out there.
New for 2016: Sport Line is now standard on BMW 3 Series xDrive Gran Turismo, 328i, 328d, 340i (including xDrive); new 340i features new engine, new 330e plug-in hybrid.

subTitle: Poised on the road, and to be redesigned for 2016.

pageElements.text:
Type: SUV/crossover
Price range: $25,195-$42,595 (includes destination)
Trim levels: LX, EX, SX, SX Limited
Engines: 2.4-liter four-cylinder, 191 horsepower; 3.3-liter V-6, 290 horsepower
Transmission: 6-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): 2.4-liter FWD: 20/27; 2.4-liter AWD: 19/25; V-6 FWD: 18/25; V-6 AWD: 18/24 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: Institute for Highway Safety: Top safety pick; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 overall rating
Our favorite standard feature: YES Essentials anti-stain fabric treatment
Notable standard features on this model: Front active headrests, hill start assist, stability control, second-row underfloor cargo storage,
Notable options on this model: All-wheel drive, 19-inch wheels, programmable power liftgate, panoramic sunroof, second-row sliding sunshades, ventilated front seats
You might also be considering: Dodge Journey, Ford Edge, Toyota Highlander

The Sorento is Kia’s answer to the Toyota Highlander and other leading midsize crossovers, and if it were a Jeopardy question it would be the Daily Double. It’s as good looking as any entry in this segment, and it goes down the highway with real poise. It can be loaded up to a fare-thee-well with convenience and luxury features, but even the LX—the lowest trim level—comes standard with some key safety features like stability control, antilock brakes, and active front headrests. Naturally, all-wheel drive is available. The direct-injection, 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine would at first glance seem to be insufficient, but indeed it’s up to the task of propelling this 3594-pound crossover. The direct-injection 3.3-liter V-6 definitely adds muscle, though, and towing capacity rises from 1650 to 3500 pounds. The Sorento is equipped with Flex Steer, which allows the driver to select the steering effort among comfort, normal, and sport modes. Inside, there’s a seven-inch instrument panel display and an eight-inch touchscreen for infotainment. Bluetooth connectivity is standard. Seating splits and folds every which way. The Sorento is tough to overlook because it has the right combination of appearance, performance, technology, and feature content.

New for 2015

There are no changes for 2015.

More about the Kia Sorento

2016 Kia Sorento SX AWD, Should You Buy It? March 20, 2015

title: 6 Coolest Car Experiences in Europe
subTitle: My favorites! Don’t let another year go by without crossing some of these off your bucket list.
promoTeaserSmall: My favorites! Don’t let another year go by without crossing some of these off your bucket list.

pageElements.text: Autumn is a great time to plan a spring or summer trip to Europe, and while you’re planning, make room for one or more of these auto-related adventures. I’ve tried most of them, and I’m here to tell you, you should do likewise. They’re graded from easiest to most challenging.

1. Buy a car from a European carmaker, have a vacation, and then ship it home.

Among potentials: Audi, Volvo, Porsche, BMW, and Mercedes-Benz. You order the car a few months in advance, pick it up at the factory—and get a tour and other perks—drive around Europe, then drop it off at a prearranged dropoff point. Shipping to the U.S. takes a few months; costs and terms vary by automaker. Check individual European delivery programs to be sure what’s included and what’s extra.

2. Visit the massive Schlumpf auto collection in Mulhouse, France.

Located near the Swiss border, the collection was secretly amassed by reclusive brothers who owned a textile factory. It was revealed during fiery protests by underpaid workers living almost like slaves in company housing. It is now called the National Automobile Museum Collection Schlumpf. The secretive Schlumpfs unsuccessfully attempted to find and buy every Bugatti ever made. They managed to procure a rare Bugatti Royale—the Type 41 Coupé Napoléon Royale. Only six Bugatti Royales were produced. This one almost made my brain turn to cottage cheese when I saw it up close.

3. Become a member of the Royal North Cape Club in Nordkapp, Norway.

(I became Royal North Cape Club member #1837 on May 6, 1985.) To get your diploma, drive 1,300 miles from Oslo to Nordkapp, the northernmost point in Europe. Bring companions, a satellite phone, chains, and $18.39 in cold, hard Norwegian kroner (150 of those, to be precise). Wait until early summer. You’ll experience the midnight sun from mid-May until the end of July, which is a lot like the midafternoon sun in Michigan, but with dancing Sami, the reindeer people previously known as Lapps. How do I know this? I danced most of the night sun into the day sun with them.

4. Trace the route of the great Monte Carlo Rally.

Go in winter for extra points. Go slowly. Or maybe just follow the official re-creation, the Rallye Monte-Carlo Historique, from a safe distance! The 2016 event runs from January 27 to February 3.

5. Buy a ticket to drive on the Nürburgring.

The legendary Nürburgring circuit is actually a national road open to the public, except on days when car and tire manufacturers have booked it for product testing. One of the most challenging road courses in the world, the “Green Hell” is the ne plus ultra test of cars trying to claim the ever-changing Fastest Car in the World crown. From April to October, you can hire a performance driver in a 560-horsepower BMW M5 “taxicab” to take you around the seventy-three-corner, 12.9-mile Nordschleife for about $250. Bring a strong stomach.

6. Drive from Liège, Belgium, to Rome and back to Liège as fast as you can.

Then try to figure out how British racing legend Sir Stirling Moss’s sister, Pat Moss, won that particular rally back in 1960 in her Austin-Healey 3000. In 1989, I asked my heroine Pat to race in the Pirelli Classic Marathon with me from London to Cortina D’Ampezzo, Italy, in a vintage Healey 3000, and she said, “That bloody car didn’t kill me back then, old girl, and I’m not going to give it another chance!” Stirling and I ended up doing the Pirelli Classic Marathon in a 1965 MGB, ending third overall and first in class.

title: 2016 Kia Sorento
subTitle: The newest Kia is a master class in mid-size crossover design. Video review from JKC headquarters.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
2016 Kia Sorento SX Limited AWD

Type: Five-passenger, all-wheel-drive mid-size crossover
Trim levels: L, LX, EX, SX, SX Limited, Limited V6
Base price: $42,595 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $45,095
Engine: Turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 240 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic with Sportmatic
Fuel economy: 20 mpg city/27 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick 2015
Competitors (prices include destination charges):
2016 Chevrolet Equinox LTZ AWD ($32,385)
2016 Honda Pilot Touring AWD ($43,700)
2016 Mazda CX-5 Grand Touring AWD ($30,350)
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/cc1AsxDkPX4" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
Fun-O-Meter: 7

There’s nothing that says New! Improved! like, well, a new and improved vehicle. Or an entire new and improved car company. And isn’t it about time we move on with Kia, away from the darkness of the bad, old days of the most affordable, least desirable, throwaway cars on the planet? Because Kia turned the corner on quality, reliability, and desirability an entire decade ago. If you are still looking down your nose at this car company, you haven’t kept up with the news.

It’s not that I don’t understand where the bad vibe came from. Looking for a car for my brother, I used eBay Motors in 2008 to find a super clean 2004 Kia Rio with 48,000 miles on the odometer. As I took delivery, the very sweet business owner handed me the keys and said, “If I have one piece of advice for these disposable cars, it’s change the oil often.” Yes, she said that, and it was good advice, too. I wish she’d also told me that I’d need to change out the timing belt at around 60,000 miles to prevent the engine from exploding.

Despite that dire warning, I would like to say that my brother more than tripled that Rio’s age and mileage over the course of the next three years with no massive repairs. The body was worse for the wear, but he had a heavy hand in hastening its delivery to Charity Motors.

By the time I bought that used Rio, Kia was already turning the corner. In fact, the new Rio was so brilliant, it joined the Optima on Automobile Magazine’s short list of 2012 All-Stars candidates. By then, Kias were well made and pretty fun to drive. More than that, they suddenly looked bold and fresh, a feat delivered seemingly overnight by Kia’s new design boss, former Audi chief designer Peter Schreyer, so impressive that he was a shoo-in for Automobile Magazine’s 2012 Man of the Year.
Kia hasn’t looked back, constantly refining and adding to its lineup of quirky funmobiles, cute utes, and smart-looking sedans, and pushing the envelope upmarket as it goes.

Right here, right now, I am looking at one of the most luscious crossovers in the mid-size class, the 2016 Sorento. Every bit of the exterior has been thoughtfully reshaped, in some areas more than others. Complex headlamp units tuck into a tidy new grille, and pockets for the foglamps are filled in our test car with a grid of four large LED lights.

It had better be as good as it looks, because the completely new 2016 Kia Sorento has revamped its pricing to a level that might take your breath away. If you were straggling in to the Kia dealership with your bag full of pennies, you’d be scurrying right back out. Our test car, the SX Limited AWD, is just a step below the most expensive Sorento. It checks out at $45,095 including destination ($895) and one $2,500 optional Technology package of advanced safety features like forward collision warning, lane departure warning, smart cruise control, and a few extras with them, like a very trick surround-view monitor.

But if you’re a good shopper, you’ll take a closer look with your clipboard in hand, and pull up the exceptional Kia Build & Price configurator on your laptop with its excellent descriptions and images of trim levels and features. The Sorento is available in five-passenger and seven-passenger versions. There is one versatile six-speed automatic transmission and a choice of three engines—a 3.3-liter V-6 and two four-cylinders, including a brand-new, 240-horsepower 2.0-liter turbo, which you can only get with the five-passenger Sorento. If you don’t need all-wheel drive, take $1,800 off the price.

The buying experience is almost a one-price deal, with a long list of great features that are typically extra-cost options on competitors: for example, the gorgeous nappa leather interior trim, which is standard on Limited models. Our test car’s nappa leather trim was maroon, with silvered grey leather seating perforated in a delicate chevron pattern. I had to touch it every time I got in.
Overall, the Sorento offers one of the most luxurious and meticulously detailed interior designs in this segment. It’s also slightly bigger with a second row that splits and folds flat.

The instruments are bright, clear, and gathered in a neat binnacle in front of the driver. There’s a long menu of screens with all the must-have features of the modern luxury vehicle, including an 8.0-inch infotainment screen with voice-activated navigation, app interfaces, and Sirius Traffic. The entire driver interface is exquisitely thought out and executed. Screens are large, crisp, and useful. The rearview camera, standard on all but the base L model, displays a handy live image of what’s behind the Sorento whenever you put the transmission in Reverse. There’s also a “footprint” showing the width of the bumper to really let you get your bearings. It especially came in handy when parallel parking in front of my office in a space about a foot away from an endless stream of semis roaring past. I like to hug the curb without tearing up the wheels, something that is more easily accomplished with the Sorento’s mega camera view.

This is by no means a sport vehicle, although the 2016 model is better to drive thanks to a more rigid structure, high-strength steel, and a stiffer suspension. It’s a luxury vehicle—and one that shines like a diamond.

J.D. Power now ranks Kia second only to Porsche in initial quality. And if that still doesn’t convince you to have a look at the Sorento, there’s still the best powertrain warranty in the business—ten years/10,000 miles—backing it up.
That’s putting your money where your mouth is.

title: 2015 Nissan Xterra
subTitle: Still keeping it simple.
promoTeaserSmall: Still keeping it simple.
promoTeaser: Still keeping it simple.
metaKeywords: 2015 Nissan Xterra; Nissan; sport-utility; SUV; Japanese
metaDescription: Still keeping it simple. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive sport-utility vehicle
Price range: $24,545–$32,525
Trim levels: X, S, Pro-4X
Engine: 4.0-liter V-6, 261 horsepower
Transmissions: Six-speed manual, five-speed automatic
Fuel economy: RWD: 16 mpg city/22 mpg highway mpg; AWD: 15/20 mpg; Manual AWD: 16/20 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Moderate overlap front, Side: Good; Roof strength: Acceptable; Head restraints and seats: Marginal; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Roof rack
Notable standard features on this model: Remote keyless entry, power locks and windows, heavy-duty front suspension, rear leaf springs and solid axle, skid plate, Bluetooth connectivity, air conditioning, cruise control, front-seat active head restraints, 60/40-split rear seats, 6-speaker audio
Notable options on this model: Navigation, premium audio, NissanConnectSM, alloy wheels
You might also be considering: Jeep Renegade, Subaru Forester

Some things are just too complicated, but the Nissan Xterra isn’t one of them. As the Xterra has proved in the past fifteen years, the world always has a place for a rugged, unpretentious compact sport-ute. This is a simple SUV that emphasizes utility and capability and has well conceived details. For example, the rear bumper’s integrated steps help with that reach to the top, where the aluminum roof rack supports up to 150 pounds and is shielded by an air dam. Rear-wheel drive is standard, but if you’re going somewhere with mountain bikes or camping gear, you’ll want the available four-wheel drive. Loading up for adventure is easy with 36.3 cubic feet of cargo capacity with rear seats up and 65.7 cubic seat with rear seats folded; the available Utili-track Cargo Channel system helps you to secure the payload. The Xterra is maneuverable and offers great visibility. While it doesn’t corner too well on the highway, it will crawl over some impressive offroad obstacles. Or it can be like a pair of oxen, towing up to 5,000 pounds. When the dirty work is finished, the Xterra has a wipe-clean interior.

New for 2015

Available NissanConnectSM with Mobile Apps, 5.0-inch display screen, USB port, Bluetooth connectivity, voice-operated text messaging, and satellite radio.

title: 2015 Nissan Versa
subTitle: Subcompact with style.
promoTeaserSmall: Subcompact with style.
promoTeaser: Subcompact with style.
metaKeywords: 2015 Nissan Versa; Nissan; hatchback; sedan; Japanese
metaDescription: Subcompact with style. JeanKnowsCars.co

pageElements.text:
Type: 5-passenger, front-wheel-drive sedan
Price range: $12,800–$17,700 (includes destination)
Trim levels: S, S Plus, SV, SL
Engine: 1.6-liter four-cylinder, 109 horsepower
Transmissions: 5-speed manual, 4-speed automatic, continuously variable
Fuel economy: Manual: 27 mpg city/36 mpg highway; automatic: 26/35 mpg; continuously variable: 31/40 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Small front overlap: Poor; Moderate overlap front, Side, Roof strength, Head restraints and seats: Good; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Bluetooth connectivity
Notable standard features on this model: Air-conditioning, speed-sensitive electrically assisted power steering, 2-speaker audio system, programmable hands-free calling with voice recognition, 15-inch wheels, stability control
Notable options on this model: Continuously variable transmission, smart key with pushbutton start, hands-free voice activation, NissanConnect with Navigation and Mobile Apps, satellite radio, rearview monitor, variable intermittent wipers, 6-way manually adjustable driver’s seat with arm rest, fog lamps, power-adjustable side mirrors, rear spoiler, 16-inch alloy wheels
You might also be considering: Hyundai Accent, Kia Rio, Mitsubishi Lancer

The Nissan Versa demonstrates that cheap doesn’t necessarily mean nasty. Even for less than $13,000—there are whole lot of motorcycles that cost twice as much—the Versa is equipped with a reasonable level of standard equipment, and this year Bluetooth hands-free calling is added to the list. For no extra charge, the Sentra received quite a makeover for 2015. The front now has larger headlamps and a chrome grille that reinforces the subcompact sedan’s relationship to its larger siblings in the Nissan lineup. Blacked-out B-pillars on the Versa SV and SL models improve the profile view, and a new stinger antenna sits on the roof. Nissan says the rear is more dynamic; we note the new taillamps. The body is highly aerodynamic body, and with the available continuously variable automatic transmission the Versa realizes 40 highway mpg, which is better than a whole lot of motorcycles. Inside the car, updates include a reshaped center stack, a multifunction steering wheel, and new upholstery. The more premium SV has an outside temperature display, and the SL comes with a smart key and pushbutton start and rearview monitor. So it’s obvious, the interior is pretty nice, unlike a whole lot of motorcycles.

New for 2015

Hands-free calling with voice recognition, revised front and rear styling, restyled center stack, and available Graphite Blue and Amethyst Gray paint.

title: 2015 Nissan Titan
subTitle: The offbeat alternative.
promoTeaserSmall: The offbeat alternative.
promoTeaser: The offbeat alternative.
metaKeywords: 2015 Nissan Titan; Nissan; truck; pickup; Japanese
metaDescription: The offbeat alternative. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: 5- or 6-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive pickup
Price range: $30,735–$39,265 (includes destination)
Trim levels: S, SV, Pro-4X, SL
Engine: 5.6-liter V-8, 317 horsepower
Transmission: 5-speed automatic
Fuel economy: RWD: 13 mpg city/18 mpg highway; AWD: 12/17 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Moderate overlap front, Head restraints and seats: Good; Roof strength: Acceptable; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Traction and stability control
Notable standard features on this model: Air conditioning, 18-inch wheels, tilt-adjustable steering wheel, 60/40-split fold up rear bench seat, skid plates (4x4), removable locking tailgate, front seat active head restraints, wide-opening rear doors (King cab)
Notable options on this model: Remote keyless entry, 20-inch wheels, overhead center console, sliding back window, tow hitch receiver and trailer brake prewiring, Bluetooth connectivity, premium audio, heated front seats, leather-trimmed seats
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Silverado, Ford F-150, Toyota Tundra

The Nissan Titan has always been a great-looking pickup. Its face is bold but not outrageous, and the body design incorporates a few swoops and flares. Even though the 2015 Titan closes out the product cycle and an all-new Titan is in the offing, the original’s good looks are holding up just fine. The Titan is offered in extended King Cab or Crew Cab body styles with rear- or available 4-wheel drive. Boasting the largest standard engine among full-size pickups, this workhorse will tow up to 9,500 pounds. It includes traction control and stability control for surefire hill climbing and cornering on slick roads. The locking removable tailgate is a nifty standard feature, and the available locking bedside storage compartment and Utili-track cargo carrying system enhance the cargo box’s usefulness. Inside its cab, the Titan masters the pickup category’s mobile office requirements; the center-console’s workstation is as versatile and convenient as they come, and the front passenger seat folds flat for what serves as a desk. In back of either King or Crew Cab, the 60/40-split rear seats flip up to provide extra cargo space. The SV Value package puts the Titan on 20-inch wheels, hangs step rails on the cab, and places captain’s chairs in the front row. Then it piles on the infotainment and connectivity features. The PRO-4X girds the Titan for rock-busting duty, adding a transfer case skid plates, and high-performance shock absorbers. For all its virtues, though, the Titan runs far behind the pack in fuel economy, so be prepared to frequent the pump.

New for 2015

Revised interior trim, available power-adjustable driver’s seat lumbar support, new 20-inch alloy wheels, and two new exterior paint colors: Arctic Metallic blue and Magnetic black paint.

Type: 5- or 7-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive SUV/crossover
Price range: Rogue Select: $21,035; Rogue: $23,925–$30,515 (including destination)
Trim levels: S, SV, SL, Rogue Select S
Engine: 2.5-liter four cylinder, 170 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable
Fuel economy: Rogue: FWD: 26 mpg city/33 mpg highway; AWD: 25/32 mpg
Rogue Select: FWD: 23/28 mpg; AWD: 22/27 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Rearview camera
Notable standard features on this model: Satellite radio, NissanConnect with Mobile Apps, LED daytime running lights, power windows with driver’s auto up/down, 5.0-inch display screen, power locks, air conditioning, iPod port, Bluetooth connectivity, hands-free texting
Notable options on this model: Three-row seating, 360-degree monitor with moving object detection, blind-spot warning, lane-departure warning, forward collision warning, 18-inch wheels, LED headlamps, fog lamps, roof rails, heated side mirrors, power liftgate, panoramic roof, dual-zone climate control, 7.0-inch touchscreen
You might also be considering: Ford Escape, Honda CR-V, Mitsubishi Outlander

The Nissan Rogue is a front- or all-wheel-drive crossover utility vehicle with a strong emphasis on interior versatility. It seats up to seven people with the available third-row bench, and the flexible interior layout provides up to 70.0 cubic feet of cargo space. Long pieces of cargo will fit, thanks to the flat-folding front seat folds flat. Wide-opening rear doors admit passengers to the back seats, the second row slides 9.0 inches and also reclines, and there are plenty of storage pockets. Comfort is a priority for front-seat occupants, as well, and the Rogue is available with advanced seat heaters that quickly warm the most strategic parts of the seat. The Rogue was all-new in 2014, and its advanced structural design leads to excellent safety ratings. It is available with a suite of contemporary driver assistance features, including 360-degree surround view, a class exclusive. Another point of pride is the excellent fuel economy. Under the hood, the 2.5-liter four-cylinder makes 170 horsepower, and paired with a continuously variable transmission—a competent and highly efficient powertrain. But because of the CVT, towing capacity is limited to just 1000 pounds. While being conventional in design, the Rogue is nicely detailed inside and out. Nissan still offers the previous-generation model as the Rogue Select S, a well-equipped value package that has an appealing $21,035 price tag (includes destination).

New for 2015

Standard satellite radio, NissanConnect with Mobile Apps connectivity, available Eco mode, heated cloth seats, new colors: Arctic Blue, Pearl White, Glacier White.

subTitle: Life on the upswing.
promoTeaserSmall: Life on the upswing.
promoTeaser: Life on the upswing.
metaDescription: Life on the upswing. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: 5-passenger, front-wheel-drive sedan
Price range: $17,305–$21,495
Trim levels: S, FE+ S, SV, SR, SL
Engine: 1.8-liter four-cylinder, 130 horsepower
Transmission: 6-speed manual, continuously variable
Fuel economy: Manual: 27 mpg city/36 mpg highway; automatic: 29/39 mpg; FE+ S: 30/40 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Automatic headlights
Notable standard features on this model: Bluetooth connectivity with hands-free calling, cruise control, multifunction steering wheel, LED front accents, LED taillights, automatic headlamps, air conditioning, USB port, remote keyless entry, electroluminescent gauges, 6-way manual driver’s seat, 4-speaker audio system, 60/40 split folding rear seats, power windows with driver’s one-touch operation
Notable options on this model: NissanConnect with Mobile Apps, 5.0-inch display, Bose stereo, smart key with pushbutton start, rearview camera, leather upholstery, leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift knob, dual-zone climate control, heated front seats and mirrors, rear-seat heat vents
You might also be considering: Ford Focus, Honda Civic, Hyundai Elantra

From its chrome grille to the chrome accent on the trunk lid, the Nissan Sentra indicates the intention to be premium. From its chrome grille, along the undulating character line, to the LED-accented tail lamps, this five-seat sedan strives to be exceptional. Inside the airy cabin, the instrument panel’s contours sweep into the doors, and the roof arcs gracefully. No one will every call the Sentra “boxy” again! As with other Nissan models, the body is aerodynamically efficient, and excellent fuel economy is the payoff, especially in the Sentra FE+ S, which incorporates underbody deflectors, a rear spoiler, and low rolling resistance tires to achieve 40 highway mpg. The 1.8-liter four-cylinder produces 130 horsepower, which is adequate if not exciting, and is paired with either a 6-speed manual transmission or a continuously variable automatic. The Sentra SV is loaded with infotainment and convenience features and now offers a Style Package that includes a power-operated sunroof, unique 16-inch alloy wheels, and a rear spoiler. Heated front seats and heated side mirrors are available for buyers in less than toasty climes. The sporty Sentra SR shares those features, adds rear disc brakes and a smart key before offering available leather upholstery and a premium audio system. This is the seventh-generation Sentra. Having followed its progress all along, we can’t help but marvel at how good it’s become.

New for 2015

Standard USB port, Bluetooth connectivity, USB port provides interface for iPod, multifunction steering wheel, automatic headlamps, cruise control, and four new colors (Titanium, Cayenne Red, Fresh Powder, Red Alert).

subTitle: The design edge.
promoTeaserSmall: The design edge.
promoTeaser: The design edge.
metaKeywords: 2015 Nissan Quest; Nissan; minivan; van; Japanese
metaDescription: The design edge. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: 7-passenger, front-wheel-drive minivan
Price range: $27,415–$44,065
Trim levels: S, SV, SL, Platinum
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 260 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable
Fuel economy: 20 mpg city/27 mpg highway
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Small overlap front: Poor; Moderate overlap front, Side, Head restraints and seats: Good; Roof strength: Acceptable; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Smart keyless entry with pushbutton start
Notable standard features on this model: Fold-flat second and third rows, rear storage well, rear spoiler
Notable options on this model: Roof rack, towing package, hatch tent, 18-inch wheels, tinted glass, HID headlamps, dual sunroof, power sliding side doors, 5-, 7-, or 8-inch color audio display, blind spot warning, rearview camera, 360-degree view with moving object detection
You might also be considering: Dodge Caravan, Honda Odyssey, Toyota Sienna

Distinctive, modern styling makes the Nissan Quest stand out from the crowd. Under a firm canopy that ends with a jabbing spoiler, there’s a wraparound expanse of tinted glass that makes this minivan an observation platform. A character line rises boldly along the flank to meet the tail lamp. While the visual drama rises, Nissan boasts a low step-in height to the seven-passenger cabin. The occupants are well outfitted with safety features, including side-curtain airbags and stability and traction control, and accouterments like standard second- and third-row climate controls and an available rear entertainment system with 11-inch screen. The versatility of second-row seats is exemplary. Sliding, reclining, and then folding flat with one pull are hallmarks of the second row. The 60/40 third row flattens out with one tug of a strap or, in the Quest Platinum, the push of a button. The rear storage well is a Quest feature. Over-the-road performance is respectable thanks to the 260-horsepower V-6 and continuously variable transmission, which enables towing of up to 3,500 pounds. Amenities include Nissan’s Quick Comfort front seat heaters that initially warm thigh and hip areas before spreading heating to other points. (Naming this feature “The Bum’s Rush” seemed a bad idea.) And Quest boasts a hatch tent. This dealer-installed option connects a roomy a screen tent to the rear hatch for insect-free tailgating.

New for 2015

Quest LE is now Quest Platinum, revised transmission settings, and improved fuel economy.

promoTeaser: Excellence in the long haul.

metaDescription: Excellence in the long haul. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: 7-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive SUV
Price range: $30,395–$43,985 (includes destination)
Trim levels: S, SV, SL, SL Tech, SL Premium, Platinum
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 260 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable
Fuel economy: FWD: 20 mpg city/27 mpg highway mpg; AWD: 19/26 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Customizable driver information display
Notable standard features on this model: Independent rear suspension, hill-start assist, hill-descent control (with four-wheel drive), three-zone automatic climate control, EZ Flex Seating with Latch and Glide, pushbutton start, cargo area under-floor storage, roof rails
Notable options on this model: All-wheel drive, 20-inch wheels, panoramic roof, heated and cooled front seats, heated steering wheel, power-adjustable steering wheel, 360-degree surround view, voice-controlled navigation, 13-speaker audio system, second-row 120-volt outlet, blind-spot warning, rear cross-traffic alert, traction and stability control, dual-screen rear entertainment package
You might also be considering: Ford Explorer, Honda Pilot, Subaru Outback

Whereas the Nissan Pathfinder always used to look chunky and trucklike, the present version, redesigned in 2013, is sleek and refined. The twin-bar grille says it’s a Nissan, the fenders swell and taper, but the larger emphasis shifts toward the interior and the mechanical specification of this seven-passenger vehicle. Convenience, comfort, and capability are the Pathfinder’s hallmarks. It is available as a rear- or all-wheel-drive vehicle; for 2015, hill-descent control is included with the latter. A competent V-6 engine provides the power, and all Pathfinders now have an enhanced continuously variable transmission that makes less fuss while enabling the return of as much as 27 highway mpg. The advanced four-wheel drive knows when and for how long to engage all four wheels, a fuel saving feature. The Pathfinder seats seven and tows up to 5,000 pounds. Interior flexibility is improved for 2015 by the standard Latch and Glide feature, an industry first, which allows either second-row seat to tilt and glide forward without removing a child safety seat. The available rear entertainment system has dual 7.0-inch screens integrated into the front seatbacks. Even the third-row occupants can recline their seatbacks and enjoy the show. The Pathfinder continues to take big steps away from its origin long ago as a converted pickup to a highly contemporary family limo

New for 2015

Available blind-spot warning and rear cross-traffic alert, hill-descent control on all-wheel-drive models, improved transmission, rear entertainment package, increased feature content in SV and SL trims, and six new exterior colors.

title: 2015 Nissan NV200 Compact Cargo
subTitle: Fulfilling a purpose.
promoTeaserSmall: Fulfilling a purpose.
promoTeaser: Fulfilling a purpose.
metaKeywords: 2015 Nissan NV200 Compact Cargo; Nissan; work van; van; passenger van; Japanese
metaDescription: Fulfilling a purpose. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: 2-passenger, front-wheel-drive cargo van
Price range: $21,580–$22,570 (includes destination)
Trim levels: S, SV
Engine: 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 131 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable
Fuel economy: 24 mpg city/26 mpg highway
Safety ratings: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Power windows with auto up/down
Notable standard features on this model: Six-way adjustable driver’s seat with armrest, front-door map pockets, “mobile office” center console
Notable options on this model: Bluetooth connectivity, satellite radio, rearview camera, navigation, hands-free texting
You might also be considering: Dodge Caravan Cargo, Ford Transit Connect, Ram ProMaster City

Intended for business owners who want a smaller, more efficient van, the NV200 Compact Cargo provides great forward visibility and proceeds nimbly through city traffic. It has a 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine and new continuously variable transmission, so fuel economy improves to 24 city mpg. Yet cargo capacity is impressive: 122.7 cubic feet. The cargo bay accepts a 40-by-48-inch pallet between the wheel wells, and a seven-foot-tall person could lie down in the cargo area (although he’d have to bend his neck a little to fit). The rear doors are split 60/40, with the smaller door opening to the traffic side of the street; both doors open to 180 degrees, resting flush against the van’s sides. The dual sliding side doors are solid for the company’s logo, but glass is available in all rear doors. Inside, standard cargo mounting points enable attachment of shelves, and six available floor-mounted cargo hooks help to keep things in place. Roof rack mounting points are standard. Inside, the driver will take advantage of Nissan’s “mobile office” center console, which stores a laptop or hanging file folders as well as the necessities one requires when spending long days in the vehicle. The front passenger seat slides 9.5 inches to extend cargo space, and the seat back folds flat to serve as a desk or picnic table. The hawkish appearance reflects an uncompromised approach to functionality, which is also in evidence in the NV200 Taxi, and maybe after we’ve gaped for a few more years we will learn to appreciate it.

New for 2015

Warranty coverage increases to 5 years/100,000 miles, new continuously variable automatic transmission, available sliding door glass package, updated infotainment, and two new paint colors: Cayenne Red and Graphite Blue.

title: 2015 Nissan NV
subTitle: Looks don’t kill.
promoTeaserSmall: Looks don’t kill.
promoTeaser: Looks don’t kill.
metaKeywords: 2015 Nissan NV; Nissan; cargo van; van; wagon; Japanese
metaDescription: Looks don’t kill. JeanKnowsCars.com

Trim levels: Passenger HD S, Passenger HD SV, Passenger HD SL, 1500 Cargo, 2500 HD Cargo, 3500 HD Cargo

Transmission: 5-speed automatic
Fuel economy: N/A

Notable standard features on this model: Dual-zone climate control, durable upholstery, heated tow mirrors, 17-inch wheels
Notable options on this model: Fog lamps, leather-appointed seats, leather-wrapped steering wheel, 8-way power driver’s seat, heated front seats
You might also be considering: Ford Transit, Ram ProMaster, Mercedes-Benz Sprinter

Nissan says “rugged and professional” design. You might say, “The van with the large forehead.” The Nissan NV is distinctive and purposeful, a fully modern entry in the full-size van category. It is available in Passenger and Cargo models, each of which is well conceived. They come with either V-6 or V-8 power and a 5-speed automatic transmission. The Passenger van has a 41.7-inch side opening and seats up to 12 occupants in four rows. The three rows to the aft have split benches, and the individual sections can be removed and repositioned. Nissan claims 324 different configurations. Each seating position has its own headrest and an integrated seatbelt, so there’s no “seatbelt jungle” that anyone who’s climbed onto an airport or hotel shuttle is familiar with. Rear passenger comfort is ensured, thanks to dual rotating overhead A/C vents and available reading lamps in each row. Heat vents are built into the floor.

After taking advantage of the cheaper-by-the-dozen offer at the drive-in, everyone will be happy to find that cupholders slide out from beneath the seat cushion. Up front, there are dual-zone climate controls and available heated seats. The infotainment system now incorporates a text-to-voice feature. Productivity is enhanced by the same central “mobile office” center console unit familiar from the Titan pickup. The van’s available rearview camera seems like an essential feature. Standing even taller beside the Passenger version, the NV Cargo is available in 1500, HD 2500, and HD 3500 grades and, like its sibling, S, SV, and SL trim. High-roof variants are available. The Cargo takes advantage of the same wide-opening rear doors, available third-row 12-volt outlet and cargo-area 120-volt outlet to run devices, tools, or accessories. The Passenger van tows up to 8,700 pounds, and the Cargo van up to 9,500 pounds. A 5-year, 100,00-mile warranty is extended to both versions.

New for 2015

Updated infotainment with 5.8-inch display, voice recognition for audio and navigation, hands free calling and texting. Arctic Blue Metallic brings the number of available colors to six.

You might also be considering: Ford Edge, Hyundai Santa Fe Sport, Jeep Grand Cherokee, Toyota Venza

The Nissan Murano is totally different from almost anything in its price range. It compares to the more expensive Land Rover Range Rover Sport and BMW’s multi-activity vehicles. But it is an entity unto itself: streamlined, dramatic, and futuristic. While it combines style and luxury with a strong strain of sportiness, there’s also the functionality of a five-seat crossover utility vehicle with 69.9 cubic feet of cargo room. (The available power-folding rear seat is a nice feature.) Nissan’s smart all-wheel drive system is available with each trim level. A sufficiently powerful V-6 engine pairs up with a continuously variable automatic transmission that simulates a conventional gearbox’s shifting steps. And when it’s hitched to a 1500-pound utility trailer, the Murano might look like Goldilocks with a granny shopping cart, but it’ll do the job. Standard LED daytime running lights and “boomerang”-style tail lamps (originally introduced on Nissan 370Z) add flair. Inside, the experience is intended to be lounge-like, with an open center console making conversation easy between front and back rows. And the driver has an excellent outward view over the low, uncluttered instrument panel and dashboard. The Cashmere upholstery—cloth in the Murano S or SV, leather in the SL and Platinum—is something to behold. With the standard and available connectivity, convenience, infotainment, and safety features, the Murano will continue to be in a class by itself.

New for 2015

The third-generation Murano is all new this year.

Production of the 2014 Nissan Maxima was extended unchanged for continued availability into model year 2015, and a few examples remained in dealer inventories into early summer. The 2014 Maxima may be an older car at the end of its product cycle, but no one would call it unsophisticated. It has a powerful V-6 engine, a continuously variable transmission with manual and sport modes and available paddle shifters, and a suspension with braced front strut towers and a multilink rear to nearly match European sport sedans. Of course, the Maxima doesn’t cost as much.

The ’15 Maxima is actually .9-inch shorter than the Altima, which is a newer car. Its 3.5-liter V-6 puts out 20 more horsepower than the same engine as offered in the Altima. The Maxima has plenty of premium accouterments in the S and SV trims, but it gets more interesting with the available Sport (19-inch wheels, tuned suspension, reinforced rear chassis) and Premium (power rear sunshade, leather upholstery, rear bucket seats) packages. If you can live without the latest infotainment and safety technologies, you’ll always love driving the Maxima.

New for 2015

There are no new features for 2015.

You might also be considering: Ford Focus ST, Kia Soul, Scion xB

As one of the most delightfully strange vehicles offered by any manufacturer, the Nissan Juke makes you forget there was ever a day when people fretted about all cars looking alike. (It was about 10 years ago.) The Juke’s unusual face and profile eventually work their charms, and then you’re won over by subtle details like the rear door handles, which are integrated into the doorframe. Standing tall on large wheels, this little hotrod is playful and insouciant. And then there’s the driving experience. The Juke punches above its weight with a direct-injection, turbocharged 1.6-liter four-cylinder engine, revised this year for better fuel economy, improved responsiveness, and lower emissions. It’s paired with a continuously variable transmission with a sport mode. Not only does the Juke bustle right down the road, but it also gives a Bronx cheer when passing gas stations. This five-seater is a front-wheel-drive vehicle with available all-wheel drive and up to 35.9 cubic feet of cargo space. The Juke S is well equipped with desirable feature content: connectivity and audio are strong points. The upmarket models add such items as a sunroof, leather, premium audio, and a 360-degree view. And you still haven’t spent a lot of money! The Nismo, names for Nissan’s motorsports arm rides on 18-inch wheels and a tuned suspension, and the Nismo RS is further endowed with a punchier 215 or 211 horsepower four—front- or all-wheel-drive models, respectively—stronger brakes, a braced chassis, and Recaro front bucket seats, taking the Juke into territory that’s not really shared with any other vehicle.

New for 2015

Projector-headlamps with LED Accents, revised engine, standard smart key with pushbutton start, standard Bluetooth connectivity and hands-free texting, new colors: Solar Yellow, Cosmic Blue, Super Black.

Fuel economy: 16 mpg city/23 mpg highway
Safety ratings: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: Active noise cancellation
Notable standard features on this model: Navigation, Bluetooth connectivity, configurable multifunction display, rearview camera, smart key with pushbutton start, leather upholstery with suede inserts, leather-wrapped steering multifunction steering wheel, heated front seats, all-wheel drive, 20-inch wheels, 11-speaker audio system
Notable options on this model: Titanium exhaust system, cold weather package, ivory or red amber premium interior
You might also be considering: BMW M, Chevrolet Corvette Z06, Porsche 911

A cult car, rare and expensive, the 2015 Nissan GT-R is the result of great engineers and designers obsessing over every conceivable detail. Consider just a few examples. The stereo speakers are mounted in die-cast aluminum frames. Rather than iron sleeves, the V-6 engine’s cylinder bores have low-friction plasma coatings. The engine cover is a work of art, suitable for framing. This year, much attention was given to retuning the suspension components and brakes with the goal of better drivability around town. Who knows? The lucky owner of a GT-R might utilize the 8.8 cubic feet of cargo capacity for a trip to Costco. Additional sound deadening measures have also been taken, and active noise cancellation counteracts booming from the twin-turbo V-6, which produces 545-horsepower (600-horsepower in the GT-R Nismo). Being capable of 196 mph, the GT-R boasts one of the most aero-efficient bodies (0.26 cd) thanks in part to the carefully designed rear spoiler and undertrays, and now the GT-R Black Edition features a handmade, specially coated carbon-fiber spoiler. For that shopping trip, the driver might tame the GT-R with the 6-speed dual-clutch gearbox’s Normal or Save mode, and wait to use the paddle shifters and rev matching when R-Mode is engaged on track day. New for 2015 and typical of the obsessive details we mentioned, the available Regal Red body color blends 24-karat gold-coated glass flakes into the paint. And the Ivory Premium Package interior covers the seats in hand-stitched, semi-aniline leather, which is also applied on the instrument panel, steering wheel, and shift knob. The GT-R Black Edition has a red-and-black interior with leather-covered Recaro front bucket seats. Now get in and drive—stop obsessing!

New for 2015

Recalibrated suspension and brakes, active noise cancellation, carbon-style instrument cluster, new tire compound and tread pattern, LED headlamps, and a new paint color: Regal Red.
