From modest to macho, the Nissan Frontier presents many aspects in the compact truck segment. It goes about its duties with an agreeable expression and willingness to perform. The most basic Frontier S is offered in extended King Cab configuration with a 6-foot-one-inch bed and rear-wheel drive; a four-cylinder engine and 6-speed manual transmission are included. On the other hand, the four-wheel-drive Desert Runner has a more capable suspension, aggressive-looking alloy wheels, and a trendy decal. The basic S comes with antilock brakes and forward-facing rear seats that flip up to provide interior cargo space. A 5-speed automatic transmission is available in place of the manual. The SV and Desert Runner are offered in King or Crew Cab, and the SL is Crew Cab only. The list of features and amenities grows longer as the truck itself does: The SL Crew Cab stretches to 219.4 in length and the price tag stretches close to $40,000 when options like the sunroof and various accessories are thrown in. (Among the latter, our favorite is the $260 bed tent, a nylon dome with a pole-supported awning that puts real “bedtime” into effect. Debonaire, muscular, and sturdy, the Frontier does something for everybody who doesn’t need a full-size pickup.

New for 2015

Sunroof standard on Frontier SL long-wheelbase, NissanConnect with Mobile Apps and 5.0-inch display standard with SV and Desert Runner, Arctic Blue Metallic color.

You might also be considering: BMW i3, Chevrolet Volt, Toyota Prius

A friend recently traded his first-generation Nissan Leaf for the second-generation model that was introduced two years ago, so we asked him to describe the electric car’s virtues. He says, “The new Leaf is basically maintenance free and easy to live with. There’s quick acceleration at traffic speeds with no pesky downshifting. It has much better charging (faster) than the first generation, and the heat is much more efficient.” The Leaf seats five and, with the 60/40 split rear seat folded, up to 30 cubic-feet of cargo space. With an 84-mile range, the Leaf is effective as a commuter vehicle. It operates quietly. After applying benefits like tax incentives and access to the freeway’s diamond lane, the Leaf is less expensive, with greater added value, than you might think, especially because it never visits the gas pump. A quick-charge port allows recharging the lithium-ion battery pack to 80-percent level in 30 minutes with a fast charger. Only five hours is needed to achieve a full charge. In addition to being quiet to drive, the Leaf has a high level of standard. There’s a smart key with pushbutton start, a heated multifunction steering wheel and heated front and rear seats, and a rearview camera. Three driving modes are included: Normal, Eco-Mode, B-Mode, which has stronger regenerative braking capability to generate current. One other tip from our friend: the top-of-the-line SL with all the goodies can be a great deal because most buyers are frugal and economical.

New for 2015

Morning Sky Blue paint, hands free texting in SV and SL, new 17-inch alloy wheels for SV trim.

Designed for the person (and family) with a busy life, the Nissan Armada is appointed with many thoughtful conveniences and welcome luxuries while offering outstanding capacity and capability. With its panoply of ports, screens, and pockets, the Armada readily supports a changing cast of characters during its hours of daily use. The mighty V-8 engine responds enthusiastically in traffic and enables the Armada to tow up to 9,000 pounds. The refined and sophisticated mechanical systems keep this 207.7-inch-long bruiser alert, on its toes, and level under a load. Seating for eight is standard, but the buyer can opt for second-row captain’s chairs, eliminating one position but increasing comfort. Fabric seat coverings are standard, but the Platinum Reserve package introduces premium, two-tone leather. As the name might lead one to expect, there’s a complement of standard and available safety and security features, including active front head restraints and a front sonar system. A power liftgate and power-fold third-row bench aid access to the rear. Among full-size SUVs, the Armada breaks out of the box with a sweeping roofline and sculpted sides creating a fuselage effect. The friendly face indicates strength and suggests the Armada is an alternative among full-size SUVs and may be the right choice.

New for 2015

Revised interior trim, standard power-adjustable driver’s seat lumbar support, new 20-inch alloy wheels, and Arctic Metallic blue and Magnetic black paint.

You might also be considering: Ford Fusion, Honda Accord, Kia Optima, Toyota Camry

Outstanding aerodynamic design and classy details characterize the midsize Nissan Altima. This five-passenger sedan is Nissan’s bestseller, and we know why. It combines good performance—including an athletic ride, thanks to premium shock absorbers—with great fuel economy and high feature content. For example, every Altima has scientifically developed “Zero Gravity” front seats to reduce fatigue, so there’s no “claim to lame.” There’s also a customizable 4.0-inch driver information display that relates audio system or fuel economy data, among other topics. The interior, where quietness is emphasized, is a pleasant, well-designed place with tasteful colors, fabrics, textures, and finishes. The standard 4-speaker sound system can be upgraded to the premium 9-speaker one. Standard Bluetooth connectivity enables hands-free calling and wireless streaming from your smartphone. The popular Altima SV comes with dual-zone climate control, hands-free texting, and leather-wrapped multifunction steering wheel. Sophisticated active safety technology is available, with blind-spot and lane-departure warning and moving object detection being bundled with the available Technology Package. The newly available active understeer control lightly brakes the inside front wheel as needed for more effective turning. Under the hood is either a 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine or a 3.5-liter V-6, and every model has a continuously variable automatic transmission. The 3.5 SL has paddle shifters with a manual shift mode.

New for 2015

Additional standard infotainment, safety technologies, and improved fuel economy for the 3.5 SL, smart climate control for cars equipped with remote start, Special Edition package includes convenience and infotainment features.

The Nissan 370Z represents a sports car bargain, and that’s always been the case since its 240Z predecessor appeared 45 years ago. It has a sports car’s classis front-engine, rear-wheel-drive layout. With a short 100.4-inch wheelbase and overall length of just 167.5 inches, you know it will get through the cones at your local autocross course. The 370Z has a highly aerodynamic body—the Sport and Sport Tech trim levels most of all. To keep down overall weight, aluminum is used in the hood, doors, and rear hatch. Power comes from a 3.7-liter V-6, which makes 332 horsepower (350 horsepower in the 370Z Nismo). The standard 6-speed manual gearbox can be ordered with a feature that blips the throttle for smooth downshifts. The available 7-speed automatic comes with a similar feature. While even the base model has great brakes, the 370Z Nismo has even more powerful ones to go with a specially braced and tuned suspension and viscous limited-slip differential for that extra edge in handling. The 370Z Roadster has a power-operated, fully automatic top in black or Bordeaux with a fabric liner and glass rear window with integrated defroster. This year’s new 370Z Touring Sport Roadster is equipped with some of the Nismo’s components for give it an edge over its competitors, of which there are few.

New for 2015

370Z Sport, 370Z Sport Tech, and 370Z Touring Sport Roadster join the model lineup, revised suspension tuning, and navigation is now standard on 370Z Touring.

Engine: 2.5-liter four-cylinder, 185 horsepower; 3.5-liter V-6, 270 horsepower
Transmission: Xtronic continuously variable automatic with paddle shifters
Fuel economy: 2.5: 27 mpg city/39 mpg highway; 3.5: 22/32 mpg
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not yet rated; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not yet rated; 2015 model was Top Safety Pick
Competition: Ford Fusion, Honda Accord, Mazda 6, Toyota Camry

The Nissan Altima is only one of a huge number of competitors in the popular mid-size sedan segment. Faced with so many other choices, a shopper would do well to wonder, what is so special about the Altima? Nissan answered that question by updating the look and performance of the Altima for 2016—and by adding a new SR model that's sportier both in look and feel.

The Altima now looks more like the flowing designs you see in the Murano and the Maxima. The change is particularly noticeable on the front end, with a V-shaped grille and new headlamps; LED lights are an available option. Inside, the interior also echoes the look of the Murano and Maxima with a redesigned center console and information display. The standard infotainment screen is 5.0 inches and includes Siri Eyes Free hands-free voice command technology on all but the base 2.5 model, but there's an optional 7.0-inch touchscreen infotainment screen with voice recognition, 3D-effect maps, and navigation; that comes on the 2.5 SV and SL and the 3.5 SL. The optional Nissan Connect with Mobile Apps offers hands-free text messaging and steering-wheel-mounted text commands (that say such things as "driving, can't text").

Safety technology is one good reason to buy a new car these days, and the Altima gets a new option that other mid-size sedans don't have (yet): predictive forward collision warning, which senses the velocity and distance of vehicles two cars ahead. There's also blind spot warning (standard on SV and SL models), intelligent cruise control and forward emergency braking (both part of the optional SL Tech package), and rear cross-traffic alert.

As their names suggest, the Altima 2.5 models have a 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine, while the 3.5 models get a 3.5-liter V-6. The new-for-2016 Altima SR can be had with either engine and additionally gets eighteen-inch wheels and tires, a suspension stiffened and tuned for a sportier feel, and a set of paddle shifters for more fun.

Nissan proudly cites a strong upward trend in sales of the Altima, which is now number two in sales behind only the Toyota Camry. If you've overlooked this car in the past, you're increasingly in the minority these days.
New for 2016: The Altima has been redesigned for 2016; new sportier SR model available in both 2.5-liter four-cylinder and 3.5-liter V-6 versions.

More to Read:

2016 Nissan Altima Rolls Out, by Jean Jennings

images.caption: New for 2016: Sportier Nissan Altima SR.

title: 5 Cool Things about Tesla's Model X
subTitle: The long-awaited electric crossover  will go on sale in late 2016.
promoTitle: 5 Cool Things about Tesla's Model X
promoTeaserSmall: The long-awaited electric crossover will go on sale in late 2016.
promoTeaser: The long-awaited electric crossover will go on sale in late 2016.
keywords: 5 Cool Things about Tesla's Model X
metaTitle: 5 Cool Things about Tesla's Model X - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: The long-awaited electric crossover will go on sale in late 2016.

pageElements.text: There are naysayers about Tesla, the car company that wants to do everything differently, but we are not among them. Definitely an oddball, Elon Musk is a creative oddball, and you can’t argue that he has just come up with another fascinating model that takes us further down the road to making the electric car look truly desirable.

Musk says the point of his car company is “to accelerate the advent of sustainable transport.”  Part of that mission is to show that any type of vehicle can be electric, which Tesla Motors has shown with its roadster and sedan—both critical and popular hits. Next up: the SUV, so here is the Model X. People want versatility, three rows of seats, towing capability, and spaciousness. Musk’s plan is to make that a sustainable choice, and who can argue with that?

Prices haven’t been announced yet, but Elon Musk said this week that it will start only $5,000 higher than the Model S, which is currently priced at $76,200 before tax incentives. “Lower-cost versions coming later,” he added in a tweet.
Here are five cool things to know about the 2017 Tesla Model X while waiting for its on-sale date in late 2016.

1. It seats seven and has the “utility” that a sport-utility vehicle requires. It also tows up to 5,000 pounds while carrying seven people and their gear. In that, even though it doesn’t look much like one, it’s a real utility vehicle. There is an accessory bike hitch that can be put on in seconds and carries up to four bicycles while allowing full access to the trunk area.

2. It has cool falcon-wing doors. Guess what inspired them? Not sci-fi, but the fact that Musk has a set of twins and a set of triplets, so he knows about the hassle of car seat wrangling. (Not that anyone thinks he installs them himself, of course.) Access to the second row is simplified with the doors up above the vehicle, and the second-row seats are quick to slide for full access to the third row of seats. Better still: The car has ultrasonic sensors in the roof that automatically compute the height of the ceiling and any obstacles to the side, so you don’t bark the tops against the garage walls.
While we’re talking about cool doors, the front doors detect your presence and open for you, then close for you once you’re seated in the Model X. An “invisible chauffeur,” as Musk described it.

3. More to the point, there are 257 miles of range between charges, and an indecent amount of speed. With all-wheel drive and that kind of range, you can still reach a top speed of 155 mph and go from 0 to 60 mph in 4.8 seconds. But the P90D model has Ludicrous mode, with which you get 250 miles of range and 0 to 60 mph in 3.2 seconds (“so fast it’s wrong,” Musk said).

4. The interior air quality is comparable to a hospital’s operating room. We tweeted this week about the frankly huge air filter and the Bioweapon Defense Mode setting, which gives you a completely protective interior environment in case of, you know, some kind of WMD attack. In the absence of that, you can enjoy the fact that the Model X cuts virus, bacteria, pollen, and pollution levels down to practically unmeasurable levels. And you actually are going to run into those in your travels. Our only question: How much is it going to cost to replace that immense air filter, and how often do you have to?

5. With five-star ratings in every category, it’s tipped as the safest SUV ever. The large battery pack extends across the base of the vehicle, lowering the center of gravity and serving as a load transfer mechanism in a side impact, so you have half the rollover risk of a traditional SUV. One look at the Model X tells you that, since it looks so unlike a historically tall-bodied SUV. It also has a huge crumple zone in front without an engine up there. Automatic emergency braking and side collision avoidance technology are standard features, too.

You might also be considering: Porsche Macan S, BMW X3, Mercedes-Benz GLC-Class, Audi Q5

Looking for the best of both worlds when it comes to style and usability? Say hello to the BMW X3. It takes the spaciousness of an SUV and the sleekness of a coupe and mixes them together to create a perfectly fashionable wagon. The trunk offers 27.6 cubic feet of space, and when you flip the rear seats down, you can enjoy up to 63.3 cubic feet. There are three engine choices, all connected to an eight-speed automatic transmission. You can stay connected in the X3 with enhanced USB and Bluetooth and Harman Kardon surround system, all of which come standard. You’ll have to shell out extra cash for the Driver Assistance Plus and Dynamic Handling packages, but on the bright side BMW has made some features like Smartphone integration and navigation systems less expensive. Whether you’re tossing groceries and kids in the backseat or folding down the backbench to make room for your latest furniture purchase, you can expect ease and comfort (and a few envious looks from other drivers).
New for 2016: Less expensive navigation system and smartphone integration

pageElements.text: Practicality is probably not the first word that comes to mind when you think of BMW, and the X4 does not prove you wrong. With the same engines and wheelbases, the X4 and X3 feel like siblings, except if the two went to the fair the X4 wouldn’t be tall enough to get on any of the rides. With only 37.4 inches of rear headroom and shrunken cargo capacity, the X4 offers significantly less space than the X3. You’ll still get BMW’s high quality standard features, including heated mirrors, a power tailgate and Bluetooth, but if you want blind spot detection or a rearview camera, you’ll have to pay for it. And when comparing apples to apples, the X4 is more expensive than the X3. However, what the X4 lacks in practicality it makes up for in sleekness. You can retain your SUV-style commanding view of the road without anyone thinking for one second you’re a soccer mom.
New for 2016: Enhanced Bluetooth (Mobile Office, Bluetooth sync for second phone, iSpeech)

As if the X5 lineup didn't offer enough choices, BMW has added a plug-in hybrid to its X5 lineup for 2016, and it’s just as stylish, spacious, and powerful as the other X5s. The gasoline-powered wagons’ engines range from 255 to 300 horsepower, and on the hybrid you’ll get a combined output of 308 horsepower. A green machine that goes from 0 to 60 mph in 6.5 seconds? Tempting. Moving away from the eco-friendly perks, though, the X5 offers 23 cubic feet of cargo space and collapsible seats, perfect for families or heavy packers. Although BMW will tempt you with options that can rack your bill up to close to six figures, the standard options should curb your cravings. Front and rear parking sensors, leather steering wheel, and 14-way power driver and front passenger seats with lumbar support all come standard on the X5. The bad news is you will have to pay for a rearview camera, head-up display, and blind-spot detection. That’s okay, though, you can wipe your tears with seats’ Canberra Beige leather.
New for 2016: xDrive40e, BMW’s first plug-in hybrid Sports Activity Vehicle

title: Five Steps to Jump-Starting a Car
subTitle: You can do it! Watch my video lesson in the art of starting a car when its battery has let you down.
promoTitle: Five Steps to Jump-Starting a Car
promoTeaserSmall: You can do it! Watch my video lesson in the art of starting a car when its battery has let you down.
promoTeaser: You can do it! Watch my video lesson in the art of starting a car when its battery has let you down.
keywords: Five Steps to Jump-Starting a Car
metaTitle: Five Steps to Jump-Starting a Car
metaKeywords: how to jump a dead car battery
metaDescription: You can do it! Watch my video lesson in the art of starting a car when its battery has let you down.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
If you have a roadside assistance card in your wallet, maybe you think you’ve got any roadside emergencies covered. But even so, it’s important to know a few basic survival skills in case you ever find yourself stranded where a service truck can’t get to you or will take too long. Having jumper cables in the car is de rigueur in frigid northern climates, but these practical accessories are really an important part of anyone’s automotive emergency kit.

The skill of jump-starting a car sits right up there with knowing how to change a tire. You might not want to, but you should know how. Be the person who can handle the situation when you walk out of that night baseball game and realize you’ve left your lights on and killed the battery—or someone else has.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/ZU7hGSZ1pA4" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
Here are five steps to a successful jump start. Watch my video for the demonstration.

1. Get out the owner’s manual and look at the safety warnings.

Take them seriously! The manual will also help you locate the battery in case it has been placed in some strange location in your car (or the other person’s). Sometimes it's even in the trunk.

2. Prepare the two vehicles.

This will usually mean pulling the helper car as close as possible to the one with the dead battery, without having them touch. Then set the parking brake; turn off the ignition, lights, radio, and other accessories in both cars; and make sure nothing such as phones or iPods is hooked in to accessory ports in either vehicle.

3. Hook up the jumper cables, making sure not to let the metal ends of the cables touch each other.

Make sure to attach the cables to both cars in the correct sequence. Positive, red (marked +) cables hook up first. Do it in this (circular) sequence: (1) Attach a red cable to the positive terminal on the good battery. (2) Attach the other red cable to the positive terminal on the dead battery. (3) Attach a black, negative (marked -) cable to the negative terminal on the dead battery. (4) Hook the other black cable on to a clean metal part inside the donor car, away from the battery.
4. Fire up the donor car and let it run for a few minutes.

5. Fire up the car with the dead battery and let it run for a few minutes.

Keep the cables hooked up to both cars. Then remove in reverse order: negative (black) cables first, then positive (red) cables. Once you’ve got the car started, drive the car for at least fifteen to twenty minutes to help the battery recharge before you shut it off. If this doesn’t work after two to three attempts, call the tow truck for expert help!

pageElements.text:
2016 Infiniti QX50 RWD

Type: Five-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive luxury crossover
Trim levels: QX50, QX50 AWD
Base price: $35,445 (rear-wheel drive); $36,845 (all-wheel drive) (prices include destination charge)
This car: $43,095
Engine: 3.7-liter V-6, 325 horsepower
Transmission: Seven-speed automatic with manual shift mode
Fuel economy: 17 mpg city/24 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not yet rated; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not yet rated
Competitors (prices include destination charges):
2016 Audi Q5 2.0 TFSI ($41,825)
2016 Acura RDX ($36,190)
2016 Lexus NX200 ($36,360)
2016 Porsche Macan S ($53,595)

Fun-O-Meter: 8.5

My husband, a.k.a. The Laugh Riot, claimed once that he’d written me a song he titled, “I Might Be Old, But I’m New to You.” That would be apropos of the 2016 Infiniti QX50, which you may have missed (or ignored) when it was called the EX35 and then the EX37.

It’s also a song title that implies the distinct possibility that being old isn’t necessarily a bad thing. My husband, for instance, is the best thing ever. As it turns out, the QX50 has every bit of the old EX37 sparkle, only some remnants of now dated technology, and quite a lot of notable improvements.

You don’t have to squint at its curvaceous profile to see the eight-year-old crossover before you. It looked fresh back then, it still looks interesting, and if you’re sharp about these things, you’ll see that the QX50 sits a tad higher (0.8 inch, for 6.9 inches of ground clearance), and that it’s more than a bit longer. That little 4.5-inch stretcharoo does wonders for its overall proportions, not to mention its cabin volume, which gained 8.3 cubic feet of precious space.

Lack of space, especially in the rear seat, was a real problem with the EX37. Infiniti points proudly to the 2016 QX50’s extra 3.9 inches of legroom back there. Hmm. I have a thirty-four-inch inseam, and my driving partner, KABC automotive reporter and nutball Dave Kuntz, is probably 6'5". We fit comfortably in the front, but I could barely wedge the Dutch apple pie I bought from the Julian Pie Company during our test drive in the mountains above San Diego on the floor between the front and back seats. My feet are longer than that pie box.
Okay, so I have huge feet, and maybe you don’t.

The QX also got a face lift with Infiniti’s latest design statement—a new “double arch” grille with bold grating that forms a strong backdrop for the large chrome Infiniti badge. The headlamps are also new (as so many are these days) and puts forth an interesting light “signature” at night. New alloy wheels complete the exterior tailoring.

Our test car’s nineteen-inch split five-spoke wheels are part of the optional Deluxe Touring package ($2,400) which also includes HID xenon headlights, a trick coat hanger built into the back of the driver headrest, and power-up second-row seats that you can control from the center console, the first in its class.
The leather-swathed, wood-trimmed, all-power-everything interior is lovely and cosseting, but it had no impact on the Fun-O-Meter.
If you can afford truly bad fuel economy (17 mpg city/24 mpg highway), you will be rewarded with an outstanding display of power and might. The V-6 is a heart of gold.

It’s the engine I swoon over: a 3.7-liter V-6 that sits behind the front wheel axis (providing exceptional balance and poise on our mountain test route) and is another carryover from the EX37. If you can afford truly bad fuel economy (17 mpg city/24 mpg highway), you will be rewarded with an outstanding display of power and might. Not only is horsepower rated at 325, the torque (which provides the thrust that throws you back in the seat when you stand on the throttle) is a substantial 267 pound-feet. It’s mated to a seven-speed automatic transmission with a manual shift mode that includes automatic rev matching for quick and satisfying downshifts. It is like magic. The V-6 is a heart of gold, and we had many opportunities to test it on the twisty roads leading up to that unbelievable pie.

I honestly don’t remember the EX37 being this much of a riot to drive. It’s always more fun to drive a rear-wheel-drive car, and the QX50 was no exception. Note that I said car. The steering is much more responsive than you would expect from a sub-$50,000 crossover, and the sophisticated suspension is what you would find under a sports car. No real surprise, then, that this platform also underpins the Q50 sedan and Nissan’s 370Z.

There just aren’t that many hot rod utility vehicles among the small luxury crossover competition—and it’s the fastest, hottest crossover growth segment today. According to Infiniti product planning director Keith St. Clair, small luxury crossovers may be even bigger than sedans, no surprise.
Our test QX50 was loaded up with every single option package, and it still came in under $44,000.

You would have to head pretty far up in the crossover food chain to find one better. The mighty (and mighty popular) Porsche Macan is the first one to come to mind. It’s base price is $53,595, including destination charge. Compare that with the QX50’s base price of $35,445 for the rear-wheel-drive model ($36,845 for all-wheel drive), which Infiniti noted was $550 less than the EX37 and includes $1,750 in added standard features. Our test QX50 was loaded up with every single option package—the one with all the hot safety tech, the luxury comfort stuff, the sweet Bose system, the navigation, XM Traffic, and the Around-View Monitor with the first vehicle that can detect moving objects around the perimeter, as well as illuminated kickplates—all for an additional $8,090. It still came in under $44,000.

This is the new Infiniti, one that is hellbent on enjoying selling some cars for a change. Buoyed by twelve consecutive months of record sales (up 10 percent in the U.S and 14 percent globally), Infiniti is embarking on an ambitious run of new products over the next couple of years. New products will replace current Qs (the cars), and you can expect brand-new QX models (the crossovers).

Johan de Nysschen, who came from Audi to revamp Infiniti, used to say about Audis that he didn’t want to see one in every driveway because it would erode their aura of exclusivity. At Infiniti, exclusivity was not his priority. He moved global headquarters to Hong Kong, expanded sales around the globe, and launched production plants in Mexico, the U.K, and China (where Infiniti’s booming sales are second only to Porsche). He flew the coop in 2014 after two years to head up Cadillac, leaving Infiniti to make sense of it all.
If this new QX50 is an indicator, the Nissan luxury division is making plenty of sense.

Based on the concepts we’ve seen at the world’s auto shows and in the backroom of Infiniti design, the aura of exclusivity is all there. Luckily for its customers, the affordability goes along with it. Get them while they’re this hot.

title: 2017 Range Rover Evoque Convertible
subTitle: Five cool things about Land Rover's new droptop.
promoTeaserSmall: The convertible form of the Evoque has to be seen to be believed.
promoTeaser: The convertible form of the Evoque has to be seen to be believed.
metaDescription: The convertible form of the Evoque has to be seen to be believed.

pageElements.text: The smallest, arguably most stylish Land Rover product is the Evoque crossover, and soon you'll be able to get it in a convertible version. It's not unprecedented for the British off-road specialist to offer softtops, but traditionally they have been military-style Defenders. This one is, in the words of design chief Gerry McGovern, intended for a "natural urban environment."

So it's a little amusing that it has made a couple of video appearances showing how rugged and capable it is in environments far off the beaten track. Very stiff upper lip. The Evoque convertible will be officially unveiled at the 2015 Los Angeles Auto Show next month. It goes on sale in the United States next spring.

1. It can wade in water a half-meter deep—and has wade sensing to tell you how deep you're plunging, so you don’t get out of your depth, so to speak. Fly-fishing while strapped in to the back seat, anybody?
2. It passed its final road-testing program at the Land Rover Experience Centre on Eastnor Castle Estate, handling steep inclines and muck in a very Land Roverish way, as this video shows.

3. The Evoque was the first vehicle to drive through the twenty-six-mile underground Crossrail tunnel network, currently under construction 131 feet below the streets of London, to test its capability in challenging terrain. Will you ever drive yours in an uncompleted underground tunnel? Unlikely, but what a cool stunt. The top was down, in case you had to ask.

4. Land Rover put out six full-scale wireframe sculptures of the Evoque convertible in front of Harrods department store and Burberry’s flagship store in central London to whet appetites. Now those are the customers who seem the most likely to go for this droptop SUV, and they’re the least likely to drive it through tunnels and into bogs. The wireframe sculptures are going to tour other cities prior to next month's Los Angeles Auto Show unveiling of the production model.

5. It's still a Land Rover, despite its citified looks, equipped with body modifications to make the convertible sturdier, plus hill descent control, four-wheel drive, and a terrain response system, among other features that mean you really could take it just about wherever you want.

title: 2016 Chevrolet Volt Premier
subTitle: The game-changer hybrid ups its game for the second generation.
promoTeaserSmall: The game-changer hybrid ups its game.
promoTeaser: The game-changer hybrid ups its game.
metaDescription: The game-changer hybrid ups its game.

pageElements.text:
2016 Chevrolet Volt Premier

Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive gasoline-electric hybrid compact hatchback
Trim levels: LT, Premier
Base price: $33,995 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $39,830
Engine:2.4-liter four-cylinder, 180 horsepower, and two electric motors
Transmission: Electrically variable direct drive
Fuel economy: 42 mpg city/highway combined, 106 MPGe
My favorite standard feature: Regen(eration) on Demand
Options I can’t live without: Chevrolet MyLink with navigation ($495)
Notable standard features on this model: Seventeen-inch aluminum alloy wheels, heated power mirrors, rearview camera, heated leather seats, leather-wrapped steering wheel, 8.0-inch infotainment screen, Bose eight-speaker premium audio, five-year OnStar service
Notable options on this model: Driver Confidence 1 package: blind spot alert, rear cross traffic alert, lane departure alert ($495); Driver Confidence 2 package: lane keeping assist, low-speed automatic braking, forward collision alert, auto-dimming headlights ($495)
You might also be considering: Audi A3 e-tron, Ford C-Max Energi, Lexus CT Hybrid, Nissan Leaf, Toyota Prius, Toyota Prius V

When the Chevrolet Volt rolled onto the scene in 2010, we, along with most members of the automotive press corps, saw it as a game changer: an electric that could keep going when the battery was depleted. None of your waiting around for hours and hours with the car plugged into a wall socket.
In the world of alternate propulsion, it looked like a hands-down winner.
But it wasn’t.

Over the course of five years, Chevy sold a little under 80,000 Volts. Not all of Chevrolet’s U.S. dealers carried the Volt, but some 2,200 did. That works out to an average of just over thirty-six Volts per participating dealer, or about seven Volts per dealer per year.
Not exactly a landslide. And low fuel prices have sharply diminished America’s appetite for hybrids and electrics. So what will give this new Volt wider appeal than the first generation?
That’s a very good question. The short answer is: pretty much everything. Better looks, excellent road manners, improved performance, and substantial improvement to its innovative powertrain.

Let’s start with the element that’s set the Volt apart from others in the growing world of electro-hybrid vehicles: propulsion. Like the first generation, the new Volt employs an internal-combustion engine. Its primary role is to power the car’s battery pack, which in turn sends juice to electric motors that turn the front wheels.

Notice that word “motors.” In the original Volt there was one electric motor, which doubled as a generator. In the new one there are two, either of which—or both—can propel the car or generate electricity.

The battery pack, which resides under the floor down the center of the car, is a little bigger, storing about 20 percent more juice, and it’s about thirty pounds lighter than the original. The 1.5-liter gasoline engine, one of GM’s new family of ultra-efficient four-cylinders, produces more power and is also lighter, by about 100 pounds.

All told, the new Volt is some 200 pounds lighter than the original. Reduced mass and higher efficiency—the engineers claim a 12 percent improvement—add up to greater range operating on electric power, greater range overall, and of course higher fuel economy.

This new Volt can go fifty-three miles on electric power alone, according to Chevrolet, and 420 miles before the gas tank needs a refill. Chevrolet claimed a maximum of thirty-eight miles running on electric power for the original, and a total range of 380 miles with the gasoline engine powering the system.

EPA fuel economy ratings are 42 mpg combined city/highway, with an mpg equivalency rating—MPGe, the government’s formula for equating electrics and plug-in hybrids with conventional internal-combustion systems—of 106.
The styling is more contemporary than the first version, and the increase in size yields more room for rear-seat passengers, a point of complaint among first-gen owners.

This is a larger Volt, a little over three inches longer, on a wheelbase that’s been stretched by about a half inch. The styling is more contemporary than the first version, and the increase in size yields more room for rear-seat passengers, a point of complaint among first-gen owners. Also, the center rear is habitable by an adult, at least for short hauls, something that wasn’t true of the original.

The front seats are manually adjustable—this is fundamentally an electric car, remember—but are comfortable, with just enough bolstering to feel almost sporty. The dashboard is dominated by an 8.0-inch screen that displays function of the power system, as well as navigation (when so equipped) and other infotainment elements. There’s also a display in the instrument binnacle showing battery state and, of course, remaining fuel.

Interior materials are a cut above what you’d expect in a compact sedan, standard safety items are basic (although the Premier trim level we drove was equipped with several optional features), and the interior is quiet at all speeds—which of course you’d expect.

Speaking of speed, the new Volt is a little peppier than the original—19 percent quicker to 30 mph, according to Chevrolet, and 7 percent to 60 mph: just under eight seconds, about a second less than Volt I. The steering has better than average road feel by today’s electric rack-and-pinion standards, body motions are subdued—very little roll in cornering—ride quality is smooth, the chassis feels solid, throttle response is vigorous, the transmission has a single speed (keep in mind that electric motors make maximum torque from the first rev), and overall operation is seamless; borderline sporty, in fact.
It’s basically a pleasure to drive, and the transition from pure electric propulsion to the involvement of the gasoline engine is totally seamless.

It’s basically a pleasure to drive, and the transition from pure electric propulsion to the involvement of the gasoline engine is totally seamless. The driver’s only clue to the engine’s activation is the information on the dashboard readouts.

As noted, Chevrolet cites a maximum pure electric range of 53 miles. Presumably, that’s by driving with an eye toward maximizing the battery charge. We logged 48 before the engine came to life, not quite up to factory spec but certainly better than Gen I’s 38-mile max. And we weren’t driving conservatively.

Another new powertrain element is a steering wheel paddle switch that increases the Volt’s battery regeneration. Chevrolet calls it Regen on Demand. Depressing the switch creates a slight but noticeable drag, and can serve as an auxiliary brake in situations where the driver needs to slow only slightly. Using the regen switch and coasting when possible can bring the battery back on line during a trip, thus extending electric range.
The company says that many first-generation owners went as much as 900 miles between fillups, and the expectation is for 1,000 miles with the new generation.

We didn’t have enough time with the car to require a fuel fill, but Volt owners tend to maximize electric range, according to Chevrolet. The company says that many first-generation owners went as much as 900 miles between fills, and the expectation is for 1,000 miles with the new generation. It's hard not to be impressed.

Like other plug-in hybrids, recharging the Volt’s battery pack plugging into ordinary household current is time-consuming: half a day. Setting up the optional 240-volt system reduces that to 4.5 hours. But with this car, battery depletion needn’t precipitate a lot of sitting around waiting; you have options.

One of the elements that damped sales of the first-generation Volt was price. With a base MSRP close to $40,000, the Volt was a pretty expensive compact car, even after the $7,500 federal tax incentive and other state credits. Chevy has whittled the base price for the second generation down to $33,995, which, with tax credits, gets the Volt down closer to compact reality.

The top Premier model we tested has a base price of $38,345, and it added $990 for two packages of safety features—blind zone alert, lane departure warning, lane keeping assist, low speed automatic braking, forward collision alert—and $495 for Chevy’s MyLink radio with nav system, putting the as-tested price very close to $40,000.
As an aside, it’s interesting that Chevrolet does not offer an adaptive cruise control option.

At $39,830, the Volt’s virtues become a little more difficult to appreciate, tax breaks notwithstanding. But with a bit less luxury, this car rewards its owner financially, as well as in terms of driving pleasure—particularly owners whose primary driving is within or close to the Volt’s electric range.

There will be a "shortened model year" for the 2016 Volt, Chevrolet's Michelle Malcho told us. The 2017 Volt is coming next spring to the whole country, but the 2016 Volt is getting a limited rollout. About 45 percent of Volt sales to date have been in California, so it makes sense that GM will begin rolling Volts into California showrooms first, starting in the next two weeks. After that, the Volt will go on sale in traditionally strong alternative-energy vehicle markets: Oregon, Connecticut, Maine, Massachusetts, Maryland, New York, New Jersey, Rhode Island, Vermont, and New Hampshire.

title: Dieselgate Update
subTitle: Thoughts on the Volkswagen story, and an invitation to join the ranks of our newsletter readers.
promoTeaserSmall: Thoughts on the Volkswagen story, and an invitation to join the ranks of our newsletter readers.
promoTeaser: Thoughts on the Volkswagen story, and an invitation to join the ranks of our newsletter readers.
metaDescription: Thoughts on the Volkswagen story, and an invitation to join the ranks of our newsletter readers.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: This was my commentary in the weekly Jean Knows Cars newsletter, sent via email to a discerning group of readers. Want to be one of them and read it every week? Simply send your email address to me at feedback@jeanknowscars.com. Thanks!

I just made my first appearance on the BBC ​yesterday,​ talking about you-know-what. I am amazed at how much there is to say on the subject of #dieselgate. The Congressional hearings began​,​ and it becomes even clearer why the V​olkswagen​ AG bosses still standing after the first purge let Michael Horn stay on as Scapegoat in Chief of VW USA. As ​C​ongress gets in line to take a bat to Horn, he stands tall and offers them no target. The company lied to him, he is shocked, and he apologizes from the bottom of his heart. Hit him, beat him, excoriate away. He will be the hero at the end of this saga, mark my words.

As I thought about the enormity of it all, ​JKC ​creative director Molly Jean insisted that we not call for VW’s demise. Bad karma, first, and​ also​ bad for the global economy. She’s right. When Detroit was foundering​,​ and ​C​ongress called for GM to ​be hoist ​with​ its own petard, our esteemed legislature didn’t understand that if GM shut off the lights, the Tier 1 suppliers would fall. When the suppliers failed, Ford would not be able to build cars no matter how much money it had socked away. We don’t want VW to fail​;​ we want them to go to their bedrooms without supper for a few years.
Just as U.S. consumers have begun to show a fragile acceptance of diesel engines, VW has most probably killed it dead for some time to come.

Just as U.S. consumers have begun to show a fragile acceptance of diesel engines, VW has most probably killed it dead for some time to come. Funny when you think about it: VW is the very reason we even have such a bad opinion of diesels. Are you old enough to remember the ​late​​-​1970s VW Rabbit Diesel? Who can forget following one on the highway, its black clouds of belching particulates, the rear covered in an oily black film?

The German government has raided VW headquarters. Some ten important engineers have been suspended, two of whom are among the most respected engine development chiefs in the industry. It’s going to be a long winter.
Love, Jean

title: 9 Driving Behaviors Everyone Hates
subTitle: (So don’t be that person.)

pageElements.text: In this age of smartphones and touchscreens, any driver would be forgiven for worrying about whether the other drivers around him or her are watching the road instead of texting or programming music using Pandora. It’s like flying—it’s so bad out there that you just have to lower your expectations (and heart rate) so you don’t lose your mind. That’s why it’s even more important to make your own driving be the change you want to see in the world. Start by eliminating these ten really bad moves, which at best may just be supremely annoying and at worst may provoke road rage. Here we go.
1. Inching forward at stop signs or corners, making the people driving past you think you are about to T-bone them. Don’t you hate that?

2. Tailgating. This is not the same as dipping into other drivers’ personal space for a brief interval before you get back to a safe following distance. What is that safe distance? That would be three seconds in perfect weather. One-one thousand, two-one thousand, three-one thousand.

3. Driving mindlessly below the speed limit when road conditions don’t indicate you need to. This will mean you have decided to ignore or be unaware of other drivers lining up behind you. On the interstate, this usually means you are on your phone, being the stupidest, most thoughtless, most dangerous driver on the planet.
4. Letting your mind wander—ever—but more specifically at a four-way stop so you aren’t sure when it’s your turn. The turn, by the way, always passes to the car to the right.
5. Whipping out your phone at a stoplight to check your texts and failing to notice when it’s time to go. Thoughtless wretch.

6. Using your horn as an instrument of terror. It’s for emergencies. It’s for a light tap if the car in front of you is engaging in behavior #5. It is not for a long, angry blast as you shoot past a line of cars holding you back from total road domination.

7. Practicing highway vigilantism—brake-checking or deliberately slowing down when another car is following too close, adjusting your speed specifically to keep someone else from passing you, revenge tailgating—is a really bad idea. Paybacks to other drivers who are breaking the social contract isn’t your responsibility. It’s really bad for your blood pressure and it’s how people get shot. Take a deep cleansing breath.

8. Getting into any relationship with another driver. It is bound to be a bad one. (Re-read #7.) No flipping the middle finger. No shouting out your window, especially horrifying to your passengers. And don’t let your passengers do it for you.

9. There is a special place in Hell for drivers who drive on the shoulder in construction and accident traffic to get to the front or to get off the next exit. There is also a really big fine if you get caught.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, all-wheel-drive compact sedan
Trim levels: Front-wheel drive: LX, Limited S, C; All-wheel drive: S, C
Base price: $30,540 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $33,525
Engine: 3.6-liter V-6, 295 horsepower
Transmission: Nine-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 18 mpg city/29 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick Plus (2015)
My favorite standard feature: Park View rearview camera
Options I can’t live without: Heated front seats and steering wheel; Uconnect Access on-board Wi-Fi hot spot
Notable standard features on this model: Sport suspension, ambient LED lighting, tilting and telescoping steering wheel, leather-wrapped steering wheel, LED taillamps
Notable options on this model: Navigation and Sound group ($1,495) includes 8.4-inch infotainment touchscreen, navigation, SiriusXM Traffic, Harman HD radio, 7.0-inch driver information screen, Alpine 506-watt amplifer, Uconnect Wi-Fi hot spot; Comfort group ($895) includes heated front seats and steering wheel, remote start
You might also be considering (prices include destination charge):
2016 Ford Fusion SE AWD ($29,345)
2016 Subaru Legacy 3.6R ($29,945)

Shopping for a new car can be fun, but it can also be overwhelming. There are far more possible choices in the mid-size sedan category than you will ever have the patience to test drive—or even fully research. So when you are shopping in this category, the sooner you can narrow down your specific needs, the easier the shopping process will be.

If you want all-wheel drive in a mid-size sedan, that will narrow it down for you very quickly. There are near-luxury sedans in the high $30,000s to mid-$40,000s: the Audi A4, Lexus IS350, and Volvo S60, for example.

But if you want to stick at or very close to $30,000, you’re looking at more family-oriented cars like the Ford Fusion, the Subaru Legacy, and this Chrysler 200. Which one has more attitude? I’d have to go with the Chrysler, which has admirably incorporated attractively edgy touches into what could be (and used to be, in the 200’s predecessor, the Sebring) a dull middle-American car most comfortable on the rental lot.
The 200 was all new in the 2015 model year, so changes for 2016 are few. It’s an attractive sedan inside and out, a very tidy exterior package with a charming face and a beautifully executed cabin.
We’d recommend the 295-horsepower V-6 that we had on the 200S shown here, which you’ll appreciate the first time you want to put on a little freeway speed.

The base 200 comes with a four-cylinder engine making 184 horsepower. It gets an impressive 36 mpg on the highway, but we’d recommend the 295-horsepower V-6 that we had on the 200S shown here, which you’ll appreciate the first time you want to put on a little freeway speed. You should also seriously consider the all-wheel-drive option, as it beautifully manages the added power of the V-6. The added incentive of all-wheel drive will make believers out of shoppers in the northern climates.

Even as a front-wheel-drive sedan, the 200 still has a lot to recommend it, in both looks and technology. Chrysler’s excellent Uconnect infotainment system is standard on every model, but the screen gets bigger as you go up in trim levels. The 5.0-inch screen is standard on all but the base model, but if you want our vote? Spring for the one we had on our test car, the 8.4-inch screen with HD radio, Bluetooth connectivity, and navigation. It’s big enough to give you a great instant read on every song you choose via SiriusXM radio, including the album cover art.

Speaking of electronic technology, the 911 Call button on the rearview mirror is worth calling out. Imagine being able to press that while driving to report an emergency that easily and immediately. No fiddling to get to the right place on the infotainment screen to find the emergency button. No fishing in the purse for your phone to call 911, either.
Your bag can remain safely stashed in the Chrysler 200’s awesome center console that is big and deep enough for a reasonably sized handbag.

The combination leather-and-cloth seats with ventilation and heating not only look stylish, they’re the kind of firm and supportive we like—a worthy option available only on S and C models. This is something else that sets the Chrysler 200 apart in the mid-size sedan arena: it’s really superbly done inside.

On the safety front, a rearview camera is standard on all but the base LX model, and blind spot and cross-path detection are an affordably priced option at $595. A $1,295 SafetyTec option group, available on the 200S and 200C models, adds adaptive cruise control, brake assist, forward collision warning, park assist, and rain-sensing wipers. Chrysler’s YouTube channel offers a wide variety of short videos explaining many of these new safety features.

Features that are new for 2016 include the standard rearview camera on Limited and S models, the addition of blind spot monitoring and rear cross-path detection as standalone options at one price (as on our test car), and a standard heated steering wheel on the top-of-the-line 200C. (If you haven’t tried one, especially in winter, you haven’t lived.) There’s also a 90th anniversary package for the 200 Limited, this year only, and the Limited also gets the V-6 for the first time in 2016. There are some infotainment upgrades for 2016 as well: a drag-and-drop menu bar for cars equipped with the 8.4-inch version of the Uconnect touchscreen, plus Siri Eyes Free with voice recognition for Apple users, and a Do Not Disturb function that keeps your phone from intruding on your drive—something everyone can appreciate.

A hybrid version is glaringly absent in the 200 line, but there are other features that give the 200S its own special flair—that optional and satisfyingly rorty V-6 engine; a superior nine-speed automatic transmission with paddle shifters; and one of FCA’s signature strengths, that all-wheel-drive option. It’s definitely worth a place on your mid-size-sedan shopping list.

title: 5 Cool Things: Internet in the Car
subTitle: Survey says you want to be connected while you drive. AT&T and others are happy to oblige.
promoTitle: 5 Cool Things: Internet in the Car
promoTeaserSmall: Survey says you want to be connected while you drive. AT&T and others are happy to oblige.
promoTeaser: Survey says you want to be connected while you drive. AT&T and others are happy to oblige.
keywords: 5 Cool Things: Internet in the Car
metaTitle: 5 Cool Things: Internet in the Car - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Survey says you want to be connected while you drive. AT&T and others are happy to oblige.

pageElements.text: Is Wi-Fi completely indispensable to your life yet? If you say no, chances are you have never taken a long trip with a car full of teenagers. Or found yourself stopping at fast-food joints far too often to catch up with your work on the computer. That may be about to change. Many automakers have started incorporating on-board wireless into their new models. AT&T and phone supplier Ericsson just released a survey that shows almost four out of five car shoppers are willing to wait a year to buy a car, if it means they can get connectivity on board. Even if you're not that patient—or not in the market at this moment—the study also shows that this is the most desired feature on a new car.

At first glance, it's another one of those modern "improvements" that seem easy to resist. We're guessing, however, that it won't be very many years before the idea of on-board Wi-Fi is considered as essential to the inside of your car as air conditioning or power windows. Here, then, are our five cool things about being connected in the car.
AT&T and Ericsson just released a survey that shows four out of five car shoppers are willing to wait a year to buy a car, if it means they can get Internet on board.

1. You get a stronger signal. That's because you are running your Wi-Fi through the car's antenna, in essence using the vehicle like a big metal connecting box, Joe Mosele of AT&T explained. Mosele showed off his company's 4G LTE wireless connection in a Cadillac Escalade, explaining that wireless speed is "significantly better" if you use the embedded Wi-Fi in the car versus going through your smartphone.

2. You won't have to buy an expensive optional (or aftermarket) entertainment system. Bonus: everybody is not forced to watch the same movie, and you don't have to pack DVDs for your trip to the soccer field or vacation spot that make a bunch of noise but can only be viewed by those in the second row. You have no idea how many Disney movies I've only listened to but never seen. With on-board wireless, you can stream from your Netflix account, or everybody can catch up on email and homework assignments while the driver enjoys some peace and quiet.

3. You can be so much more efficient, in your own time and space. Whether it's a driven college student with a paper to finish, or a business owner pulling in to a parking lot to send a few quick emails on the laptop, it's all so much easier to do right inside your own car, at your convenience and where you wish. Wouldn't you rather be doing all that when sitting by the lake than in a McDonald's? And with no fear of being kicked off the Internet after a half-hour at peak times, as happens in some of the joints I've stopped in? Bonus: AT&T's 4G LTE works for a fifty-foot radius around the car.

4. You don't have to pay for navigation on your new car. Not if you have a smartphone and on-board Wi-Fi. If your car has Apple CarPlay or Android Apps, you can run navigation right off your phone and onto the infotainment screen in your car. If not, you can still run it from your smartphone using the car's Wi-Fi.

5. It's not actually very expensive. Popular brands like Chevrolet (along with the other General Motors brands) already have on-board Wi-Fi hot spots. Others will follow. On GM vehicles, you can add the 4G LTE into your existing OnStar subscription, but AT&T says that most consumers surveyed said they'd prefer to add the cost of on-board Wi-Fi to their existing mobile phone plans. For those who have shared data plans like AT&T's Mobile Share, your vehicle can become another data user on the same plan, making your added expense close to unnoticeable. Or you can buy a Tesla: the electric-car maker picks up the cost of data used by owners in its cars.

Wireless in the car is far from universal, but Jaguar Land Rover, Audi, and General Motors are all on board already, and others are coming. AT&T says it will have more than 10 million vehicles on its network before the end of 2017—and they added almost a million in the second quarter of 2015 alone—so the likeliness is growing that you'll be able to get a car with the Internet on board very soon.

title: Pro/Con: To GoPro or Not to GoPro?
subTitle: Molly says people should stop filming while driving. Laura says it's no worse than other tech. You?
promoTitle: Pro/Con: To GoPro or Not to GoPro?
promoTeaserSmall: Molly says people should stop filming while driving. Laura says it's no worse than other tech. You?
promoTeaser: Molly says people should stop filming while driving. Laura says it's no worse than other tech. You?
keywords: Pro/Con: To GoPro or Not to GoPro?
metaTitle: Pro/Con: To GoPro or Not to GoPro? - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Molly says people should stop filming while driving. Laura says it's no worse than other tech. You?

contributors.displayName: Laura Sky Brown and Molly Jean

pageElements.text: Do you take videos of yourself and your loved ones? Of course you do. These days, it’s a given; just look at social media. And there’s a product for it: the GoPro. This flexible little camera is so unbelievably cool that the 2016 Toyota Tacoma has a GoPro mount as standard equipment. On BMW and Mini cars, you can use the iDrive infotainment app to control your GoPro camera from your smartphone. “There is a major shift in what consumers are looking for to help them document their lives,” GoPro inventor Nick Woodman told Forbes in a 2013 interview that was, of course, captured on video. And he’s right. It has all happened so fast. The first iPhone with a video function came out just six years ago. The GoPro portable action digital camera has been around in its current form only since 2006.

So, for less than a decade, the ability to shoot impromptu personal video has been a possibility. The ability to shoot video in the car? People naturally want to do that, too. And that’s where we (as usual) disagree on how OK it is for people to set up a GoPro in the car, especially when it's set up facing toward the occupants of the car, and shoot video while driving.

Laura Says: It’s No Worse Than Other Potentially Distracting Tech; Just Be Responsible

What’s bugging my easily annoyed colleague Molly Jean today? It’s all those videos, all over social media, showing people out on the roads singing duets of “Frozen” show tunes while careening down the freeway. “This is what our children are probably doing right now,” she complains. From a quick glance at YouTube, she’s right; my kids aren’t (I hope), but a lot of people are.
What’s bugging my easily annoyed colleague Molly Jean today? Videos all over social media, showing people singing duets from “Frozen” while careening down the freeway.

And yet, I still think the GoPro is a cool thing that has its uses inside the car, as long as people are reasonable about setup and use and don’t let it be any more distracting than the nav systems, app suites, and other technology you’ll find on the modern car.

The inside of the car is as close to a rolling living room as it gets. It is in the car that people have intimate conversations with family members and friends, share musical experiences, and—let’s face it—sit closer to most people than they do in any other setting. It’s enforced togetherness as you commute, go on road trips, or just drive around town. I think it’s kind of lovely that people are using the GoPro to document their time together. The device was invented for surfers and is famous for being mounted to the helmets of skiers and dirt bike riders. Looked at that way, mounting one on the rearview mirror of a car is downright tame.

That doesn’t mean I want to watch other people sing show tunes, but if that’s what people enjoy doing as a family or peer group, more power to them. It should go without saying that the GoPro should be set up and operated by the passenger, not the driver, and the driver needs to focus on driving, not video stardom. With those caveats, roll the tape. (But wear your seatbelts. Don't be idiots like these idiots. Talented, but park the van first, guys.)
Molly Says: Quit Clowning Around. The Car Is Not Your Bathroom Mirror
If a picture paints a thousand words, this video paints a million.

Social media is drowning with videos of people using the interior of the car as a recording studio. Many are safely parked, but there are plenty with the drivers piloting their two-ton missiles down the Interstate. I have seen dozens of videos of parents lip syncing “Let It Go” while maneuvering through traffic. Perhaps it is time for a public service announcement about keeping your eyes on the road. I have seen hundreds of ads reminding us not to text and drive, but nary a mention of clowning around while driving in front of the camera. Several states have outlawed talking on the phone while driving, even if it is hands free. The intrusion of videotaping passengers in a car seems like a recipe for distracted driving.

I get it. I love to sing in the car, too. Throw in a friend or two and I might be coerced into auditioning to be the next YouTube star. But then I remember that one simple mistake could cost a life, and it is not worth it. This video turned up on the Internet last week of two young guys who videotaped their own fatal accident. Perhaps if they were driving the car rather than showing off for the camera, their deaths could have been avoided.
I love to sing in the car, too. But then I remember that one simple mistake could cost a life, and it is not worth it.

The introduction of dash-mounted videos facing outward is a giant leap forward for the motoring world. It can serve as a star witness for accidents and can record stunning roads and scenery. But it is important to stress that safe driving is the number-one responsibility of the driver. I can only imagine the footage that Evel Knievel would have captured. I also love Johnny Knoxville, but I would prefer to think of him in a state far, far away from me, not driving the car next to me on I-94.

Let’s keep the video action away from the inside of cars and err on the side of safety rather than on entertainment. For those who just must have a permanent record of themselves singing in the car, please keep it in Park. Thank you. The life you save may be someone I love, or maybe someone Laura loves.

title: 2016 Cadillac Escalade and Escalade ESV
subTitle: Larger than life luxury and capacity.
promoTeaserSmall: Larger than life luxury and capacity.
promoTeaser: Larger than life luxury and capacity.
metaTitle: 2016 Cadillac Escalade and Escalade ESV - JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Seven- or eight-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive full-size sport-utility vehicle
Price range: $73,965–$95,945 (prices include destination charge)
Trim levels: Standard, Luxury, Premium, Platinum
Engine: 6.2-liter V-8, 420 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: Escalade RWD: 15 mpg city/22 mpg highway; Escalade AWD: 15/21 mpg; Escalade ESV RWD: 15/22 mpg; Escalade ESV AWD: 15/21 mpg
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars for side crash, 3/5 stars for rollover; not rated for overall safety
Our favorite standard features: Standard power-folding third row and powered programmable liftgate
Notable standard features on this model: Tri-zone climate control, Cue infotainment, Bose Active Noise Cancellation technology, heated and ventilated front seats, heated rear seats, OnStar with 4G LTE
Notable options on this model: Concealed center-stack storage with motorized door, power retractable running boards
You might also be considering: Audi Q7, Infiniti QX80, Lexus LX570, Land Rover Range Rover, Lincoln Navigator, Mercedes-Benz GL-Class

The Cadillac Escalade and its extended-length sibling, the Escalade ESV, came out in a stylish all new version for 2015, setting a high bar for the brand and other full-size SUVs in the class. Available in either a seven- or eight-seat configuration, the Escalade is a big utility vehicle that is also big on performance (0 to 60 mph in less than six seconds) and impressive good looks. Look at that brushed chrome grille and the extensive use of LED lighting in back, for example. It’s equally capable off-road and is capable of towing up to 8,300 pounds. Inside, the cabin is appropriately hushed thanks to the use of acoustic-laminate glass, triple-sealed doors, and active noise-canceling technology. Power fold-flat second-row—on ESV models—and third-row seats mean you barely have to lift a finger to load people and cargo in and out of the vehicle, and the second row reclines for passenger comfort.

If you are utilizing all three rows of seats for passengers and need the cargo space, consider the ESV, which extends the wheelbase by 14 inches and doubles the cargo space behind the third row. The programmable hands-free liftgate will make it easier to use that cargo space. Power retractable side steps make it easier to get in as a passenger (or driver), too. Since this is a luxury vehicle, the indulgent touches are many: a rear wiper that is hidden in the spoiler until you need it; a set of standard 20-inch aluminum wheels (22 inches on the Platinum and an option on other trim levels); wood trim on the steering wheel.

New for 2016:

The Escalade/Escalade ESV were all new for 2015, so changes are minor. Lane keeping assist is added, and an eight-speed automatic transmission replaced the former six-speed automatic midway through the 2015 model year. Apple CarPlay brings iPhone users' apps into the Cadillac's infotainment system.

More about the Cadillac Escalade

Real World Test: 4G LTE Wireless Hot Spot in the 2016 Cadillac Escalade May 29, 2015

A Pink Cadillac Escalade for Mom May 6, 2014

title: 2016 Cadillac CTS and CTS-V
subTitle: New engine, new technology for the performance-oriented sedan.
promoTeaserSmall: New engine, new technology for the performance-oriented sedan.
promoTeaser: New engine, new technology for the performance-oriented sedan.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive luxury sedan
Price range: $45,560 – $78,210 (CTS); $83,995 – $102,630 (CTS-V) (prices include destination charge)
Trim levels: Standard, Luxury, Performance, Vsport, CTS-V
Engines: Turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 268 horsepower; 3.6-liter V-6, 335 horsepower; twin-turbocharged 3.6-liter V-6, 420 horsepower
Transmissions: Eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 2.0-liter: 21 mpg city/31 mpg highway; 3.6-liter V-6: 20/30 mpg; twin-turbocharged 3.6-liter V-6: 16/24 mpg; CTS-V: 14/21 mpg
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Wireless phone charger
Notable standard features on this model: Cue infotainment system, remote start, rear park assist, OnStar with 4G LTE
Notable options on this model: Cue infotainment with navigation system, heated and ventilated front seats, head-up display, tri-zone climate control
You might also be considering: Audi A6, BMW 5 Series, Mercedes-Benz E-Class

Cadillac's mid-size car, the CTS, goes after both performance and luxury buyers. For 2016, the addition of an eight-speed automatic transmission with paddle shifters, plus a brand-new 3.6-liter V-6 making 335 horsepower, should entice those in the former category. There's a twin-turbocharged Vsport edition and the ultra-sporting CTS-V as well. A choice of eight interior "environments" heavy on carbon fiber and wood trimmings, plus an optional hand-crafted semi-aniline leather interior, should help with the latter. That new V-6 has cylinder deactivation and stop/start to save fuel, as does the turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder that carries over. Cadillac claims the CTS is lighter and more agile than its competitors in this segment, and the automaker does have formidable competition, particular from the German automakers. Some of the CTS's ammunition comes from its head-up display, OnStar with 4G LTE wireless hot spot on board, Cue infotainment system, and now wireless charging for your smartphone. Upgrades include heated and ventilated seats, crash avoidance systems, and parking assist.

And then there's the CTS-V, with a supercharged 6.2-liter V-8 that makes 640 horsepower; it's Cadillac's most powerful car ever. It comes with a track-oriented suspension, a performance data recorder, Brembo brakes, and twenty-way-adjustable heated and ventilated seats; Recaro seats are optional. The price of entry of the CTS-V is up in the stratosphere as well, starting in the mid-$80,000s and topping out in the low six figures. This year, there's a limited-edition CTS-V in Crystal White Frost. Only twenty-nine will be built, featuring carbon fiber trim and a matte paint finish.

New for 2016:

All-new 3.6-liter V-6; stop/start and active fuel management technology for both 3.6-liter V-6 and 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder); eight-speed automatic transmission; 360-degree camera; Apple CarPlay smartphone app integration; Android Auto smartphone app integration (late availability); three new metallic colors: Cocoa Bronze, Moonstone, and Stellar Black

More about the Cadillac CTS

2016 Cadillac CTS-V at the New York Auto Show January 14, 2015
