contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
2016 Honda Accord Touring V-6

Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive compact sedan
Trim levels: LX, Sport, EX, EX-L, EX-L V-6, Touring V-6
Base price: $22,925 (LX Sedan with four-cylinder engine); $35,400 (Touring V-6) (prices include destination charge)
This car: $35,400
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 278 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 21 mpg city/34 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick Plus
Competitors (prices include destination charge):
2016 Chevrolet Malibu LT Premier ($31,795)
2016 NIssan Altima 3.5SL ($33,175)
2016 Toyota Camry XLE V-6 ($32,205)

Fun-O-Meter: 8
Who would want to be the chief engineer and designer in charge of remaking the Honda Accord?

This is the only car, after all, that has been named to Car and Driver’s Ten Best list twenty-nine times, nearly every year since it made the first Ten Best list in 1983. It’s the car that sells up to 400,000 copies every year, that some 10 million people have bought. Who’d want to be the team that broke the streak?
Luckily, the well-earned hubris of Honda’s people has paid off, and we get a refreshed, technology-filled 2016 Accord that is a winner in every sense.
Not expecting to fall in love with the car—thinking of it more as a practical than an exciting choice—I am here to report that, in fact, I fell in love with the car.

Not expecting to fall in love with the car—thinking of it more as a practical than an exciting choice—I am here to report that, in fact, I fell in love with the car. It’s spectacularly smooth, with exceptional acceleration all the way to 80 mph (and--ahem--beyond). Its V-6, in the Accord Touring model we tested, is a magic engine. Its six-speed automatic transmission is superb.

After all, imagine a car that the rabid boy racers at Car and Driver would choose to award just about every year for decades, more often than any of the many other deserving cars out there. Is there any wonder its residual value is so high, and that it is such a coveted, top-selling car in the United States?

It is safe to say that everything about the 2016 Accord is better than ever. An updated version of the the ninth-generation Accord that made its debut in 2013, the new model continues to build on an attractive look that goes well beyond the bland appearance of many sedans. It’s stylish, especially in the crisply tailored and interestingly folded front end, with the hood now made of aluminum rather than steel. A new set of LED fog lights and taillights are found on all but the base model. It’s stronger, sharper, and more complex. The chrome trim on the exterior might be just a bit excessive—never mind my own somewhat excessive style and personality.

There is nothing soft about its appearance in any way.  That is an achievement, given how hard it is to make a front-wheel-drive car look exciting. Someone said to me that the Honda Accord is not a car you’d look out the window late at night and feel thrilled to see in your driveway. I disagree; I can’t say any Accord has made me as interested in it as this one did.

The interior is satisfying, with a great blend of materials, textures, and colors, and all perfectly screwed together. Just one indicator is the extra little cubby space in the inside door handle. An automaker that understands this knows how to waste no opportunities for clever use of space. There’s a spacious hidden compartment in the dash that I didn’t find until the end of the week, and when I did, it revealed an extra USB port. By the numbers, the Accord isn’t bigger or offer more inches of legroom, yet with Honda’s usual brilliant use of space, the back seat is more comfortable and usable than on some big crossovers I’ve driven recently.
More than most cars in this category, with the Accord you get a complete, all-around package of comfort, control, refinement, and great acceleration.

Over the nine generations of the Accord, Honda has managed to delete any hint of potential torque steer. The steering and brakes are everyday perfection, and the ride is magic-carpet-like. More than most cars in this category, with the Accord you get a complete, all-around package of comfort, control, refinement, and great acceleration.
Can you tell I fell for this car?

But it’s not just this Touring V-6 model, the new top of the line Accord for 2016. Even the base model, the four-cylinder LX, has much to recommend it, starting with the low ($22,925) price of entry to the Accord family. It is also available with either a six-speed manual or a continuously variable automatic transmission. The active safety features are all available as options on every model and were included on the Touring model as standard.

The active safety features on the 2016 Accord are adaptive cruise control (ACC), collision mitigation braking (CMBS), forward collision warning (FCW), lane departure warning (LDW), and road departure mitigation (RDM). I normally detest acronyms—they tend to add more confusion when people are already confused—but at least these are not made-up names. Remarkably, to get the whole suite of features on the LX, Sport, or EX four-cylinder Accord models costs only $1,000. Choose the model with the Honda Sensing package to get them all.

The reason to get the Touring model, in addition to the highly desirable V-6, is the inclusion of luxury features—heated front and rear seats, rain-sensing wipers, front and rear parking sensors, and automatic high beams, as well as larger front brakes and special high-performance suspension components.
There’s also an Accord Coupe, available in all the same trim levels as the sedan, but unlike in previous years, there is no hybrid model for 2016.

Technology is a big part of the story in the 2016 Accord, including both Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, a huge step forward that lets you use many of your smartphone’s apps through the car’s infotainment screen, keeping your eyes off the phone and on the road. I found the voice-activated navigation system easy to use and the dual-screen setup intuitive and helpful. The 7.7-inch upper screen shows you your audio settings and rearview camera images; you can also upload a personal photo to be the default image—sort of the Honda equivalent of the bud vase in the Volkswagen Beetle. The lower 7.0-inch touchscreen is where navigation, trip information, and Apple CarPlay or Android Auto icons live.

I can’t review any Honda without praising the excellent multi-angle rearview camera with its LaneWatch function, standard on all 2016 Accords. You get a choice of wide, normal, or top-down views with the rearview camera, and when you activate the right turn signal, you get a camera shot of what’s coming up behind you on the right. Don’t be tempted to just leave the blinker on permanently; you don’t have to. Simply press the end of the turn signal stalk to see that right-side image all the time.

Honda shoppers can learn all about this and other features on the Honda Owners website, which describes and illustrates the technology in an understandable way. I’ve said it often, but it bears repeating: connectivity and active safety tech are two good reasons to buy a new car now, and the Accord has plenty of both to tempt you.

metaDescription: How to save a bundle when your bundle of joy is off to college.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: School is in session. Yes, for your kids, but also for you. This lesson is for parents of young drivers. The cost of adding your child to your auto insurance policy can certainly dampen the excitement of the milestone of earning a driver’s license. We may not be as money savvy as Suze Orman, but we do have some tips to save some greenbacks on your insurance. The time to do your insurance homework is well before your child drives away from the DMV with his or her license. I personally was not so smart. The day my daughter was added to our auto insurance policy, our premium nearly doubled. So you should do as I say, not what I did.

1. Start early. When your student starts driver ed, begin exploring insurance for your young driver. Compile a list of questions to ask potential insurance companies. Get quotes from at least three suitors. It makes sense to begin with your current insurance company and see what programs they offer for young drivers. But be prepared to walk if another company can save you money.

2. Learn about good-student discounts. All of the nagging to get your kid to get good grades will not only get them into a good college, it may help to beef up their college fund at the same time. Just as an example, a co-worker gets $294.41 knocked off the State Farm premium on her college student’s car every six months because of a good-student discount. There are good statistical reasons why new drivers pay high premiums, but many companies let you reduce that a bit with a financial incentive for a good grade-point average. This usually applies to both high school and college students, including homeschoolers, but make sure to confirm. Each company has its own age restrictions—State Farm grants the discount until the twenty-fifth birthday, even after a student has earned a degree. Ask what magic GPA number is required to get (and maintain) the discount.
AAA, State Farm, and Liberty Mutual all offer some kind of “away” discount; all require the student’s school address to be at least 100 miles from home.

3. Find out about student-away savings. My daughter’s university is an eight-hour drive from home, so she qualifies for Liberty Mutual’s Student Away at School discount, saving us $125 per month. Ka-ching. Again, each company treats this discount differently, but AAA, State Farm, and Liberty Mutual all offer some kind of “away” discount; all require the student’s school address to be at least 100 miles from home. Check the age restrictions and find out if there are driving limitations when they are home. State Farm allows the student to drive the family car during breaks, including summer. AAA assured us that the student is still covered when driving a friend’s car at school, as well as when he or she is a passenger or a pedestrian.

4. Do the math before your child takes a car to college. Don’t miss exploring the financial implications of having your child take a car to college. You must inform your insurance company of the new address of the student. The premium may increase based on the location. Also, find out the coverage if friends drive the car. My daughter does not have a car at school, but she drives friends' cars. I often wonder if her friends' parents know they are providing a car to a bevy of young drivers.

5. Double check (and double back to check) your work. As your young driver progresses from age sixteen to twenty-five, remember to check back in with your company to see if any new programs apply to you. If your student was not eligible for the good-student discount when your coverage began but brings home a stellar report card later, or if he or she transfers to a college farther from home, make sure to let your company know. Most companies will not allow both the student away discount and good-student discount, so you may need to compare.

6. Share the information with your child. These discounts add up to thousands of dollars over the span of time your child may be covered under your family policy. So it is important to take this lesson seriously. Include your child in the research and help him or her understand more thoroughly your insurance policy and the whole cost of entry into the fabulous world of car ownership.

Resources for Parents of Teen Drivers

AAA

Liberty Mutual

State Farm

title: 1 Easy Way You Can Help New Drivers
subTitle: It's National Teen Driver Safety Week. Michelin and Katie Couric are crowdsourcing safety advice.
promoTitle: 1 Easy Way You Can Help New Drivers
promoTeaserSmall: It's National Teen Driver Safety Week. Michelin and Katie Couric are crowdsourcing safety advice.
promoTeaser: It's National Teen Driver Safety Week. Michelin and Katie Couric are crowdsourcing safety advice.
keywords: 1 Easy Way You Can Help New Drivers
metaTitle: 1 Easy Way You Can Help New Drivers - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: It's National Teen Driver Safety Week. Michelin and Katie Couric are crowdsourcing safety advice.

pageElements.text: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/AulcjLA-dXA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

TV personality Katie Couric and tiremaker Michelin are asking us to celebrate National Teen Driver Safety Week by sharing advice to help young drivers stay safe. Car crashes are the top cause of death among teenagers, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration reports. Sure, we send them off to driver education classes, but, Michelin's latest driver survey reports, only 49 percent of driver ed graduates feel the classes have completely prepared them to drive. Getting them the rest of the way there is everyone's job. Parents', of course, but really the whole community of drivers can help by mentoring and setting good examples, Michelin points out.
Only 49 percent of driver ed graduates feel the classes have completely prepared them to drive. Getting them the rest of the way is everyone's job.
This week, using the hashtag #SharingSafety, Michelin is asking people to Tweet their favorite safe driving suggestions. Here are some of our favorites that have shown up under the hashtag so far.
"Stop acting like not knowing about your car is cool. You should know what it can and cannot do." Good one, and that goes for technology and maintenance as much as performance.

In fact, the Michelin survey found that 29 percent of teen drivers don't know how to check their car's oil, 32 percent don't know how to check tire pressure, and 57 percent admit they don't know how to change the windshield wipers. Parents, this is an easy one: Don't hand over the keys to the car until you've taught these three essential skills.

"Keep plenty of distance between you and the car in front of you."

In the Michelin survey, 69 percent of drivers reported seeing other drivers ignoring safe-driving practices daily. Teen drivers will need lots of reminders—and watching you keep your own safe distance when you are driving—to help them stick to this one.

"Driving is an activity, so be an *active participant.* Check your mirrors, note other motorists' behavior. Be ready." The Michelin study found that 81 percent of drivers think they are capable, but 66 percent have felt "unsafe" when someone else was driving.

Katie Couric, in the video above, tells about how she was ready: she remembered and applied advice she'd learned about hydroplaning on wet pavement, and it helped save her from an accident. What advice do you have that could help new drivers? Share it here or with the #SharingSafety hashtag on Twitter.

title: 2016 Honda Civic
subTitle: The best Civic in almost two decades, and that's saying something.
promoTeaserSmall: The best Civic in almost two decades, and that's saying something.
promoTeaser: The best Civic in almost two decades, and that's saying something.
metaDescription: The best Civic in almost two decades, and that's saying something.

pageElements.text:
2016 Honda Civic Touring Sedan

Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive compact sedan
Trim levels: LX, EX, EX-T, EX-L, Touring
Base price: $19,475 (LX) (prices include destination charge)
This car: $27,335
Engine: Turbocharged 1.5-liter four-cylinder, 174 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable automatic
Fuel economy: 31 mpg city/42 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Honda satellite navigation system with voice recognition and real time digital traffic info
Options I can’t live without: Honda Sensing (forward collision warning, collision mitigation braking, lane departure warning, lane keeping assist, road departure mitigation, adaptive cruise control, approximately $1000; standard on Touring model)
Notable standard features on this model: Turbo boost meter; 17-inch aluminum alloy wheels; 7.0-inch touchscreen color display; 450-watt premium audio; leather seating; power adjustable heated front seats; leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift knob; Bluetooth; Pandora; power moonroof; dual zone auto climate control; rearview camera; LED headlights and turn signals; Honda Sensing safety suite
You might also be considering: Ford Focus, Hyundai Elantra, Kia Forte, Mazda 3, Nissan Sentra, Toyota Corolla, Volkswagen Jetta

During its four-plus decades as a Honda U.S. market staple, the Civic has been through more changes than a chameleon strolling across a plaid tablecloth. Some of the changes have been technological game changers, others not so propitious, but through it all the Civic has been a solid contender among compact cars.
The car you see here is just the first chapter in an expanded lineup story that features more choices than ever before.

Now here’s the tenth generation, and it’s fair to say Honda has gone all in, putting more chips on the Civic than in any previous version. The car you see here is just the first chapter in an expanded lineup story that features more choices than ever before. Over the next eighteen months, you’ll also see the hotter Si version, a coupe, a hatchback, and, the pièce de résistance, a high-performance R edition to compete with factory hot rods such as the Ford Focus RS and the Volkswagen Golf R.

Like the previous generation, chapter one of the new Civic saga is a sedan—but the similarity between generations nine and ten ends right there. Descriptions of the new car read like something from a 1950s brochure—longer, lower, wider.

Dimensional increases in the compact class tend to be tiny, but the new Civic defies that convention. The roof (55.7 inches) is almost an inch lower, the width expands by 1.9 inches (to 70.9 inches), the wheelbase has been stretched 1.2 inches to 106.3, and overall length increases by 2.9 inches, to 182.3 inches.

The hoodline is down 1.6 inches, giving the driver better forward sightlines. Although the wheelbase and body are longer, the front overhang—the portion of the car extending beyond the front wheels—has been reduced by 1.4 inches, giving the Civic a sportier, more tightly wrapped, BMW-style profile. The extra length is devoted to the rear, where the trunk has been expanded from 13 to 15.1 cubic feet. Overall, it adds up to attractive proportions that bring to mind the look of European sport sedans.
Expanded interior volume is especially noticeable in the rear cabin, where legroom has grown to 37.4 inches, a specification worthy of a mid-size sedan.

Also, typical of Honda, almost all of the dimensional increase translates as expanded interior volume. This is particularly noticeable in the rear cabin, where legroom has grown to 37.4 inches, a specification worthy of a mid-size sedan.

Roominess is a key component of comfort, and interior material is another, albeit more subtle. Soft-touch surfaces abound. The seats are modestly sporty, supportive, and attractively upholstered, and there’s an expanded array of infotainment features, including Apple CarPlay and Android Auto. A seven-inch touchscreen dominates the center dash of higher trim levels (it's four inches in the basic LX), and standard equipment ranges from good to lavish.
We should add that the base model LX isn’t really all that basic. The interior benefits from the same material upgrades as the rest of the Civic lineup,

In an age of infatuation with the notion of autonomous cars, the new Civic is a vehicle that makes you want to drive—a car that may occasionally cause its owner to take the long way home, or volunteer to run weekend errands.

Everything is new here—a new chassis that’s substantially more rigid than generation nine. New suspension tuning. A new and more powerful brake system. A new steering system. New wheels. New tires. New engines—two of them. New transmissions—two of them as well.

The engines are both four-cylinders. The LX and EX get a 158-horsepower 2.0-liter, while the EX-T, EX-L, and Touring have the turbocharged 1.5-liter, rated for 174 horsepower. The transmissions are a six-speed manual and a continuously variable automatic.

One catch: the manual is available only in the basic LX trim level with its 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine. This is not an uncommon strategy among carmakers, but the lack of manual-transmission availability is always mystifying—although, to be fair, we can expect to see a manual transmission option with the higher-performance Civics coming in the months ahead.

At any rate, though we did log a few miles in an LX with manual transmission, enough to be impressed with its crisp shifts, most of our seat time was accumulated in a Touring version, the top of the line and loaded with every feature in the Civic catalog.

All the Civic Touring Sedan's luxury amenities make the going more pleasant—they’re detailed in the standard features list—but the traits that really set this new Civic apart in the compact crowd are dynamic: steering that’s sports-car quick, laser precise, and exemplary in the new era of electric systems; responses that are decisive; minimal body motions; powerful brakes; and impressive thrust from the new 1.5 turbo.

The only possible asterisk is the CVT, which retains hints of the behavior that’s been a turnoff for this type of transmission. There's a sense of engine and gearbox being out of sync under full throttle. Programming more artificial shift steps into the CVT’s computer controls, as with the new Nissan Maxima Sport, would mitigate this phenomenon. And to be fair, putting the transmission into Sport mode reduces the lag and simulates shifts above 5,000 rpm. Moreover, most drivers will rarely provoke this annoying trait in everyday driving.

On the upside, the new turbo engine—a first for Honda in the U.S.—is punchy (look for 60 mph to come up in less than seven seconds), and fuel economy is outstanding: 31 mpg city, 42 highway, according to the EPA. Beyond that, the suspension engineers have forged an inspired compromise between athletic response and supple ride quality. And—another tribute to the design and engineering team—interior noise levels are exceptionally low at all speeds, making this arguably the quietest compact sedan on the road.

The Verdict:

The tenth-generation Civic is the best that Honda has delivered in almost two decades. In many ways, it's the best in a very good compact class. It may well stake claim to all-around best when the many variants roll into showrooms in the months ahead, but for now we can say that this four-door first offering delivers everything one can expect in a contemporary compact sedan: good looks, a broad array of comfort and convenience equipment, several new safety features, excellent fuel economy, and a high fun-to-drive quotient.

At $27,355, the Civic Touring model is pretty expensive by compact sedan standards. But you can get most of the fancier features in one of the lesser trim levels—EX-T (from $23,035) or EX-L (from $24,535). For the truly cost-conscious buyer, start with the LX (from $19,475) or the EX (from $21,875).

In developing the latest Civic, rather than target its traditional compact competitors, Honda looked to premium European brands such as the Audi A3 and A4. It doesn’t take much driving to realize that the strategy has paid off. ##

title: 5 Cool Things about the Newest Mini
subTitle: If winter comes, can spring be far behind? With it will come this beauty, the 2016 Mini Convertible.
promoTitle: 5 Cool Things about the Newest Mini
promoTeaserSmall: If winter comes, can spring be far behind? With it will come this beauty, the 2016 Mini Convertible.
promoTeaser: If winter comes, can spring be far behind? With it will come this beauty, the 2016 Mini Convertible.
keywords: 5 Cool Things about the Newest Mini
metaTitle: 5 Cool Things about the Newest Mini - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: If winter comes, can spring be far behind? With it will come this beauty, the 2016 Mini Convertible.

pageElements.text: The winter is ahead of us, but so is the promise of spring, and if you’d like to fantasize about roaring down a country lane with the sun on your head and your hair blowing in the wind, that’s only natural. Just in time to make that dream come true comes a new version of the Mini Convertible, this one with a choice of two BMW turbo engines. That’s good news for droptop fans, since the two-seat Roadster is going out of production.
Here are five cool things about the new Convertible, which goes on sale in March:

1. Four seats. Heaven forbid we mention “practicality” in the same breath with “convertible,” but this is a droptop you can use every day and run errrands in. In fact, this Mini is 4.5 inches longer, 1.7 inches wider, and 0.8 inch taller than the one it replaces. For those who think Minis are outgrowing their name, you might have a point. But: groceries! Friends! Kids! (Those seats can be had in Malt Brown diamond-stitched leather, by the way.)

2. The sport version (Cooper S) with a six-speed manual transmission. We think that is the way to go. Its engine is a turbocharged four-cylinder making 189 horsepower. Sounds more fun than the Convertible’s standard three-cylinder turbo with its 134 horsepower, doesn’t it?

3. The Always Open Timer. This lets you keep track of how many hours you’ve spent styling and profiling with the top down. Presumably this is for the kind of people who measure their daily steps, carbohydrate intake, and REM sleep cycles. But it’s also the kind of frivolity that makes Mini so much fun.

4. You can get the soft top with a black-and-gray Union Jack woven into it. Whether you opt for that or the standard cloth top, it’s all electric and opens in eighteen seconds at speeds up to 18 mph. You can also slide the roof open part way for a sunroof feeling.

5. There’s a rain warning app. It comes with the optional 8.8-inch infotainment screen (a 6.5-inch screen is standard). That screen is huge inside the bulbous interior of the Mini Convertible, and who doesn’t want to know when it’s about to be time to put that top back up?

images.caption: 2016 Mini Convertible's power soft top goes up or down in 18 seconds.
2016 Mini Convertible with optional woven Union Jack top design.

title: 2015 Smart ForTwo
subTitle: Individualism on the cheap.
promoTeaserSmall: Individualism on the cheap.
promoTeaser: Individualism on the cheap.
metaDescription: Individualism on the cheap. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Front-wheel-drive minicoupe or convertible
Price range: $12,490–$17,930 (plus destination charge of at least $750, varying by region)
Trim levels: Pure, Passion, Electric Drive
Engines: 1.0-liter three-cylinder, 70 horsepower; 55 kW electric motor, 74 horsepower
Transmission: 5-speed automatic, single-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): I-3: 34/38; Electric: 122/93 mpg-e (city/highway)
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: good (moderate overlap front, side, roof strength) and acceptable (head restraints & seats); National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 3/5 rollover, not rated overall
Our favorite standard feature: Safety cell with matching door mirror trim and radiator grille
Notable standard features on this model: Stability control with hill start assist, safety cell, and body panels available in multiple colors
Notable options on this model: Heated seats, electric power steering, cruise control package, Brabus sport package
You might also be considering: Fiat 500, Mini Cooper, Scion iQ

The 2015 Smart Fortwo is at the end of its model run and awaits replacement by the all-new 2016 model, coming later this year. That could mean good deals at the showroom. The Fortwo is available in three models: Pure, Passion, and Electric Drive. The Pure is about as basic as any car currently in the market, with manually adjustable mirrors, crank windows, and power steering as an option. Safety is lavishly attended to, though, and there are eight air bags as well as standard electronic stability control and anti-lock brakes. The Passion coupe adds a sunroof, power windows and mirrors, alloy wheels, a decent radio, and available heated leather seats. The Passion cabriolet has an automatic convertible top with a glass rear window. The Electric Drive is also available as a coupe or cabriolet, and the coupe comes with a sunroof. In either model, the interior includes the Passion’s electrically operated features. We have already driven the 2016 Smart Fortwo and can report it’s much improved. But as we said, a bargain is a bargain. In the meantime, your parking problem may need an immediate solution.

New for 2015

There are no changes to the Smart ForTwo for 2015.

title: 2016 Smart ForTwo
subTitle: Small wonder gets a bit bigger and a bit nicer.
promoTeaserSmall: Small wonder gets a bit bigger and a bit nicer.
promoTeaser: Small wonder gets a bit bigger and a bit nicer.
metaDescription: Small wonder gets a bit bigger and a bit nicer.

pageElements.text:
Type: Two-passenger, front-wheel-drive minicompact coupe or cabriolet
Price range: $15,400 – $19,230 (prices include destination charge)
Trim levels: Pure, Passion, Prime, Proxy
Engine: Turbocharged 0.8-liter three-cylinder, 89 horsepower
Transmission: Five-speed manual, six-speed dual-clutch automatic
Fuel economy: 34 mpg city/39 mpg highway (manual), 32/39 mpg (automatic), 107 MPGe (electric)
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA): Not yet rated (Smart Electric Drive: 4/5 stars); Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS): Not yet rated
Notable standard features: LED daytime running lights, Bluetooth connectivity, twin-section tailgate
Notable options: Panoramic roof (top trim levels): sport package ($600) with three-spoke steering wheel, shift paddles, chrome-tipped exhaust, and lowered suspension; eight-speaker JBL audio system ($490)
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Spark, Fiat 500, Ford Fiesta, Honda Fit, Nissan Versa Note, Toyota Prius c, Toyota Yaris

This is the least likely Mercedes-Benz you will ever see, but it is indeed a member of the family. The Smart ForTwo, just redone for 2016, benefits from the safety and quality commitment of its iconic parent company. Even though it is a minuscule two-seater, in its new version it is 3.9 inches wider, giving you (and your sole passenger) just that extra skosh more personal space. The vaunted tridion safety cell that makes the ForTwo crush resistant has been joined by standard crosswind assist and eight air bags, and now there's also optional forward collision warning. A five-speed manual transmission is standard and a six-speed twin-clutch automatic transmission optional, with either of which you'll get 39 mpg on the highway. If you move to the Electric Drive ForTwo, you'll get 107 MPGe, one very good reason to consider that choice. Smart markets these as leased cars at $139 per month for the coupe and $199 per month for the cabriolet with a three-year lease term.

A car like the ForTwo is for a very special niche: city people who aren't afraid to look and drive a little different. The 8.8-foot-long car with its awesome 22.8-foot turning radius has clear advantages in city traffic and parking situations. The fuel economy is not astoundingly great considering the diminutive size, if that's all you care about. Chances are you will be just as interested in making a bit of a lifestyle statement as a financial decision, if you're interested in a ForTwo.
New for 2016: The ForTwo is all new for 2016.

More to Read:

Smart Electric City Tour

images.caption: Smart CEO Dr. Annette Winkler introduced the 2016 ForTwo at the New York Auto Show this spring.

title: 2016 Kia Optima SX
subTitle: A perfect example of just how fast the world is moving.
promoTeaserSmall: A perfect example of just how fast the world is moving.
promoTeaser: A perfect example of just how fast the world is moving.
metaDescription: A perfect example of just how fast the world is moving.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive midsize sedan
Trim levels: LX, LX 1.6T, EX, SX, SXL
Base price: $22,665 (base LX, with 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine); $30,515 (SX) (prices include destination charge)
This car: $35,315
Engine: Turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine, 247 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 22 mpg city/32 mpg highway
Safety: Not yet rated
Competitors (prices include destination charge):
2016 Mazda 6 Grand Touring ($31,015)
2016 Ford Fusion Titanium ($31,505)
2016 Volkswagen Passat SEL Premium ($32,610)

Fun-O-Meter: 8

Five years. That’s how fast the world of Kia has moved off its axis. When Kia launched its third-generation Optima in 2011, it signaled the beginning of something very big from the Korean company known for its inexpensive econocars and their forgettable sheetmetal. This suddenly lovely Optima was the first under the direction of the immensely talented new chief designer, Peter Schreyer, who left Audi at the top of his game. It was as remarkable a transformation as any Audi he’d ever done, from drab to fab so fast that it became Kia’s first model to reach 150,000 in sales in a year, which was a 480% improvement from 2010 sales.

As word spread and awards began to roll in (Cars.com’s Best of 2011, finalist for Motor Trend’s Car of the Year, nominated for Car and Driver’s Ten Best, among the most significant), Optima sales blew up, tripling in 2011 and then nearly doubling again in 2012, and holding steady right through this past September. Over the past five years of its life, the Optima’s second-best month was recorded in May of this year. That is serious staying power.

So if you think that this fourth-generation Optima hasn’t strayed far from the previous model, well, yeah. Or in the words of the top brass: “The current car has been great for us for five years. We just refined it. We didn’t want to screw it up. It’s the most important vehicle in our franchise.”

Ah, but it has changed, and changed for the better in so many ways. It has gained a skosh in every important dimension—length, height, and width. The amalgamation of a half-inch here and there and that 1.2-inch extra width makes the cabin more comfortable for life-size humans. It also adds cargo space, “optimizes” the car’s performance in new offset crash standards, and gives the Optima more presence all the way around. Inside, the dashboard area is beautifully laid out more thoughtfully than before. It is designed to be more horizontal, and that glorious eight-inch touchscreen has matte glass so it doesn’t have that reflectiveness that is so annoying in other cars.
Kia’s first ever bi-xenon HID lights can be optioned with Dynamic Bending Lamps. You turn the steering wheel, and those lights turn with you. They are fantastic.

The sheetmetal is changed only subtly. A sharp new version of Kia’s signature grille now flows perfectly into redesigned headlamps. Those headlamps are worthy of a special mention. They’re Kia’s first ever bi-xenon HID lights, and they can be optioned with Dynamic Bending Lamps. You turn the steering wheel, and those lights turn with you; it’s a technology I first tested on a 1983 Oldsmobile 98, then across the German carmakers, beginning with high-end Mercedes-Benzes and on down to the Volkswagen Golf. Congrats, Kia. They are fantastic.

Our SX test car is the second-highest of five Optima trim levels, seriously loaded for $30,515. It had only one optional package, but it was a doozy both in cost and content. For $4,800, the Premium Technology package includes a power front passenger’s seat, heated and ventilated front seats, heated outboard rear seats, and high-beam assist to go with the standard active-cornering HID headlights. It also includes a vast array of driver assistance technology, sensibly named to give you a good clue as to each one’s function, from the increasingly common smart cruise control, blind spot detection, and lane departure warning systems to rear cross-traffic detection, front collision warning, a 360-degree view surround-view mirror (which you will consider to be pure magic), and autonomous emergency braking, which can bring the Optima to a complete stop when it senses you aren’t cutting it. Did not test that.

Bundled right in the middle of all this tech and safety—and a goodly chunk of that $4,800—is a panoramic sunroof that completely covered the rear seating area, and Kia’s first offering of Harman Kardon’s most trick QLS surround sound system. This (also pure magic) super stereo has the ability to extract signals from an original recording and redistribute them for a clearer and more detailed sound; it uses an amazing patented technology that can rebuild audio signals lost in the digital compression process.

Can you tell I think this package is worth the price? Alternatively, you can jump up to the highest of Optimas, the SXL, for $36,615, all-in. It adds rich quilted Nappa leather trim and a wireless charging pad for your phone, a feature which becomes more desirable as Android Auto and Apple CarPlay become available “two to three months” into the launch stream of the new Optima.
The Optima was always known as a better than average sport. According to the 100-mile Rocky Mountain test loop I spent the day flying around, it is now serious business.

The Optima was always known as a better than average sport, but according to the 100-mile high Rocky Mountain test loop I spent the day flying around, it is now serious business. Blasting over Independence Pass at an elevation of 12,095 feet on the Continental Divide, I noticed zero effect on the engine’s power, even as I noticed the altitude’s totally yucky effect on my brain and lungs. Time to descend.

Coming down that mountain to Aspen (elevation 7,890 feet) was the ultimate test for the brakes and the new electric power steering. I love practicing carving the smoothest path possible on a mountain road. Downhill. At speed. It was sublime, thanks to the manumatic feature of the six-speed automatic which allowed me to flick the shifter up and down through turn after turn.

A lighter, stiffer chassis and the use of a lot more structural adhesive and high-strength steel in the body made a world of difference in the new Optima’s high-speed stability, super-connected steering response, and all-around sports car feel. I had a great day driving in unbelievable scenery, and my passenger did not throw up. Bonus.

The 2016 Optima is coming out of Kia’s plant in Georgia, so Southern showrooms will see the new Optima first in October, followed by the rest of the country starting in early  November to December. And if you’re more like the 40 percent of Optima buyers who traditionally buy the entry-level LX, you’ll be pleased to note that this base model has more standard features than ever, at the same $22,665 price.
I had a great day driving in unbelievable scenery, and my passenger did not throw up. Bonus.

The next five years will be another lightning round of change for Kia as it rolls out twenty-two new or significantly revised products, including hybrid and plug-in versions of the Optima that are coming out in early 2016. This is a good time to remember that Kia is currently in second place behind only Porsche in the prestigious J.D. Power Initial Quality Study. It is among Consumer Reports’ 2015 Top Ten in brand reliability. And it still comes with a ten-year/100,000-mile warranty—one of the best in the business.

title: 10+ Cars That Auto Brake
subTitle: Find a car with automated emergency braking to save you from yourself.
promoTeaserSmall: Find a car with automated emergency braking to save you from yourself.
promoTeaser: Find a car with automated emergency braking to save you from yourself.
metaDescription: Find a car with automated emergency braking to save you from yourself.

pageElements.text: It’s a golden age of safety in cars. Joke around all you want about how you don’t want cars doing your driving for you; why wouldn’t you want your car to help keep you from rear-ending someone or hitting a cyclist? The answer is that you would. Sophisticated technology is at its best when it’s helping protect you, yet leaving you in charge of the driving.

Automated braking is one of the most promising features you can get on a vehicle today. Front-facing radar, cameras, and laser sensors  “watch” the traffic in front of your vehicle. They’ll notice when your car is closing in on a vehicle or obstacle in front of it, warn you with visual and sound alerts, and then put the brakes on for you if you don’t react in time.

This is such a good idea that the major safety groups—the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration—are working with the automakers to encourage them to bring more of these features onto more vehicles. And that’s all going toward making you and others around you much safer out on the road.
For now, this technology is mostly found on higher-end vehicles and the more expensive trim levels, but watch for it to trickle down to more affordable models quickly.

Ten auto manufacturers—Audi, BMW, Ford, General Motors, Mazda, Mercedes-Benz, Tesla, Toyota, Volkswagen and Volvo—have committed to work toward making automated emergency braking systems a standard feature on cars, and they’re working with the safety watchdogs to make a timetable for that.

For now, this technology is mostly found on higher-end vehicles and the more expensive trim levels, but watch for it to trickle down to more affordable models quickly. Here’s a guide to some of the brands where you can find it now. You're welcome.

1. Audi
What it’s called: Pre Sense Plus
Part of a package called: Driver Assistance package
What does it cost? $2,100 to $2,550 (bundled with lane keeping assist, adaptive cruise control, and more)
What models have it? A6/S6, A7/S7, A8/S8

2. BMW
What it’s called: Active Cruise Control with Stop and Go
Part of a package called: Active Driving Assistant
What does it cost? $1,900 (bundled with lane departure warning, active cruise control, pedestrian protection)
What models have it? 5 Series, 6 Series, 7 Series

3. General Motors
What it’s called: Front Automatic Braking (Chevrolet and Buick): Front and Rear Automatic Braking (Cadillac)
Part of a package called: Buick: Driver Confidence packages 1 and 2 (both required); Cadillac: Driver Assist package; Chevrolet: Adaptive Cruise Control
What does it cost? Buick: $2,235 (bundled with lane departure warning, blind spot monitoring, cross-traffic alert, head-up display, and more); Cadillac: $2,395 (bundled with adaptive cruise control); Chevrolet: $995 (bundled with adaptive cruise control)
What models have it? Buick Regal and LaCrosse; Cadillac, all models; Chevrolet Impala (pictured), Suburban, Tahoe

4. Honda
What it’s called: Collision Mitigation Braking System (CMBS)
Part of a package called: Honda Sensing
What does it cost? $1,000 to $1,800 (bundled with forward collision warning, lane departure warning, adaptive cruise control, and more)
What models have it? Accord, CR-V, Pilot

5. Hyundai
What it’s called: Automatic Emergency Braking
Part of a package called: Ultimate package
What does it cost? $1,750 (bundled with lane departure warning, rear park sensors, smart cruise control, and more)
What models have it? Genesis, Sonata, Tucson

6. Mazda
What it’s called: Smart Brake Support, Smart City Brake Support
Part of a package called: i-Activsense
What does it cost? $1,500 (bundled with radar cruise control, lane departure warning, and more)
What models have it? CX-3, CX-5, Mazda 6 Grand Touring

7. Mercedes-Benz
What it’s called: Distronic Plus with Pre-Safe Brake
Part of a package called: Driver Assistance Package
What does it cost? $2,800 (bundled with cross-traffic assist, blind spot and lane keeping assistance, and more)
What models have it? E-Class, S-Class

8. Subaru
What it’s called: Pre-Collision Braking
Part of a package called: EyeSight
What does it cost? $1,395 to 3,090 (EyeSight package includes adaptive cruise control, pre-collision braking, lane departure and sway warning; bundled with navigation and more)
What models have it? Forester, Impreza, Legacy, Outback, WRX, Crosstrek

9. Volkswagen
What it’s called: Autonomous Emergency Braking system
Part of a package called: Driver Assistance package
What does it cost? $950 to $1,495
What models have it? Golf, GTI, Golf SportWagen, Jetta TSI

10. Volvo
What it’s called: Automatic Emergency Braking
Part of a package called: City Safety with cyclist detection and full auto braking
What does it cost? Standard equipment on 2016 models
What models have it? XC60, XC90
Top image: ZF-TRW

title: 2016 Volkswagen Passat
subTitle: Reskinned, refined, with a sporty R-Line added! And still one of the best mid-size sedans out there.
promoTeaserSmall: Reskinned, refined, with a sporty R-Line added! And still one of the best mid-size sedans out there.
promoTeaser: Reskinned, refined, with a sporty R-Line added! And still one of the best mid-size sedans out there.
metaDescription: Reskinned, refined, with a sporty R-Line added! And still one of the best mid-size sedans out there.

pageElements.text:
2016 Volkswagen Passat SEL Premium

Type: Front-wheel-drive, five-passenger four-door sedan
Trim levels: S, SE, SE with Technology, SEL, SEL Premium, R-Line, all with 1.8-liter four-cylinder; SEL Premium with V-6
Base price: $24,795 (S)
This car: $35,090 (prices include destination charge)
Engine: Turbocharged 1.8-liter four-cylinder, 170 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 25 mpg city/38 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars for rollover, otherwise not yet rated; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: not yet rated
My favorite standard feature: Hands-free easy-open trunk
Notable standard features on this model: Eighteen-inch alloy wheels, LED headlights, fog lights, power sunroof, 6.3-inch touchscreen with navigation, heated leather seats, premium audio, VW Car-Net (integrated smartphone apps, emergency assistance, infotainment), Bluetooth connectivity, rearview camera, lane departure warning, autonomous emergency braking, lane keeping assist, rear cross-traffic alert with braking, adaptive cruise control, twenty-four-hour roadside assistance (incorporated with three-year/36,000-mile warranty)
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Malibu, Chrysler 200, Ford Fusion, Honda Accord, Hyundai Sonata, Kia Optima, Mazda 6, Nissan Altima, Toyota Camry

The Volkswagen Passat is the German automaker's premier sedan in the U.S. market, designed and developed for American buyers and assembled in Chattanooga, Tennessee. It’s the roomiest car in its class: quiet, mannerly, responsive, with dynamics that have an engaging Germanic feel. For 2016, the good news is: the Volkswagen Passat is an even greater value than before.

That improvement will be needed. Not only does the Passat contend in a very crowded and competitive arena, now it operates against the bleak backdrop of VW’s self-inflicted 2.0-liter diesel emissions predicament.
VW has dropped the Passat’s optional manual transmission for lack of popularity, and of course the 2.0-liter turbo-diesel has been taken off the sales menu for now.

Volkswagen characterizes the 2016 Passat as new, but this is the kind of new that doesn’t extend much below what meets the eye, fingers, and backside. The chassis dimensions haven't changed, and the only difference in terms of powertrains is what has been deleted. VW has dropped the Passat’s optional manual transmission for lack of popularity, and of course the 2.0-liter turbo-diesel—the engine that’s in the eye of VW’s emissions-gaming hurricane—has been taken off the sales menu until it can be brought into full compliance with EPA standards.

This leaves Passat shoppers with two engine choices: a 1.8-liter turbocharged four-cylinder (170 horsepower), the standard powerplant, and VW’s V-6—which is rated for 280 horsepower. However, the V-6 is only offered in the top SEL Premium V-6 trim level. On a positive EPA note, highway fuel economy ratings for the 1.8-liter engine are up 2 mpg, to 38 mpg. (The V-6 model gets 20 mpg in the city and 28 mpg on the highway.)

While the subliminal Passat is essentially unchanged, there is much that’s new on the outside, although the updates are a little subtle. VW has redesigned all the surfaces from the windshield forward—the grille is more assertive, and the lighting array now includes the option of LED headlights, fog lights, and taillights. Bumpers are also new, front and rear, as is the trunk lid.

VW design chief Klaus Bischoff says the styling updates add up to “a dynamic presence and more sophisticated look.” In most of the trim levels, the dynamism is subdued; this is still basically a conservative design. But it does have a more upscale presence than the 2015 car.
For the first time, there is an R-Line Passat. It's a sporty option in other VW models, and adding one to the Passat lineup helps mitigate the conservatism.

For the first time, there is an R-Line version of the Passat. This trim level is a sporty option in other VW models, and adding one to the Passat lineup helps mitigate the conservatism. R-Line cosmetics include a revised front bumper, rocker panel extensions, a rear diffuser, black accents, and nineteen-inch alloy wheels wearing 235/40 tires with a high-speed (186 mph) ZR rating.

The upscale look continues inside, a quiet, straightforward elegance with upgraded materials. There's much that is new: the dashboard, instruments, steering wheel, and trim. The new 6.3-inch center-dash touchscreen is the home for the second generation of VW’s MIB infotainment system, which is also new for the 2016 model year. And, inevitably, there's now enhanced connectivity via VW Car-Net with App-Connect, allowing integration with three different smartphone platforms: Apple CarPlay, Android Auto, and a new one on us, Mirror Link.

New safety features include VW’s post-collision braking system, along with a number of optional active safety features: forward collision warning, autonomous emergency braking (a feature that NHTSA is pushing to make standard in all cars), adaptive cruise control, lane departure warning and assist, blind spot monitoring, park assist, and rear traffic alert. A rearview camera is standard on all trim levels.

And, a very appealing new option for parental units trudging through supermarket parking lots while loaded with groceries, the trunk lid opens by simply passing a foot under the rear bumper, a thoughtful technology pioneered by Ford.
If you like the Germanic feeling of a Volkswagen, in the interest of full disclosure, you need to know that this made-for-and-in-America Passat is a little softer than its European counterpart.
There’s autobahn development in this car’s heritage, and it shows. The Passat displays the kind of stability required for running at 120 mph.

But not every car has to be a track star; this is a family sedan, after all. Ride quality is supple, and there’s a little more body roll than you’d get in a BMW. On the other hand, there’s autobahn development in this car’s heritage, and it shows, displaying the kind of stability required for running at 120 mph.

Not that you’re likely to be doing 120 mph on your daily commute, or while you're carting the kids to school. But stability is as welcome at 60 mph as it is at autobahn speeds. Moreover, while the suspension is tuned toward comfort, the Passat’s responses in quick maneuvers are prompt, braking performance is stronger than most cars in this class, and interior noise is low at all speeds.

Power from the 1.8-liter turbo is respectable, sufficient for daily commuting as well as passing on two-lane highways. And, if you like speed, the V-6 trims 0-to-60-mph times, albeit at a higher cost ($37,655).
About the only dynamic element that could use a little work is the electric steering, which is vague and overassisted below about 50 mph.

For the most part, Volkswagen is holding the 2015 line on 2016 pricing, which ranges from $23,260 for the entry-level Passat S across five more trim levels to the top-of-the-line V-6 SEL Premium ($35,090). And standard feature content has been increased in all models, enhancing the value story. VW says there is no base model in the lineup, and the Passat S vindicates this assertion. Its standard equipment list includes sixteen-inch aluminum alloy wheels, dual-zone automatic climate control, the MIB touchscreen infotainment system, excellent audio, a CD player, a USB port, a rearview camera, and post-collision braking, which applies the brakes after the airbag sensors detect a crash, helping reduce residual kinetic energy.

Hedonists that we are, we spent most of our preview drive, staged on sinuous highways in Vermont's October country, in an SEL Premium model, equipped with everything but the V-6, and priced at $35,090. The V-6 version, the top of the line for the Passat, starts at $37,655. But you can get almost all of the SEL's features in one of the lesser trims—the SE, from $27,100, or the SEL, from $31,315. The sporty R Line starts at $24,795.

When it comes to style, quality, comfort, dynamics, and value, the Passat stacks up with the best in a class that’s loaded with very good cars. It’s a pleasure to drive; it’s exceptionally roomy, VW anticipates top safety ratings, and there’s that hint of Teutonic ancestry in its sinews. You could think of it as the automotive equivalent of a terrific strudel, baked in an American kitchen.

The 2016 Passat will reach VW showrooms in November.

title: 2016 Cadillac ATS
subTitle: Head turner will be even more interesting with the addition of the performance-minded ATS-V.
promoTeaserSmall: Head turner will be even more interesting with the addition of the performance-minded ATS-V.
promoTeaser: Head turner will be even more interesting with the addition of the performance-minded ATS-V.
metaDescription: Head turner will be even more interesting with the addition of the performance-minded ATS-V.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive coupe or sedan
Price ranges: Sedan: $34,210–$50,205; coupe: $38,990–$51,320; ATS-V sedan $61,460; ATS-V coupe $63,660 (prices include destination charge)
Trim levels: Standard, Luxury, Performance, Premium, ATS-V
Engines: 2.5-liter four-cylinder, 202 horsepower, turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 272 horsepower; 3.6-liter V-6, 321 horsepower
Transmissions: Six-speed manual, eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 2.5-liter: 21 mpg city/33 mpg highway; 2.0-liter, automatic: 21/30 mpg; 2.0-liter, manual: 19/30 mpg; 2.0-liter, automatic, AWD: 20/28 mpg; 3.6-liter, RWD: 18/28 mpg; 3.6-liter, AWD: 18/26 mpg
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not yet rated
Our favorite standard feature: New eight-speed automatic transmission with paddle shifters
Notable standard features on this model: Push-button start, Bost premium audio with SirusXM
Notable options on this model: Wireless phone charging, Cadillac Cue infotainment with Natural Voice Recognition and Apple CarPlay, head-up display, lane departure warning with lane keeping assist, Brembo performance brakes
You might also be considering: BMW 3 Series, Mercedes-Benz C-Class

The 2016 Cadillac ATS is the Cadillac aesthetic, writ small. For the price of an ordinary sedan, you can get the lively styling and the invigorating driving credentials of a Cadillac, and that's the whole point of the ATS. For 2016, there's an all-new 3.6-liter V-6 with cylinder deactivation and stop/start technology to save fuel. Even bigger news is the arrival of the twin-turbo ATS-V performance version as a coupe or sedan, upping the ATS desirability level considerably. You get a choice of normally aspirated or turbocharged four-cylinder engines along with that V-6, and there are sedan and coupe body styles to choose from. All engines come with an eight-speed automatic transmission with paddle shifters. On the ATS-V, a six-speed manual transmission is standard, while the eight-speed automatic is a $2,000 option.

Much of the enjoyment of this car, of course, will come from personalizing it. To that end, Cadillac offers four levels of interior olor and trim that leans heavily on two-tone color schemes—Light Platinum/Black, Kona Brown/Black, Medium Cashmere/Light Platinum, for example—and interesting materials and textures. There's oil-rubbed "bronze appearance" trim, carbon fiber, metal plating, high-gloss Sapele wood, and more, not to mention semi-aniline leather, sueded microfiber, and leatherette seating material choices. On the technology front, you'll find a full-color head-up display, a 5.7-inch instrument panel display with three windows, OnStar with 4G LTE on-board Wi-Fi, and Cadillac's Cue infotainment on an eight-inch touchscreen, compatible with Apple CarPlay and, later in the model year, Android Auto.

For active safety, choose the Safety and Security package on the Luxury trim level, or the Driver Awareness package on the Performance and Premium models. Among the technology features are the fabled GM Safety Alert Seat, which gives you a little buzz in the leg if you're about to veer out of your lane, along with forward collision alert, side blind zone and lane change alerts, rear cross-traffic alert, and rain-sensing wipers. An even higher level of active safety comes with the Driver Assist package for Performance and Premium models ($2,885), which includes full-speed-range adaptive cruise control and front and rear automatic braking. The latter is something that the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, along with GM and nine other automakers, is vowing to make standard on all vehicles in the not-too-distant future. On the Cadillac ATS, you can have it right now, if you want.

New for 2016:

ATS-V performance model, coupe and sedan
3.8-liter V-6 engine with stop/start and cylinder deactivation
Apple CarPlay and (late availability) Android Auto for smartphone app connectivity

More about the Cadillac ATS

2015 Cadillac ATS Coupe Designer Walkround January 24, 2014

title: Happy Halloween! 13 Orange Cars
subTitle: They’re wild, they’re cheerful. Why settle for vanilla when you can get pumpkin spice latte?
promoTeaserSmall: They’re wild, they’re cheerful. Why settle for vanilla when you can get pumpkin spice latte?
promoTeaser: They’re wild, they’re cheerful. Why settle for vanilla when you can get pumpkin spice latte?
metaDescription: They’re wild, they’re cheerful. Why settle for vanilla when you can get pumpkin spice latte?

pageElements.text: When you shop for a new car, do you go for the time-honored silver, white, or black exterior color? Millions of people do. Those are perfectly reasonable, sane, mature choices.
So boring.

If there’s ever a little voice in your head telling you to live a little, you’ll appreciate this gallery of brilliantly orange cars in every price range. At Halloween or any time of year, a car in orange will stand out, liven up the traffic, and make you smile. Just for fun, we’ve given them a Pumpkin-o-Meter rating, based on how good they look in orange. Prices include any extra charges for the orange paint job. Sometimes you just have to suffer for your art.

1. 2016 Ford Fiesta ST

Color name: Molten Orange
Base price: $22,440
Extra cost for orange? $595
Pumpkin-O-Meter rating: 7
Comments: Ford wisely saved this wild orange for the sporty model.

2. 2016 Chevrolet Trax LTZ

Color name: Orange Rock Metallic
Base price: $26,125
Extra cost for orange? No
Pumpkin-O-Meter rating: 6
Comments: Hot colors look great on little cars.

3. 2015 Fiat 500 Sport and 2016 Fiat 500X

Color name: Rame (500 Sport); Arancio (500X)
Base prices: $18,680 (500 Sport); $20,900 (500X)
Extra cost for orange? No
Pumpkin-O-Meter rating: 6.5
Comments: If any car should be a crazy color, the Fiat 500 is it.

4. 2016 Hyundai Veloster Turbo

Color name: Vitamin C
Base price: $23,435
Extra cost for orange? No
Pumpkin-O-Meter rating: 7
Comments: A Tang-y orange that shows every carefully carved surface.

5. 2016 Jeep Renegade Sport

Color name: Omaha Orange
Base price: $18,990
Extra cost for orange? No
Pumpkin-O-Meter rating: 3
Comments: Cool on a '69 Dodge Daytona. Not so much on a Renegade.

6. 2016 Nissan Murano S

Color name: Pacific Sunset
Base price: $30,445
Extra cost for orange? No
Pumpkin-O-Meter rating: 2
Comments: Does this seem orange enough to you? The feeling is less pumpkin, more like your grandma's kitchen in the 1970s.

7. 2016 Toyota Tacoma TRD Sport

Color name: Inferno (new for 2016)
Base price: $33,650
Extra cost for orange? Yes, color requires choosing V-6 Tow package ($650)
Pumpkin-O-Meter rating: 3
Comments: An orange pickup truck says "municipal fleet vehicle" to us.

8. 2015 Lexus RC F

Color name: Molten Pearl
Base price: $74,543
Extra cost for orange? Yes, color requires choosing Premium package ($4,400)
Pumpkin-O-Meter rating: 7
Comments: The perfect color to complement this wacko grille.

9. 2016 BMW Z4

Color name: Valencia Orange
Base price: $53,245
Extra cost for orange? $550
Pumpkin-O-Meter rating: 4
Comments: An orange BMW? No. Just no.

image.altText: Mercedes Benz G Class 2015 Sunset Beam

pageElements.text:
10. 2015 Mercedes-AMG G63

Color name: Sunset Beam
Base price (estimated): $157,150
Extra cost for orange? $20,000 as part of Performance Studio package (yes, you read that number right)
Pumpkin-O-Meter rating: 8
Comments: It's shaped nothing like a pumpkin, but it looks so In Your Face in orange.

11. 2016 Jaguar C-X75

Color name: Arancione
Base price: N/A; this is a concept car that appears in the newest James Bond film, Spectre
Extra cost for orange? N/A
Pumpkin-O-Meter rating: 10
Comments: The orange Jaguar gets the top Pumpkin-O-Meter rating because the villain is driving this one.

12. Lamborghini Huracán LP610-4

Color name: Arancio Borealis
Base price (estimated): $245,245
Extra cost for orange? $4,500
Pumpkin-O-Meter rating: 9
Comments: And can get it with orange brake calipers, too.

13. 2017 Lotus Evora 400

Color name: Metallic Orange
Base price: Not yet priced; goes on sale by year's end
Extra cost for orange? Not yet announced
Pumpkin-O-Meter rating: 8
Comments: Full-boat Halloween orange plus black, and with a pre-carved Jack-O-Lantern face!
